
Proceedings of the Board of Regents
July 1993 - June 1994
The University of Michigan




JULY MEETING, 1993


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, July 15, 1993
The Regents assembled at 1:00 p.m. at the Fleming Administration Building
and took a bus tour of construction sites in the Medical Center, North Campus,
and central campus areas. They reassembled in the Regents' Room at about 2:20
p.m. for a presentation by Jim Christenson, director of plant operations, on
facilities stewardship, capital renewal goals, and deferred maintenance realities.
Present were President Duderstadt and Regents Brown, McFee, McGowan,
Power, Varner, and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary
Kennedy, and Vice Presidents Cosovich, Hartford, and Womack were also present, as was Chancellor Renick. Chancellor Jones, Vice President Kelly, and
Regents Deitch and Baker were absent.
Executive Session Motion
At the conclusion of the presentation, Regent Power made the following
motion:
Pursuant to Section 8(a) of the Open Meetings Act, as amended by
1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed session on
Thursday, July 15, 1993, immediately following Public Comments, for
the purpose of considering a periodic personnel evaluation of a person
who has requested confidentiality.
Regent McGowan seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Public Comments
At 4:00 p.m., the Regents reassembled in the Anderson Room of the Michigan Union to hear public comments. All Regents were present.
The Regents heard comments from the following individuals on the topics
indicated: Robert C. Casad, Jr., alumnus, on Regents' Bylaw 11.151; Brian S.
Kight and Craig Greenberg, vice president and president, respectively, of Michigan Student Assembly, on proposed tuition increases; and Dave Devarti, citizen,
on being good citizens of the community relative to the Burr Oak Grove.
Friday, July 16, 1993
The Regents met at 9:20 am. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power,
Varner, and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy,




July Meeting, 1993


and Vice Presidents Cosovich, Hartford, Kelly, and Womack were also present, as
were Chancellors Jones and Renick.
The president called on Provost Whitaker, who introduced Lester Monts,
newly appointed vice provost for academic and multicultural affairs, to the assembly. Vice President Womack introduced Phil Abruzzi, newly appointed director of purchasing.
University of Michigan Solar Car Team
President Duderstadt announced that on June 26, 1993, the University of
Michigan Solar Car Team had won the national championship in Sunrayce 93.
He complimented the team on this accomplishment and then called on Regent
McFee, who offered the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan wish to commend the
University of Michigan Solar Car Team for their extraordinary success
in winning the national championship in Sunrayce 93, a solar car race
from Arlington, Texas, to Minneapolis, Minnesota, for North American
colleges and universities.
The team which raised the necessary funding and designed and
built the solar car consisted of over 100 students from across the
campus, including the College of Engineering, School of Business
Administration, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, and the
School of Art.
The race team, consisting of 21 key students, was faced with many
challenges, including the fact that they were considered the defending
champions by virtue of the first place finish of the 1990 solar car team
in the inaugural solar car race, Sunrayce 90. This year's team also had
to compete against 35 other teams, 20 of which were seasoned veterans
of Sunrayce 90.
The team successfully defended its crown by placing first in the
overall competition in spite of disputed penalties and cloudy weather.
The team strategy, teamwork, and a well-designed and reliable car were
the key factors in their successful demonstration of academic excellence
put into practice.
The Regents salute the 1993 Solar Car Team for their victory in
Sunrayce 93 and wish them continued success when they compete in the
World Solar Challenge in Australia in November of this year.
The motion was approved by acclamation, and there followed a round of
applause. The president recognized several members of the team who were in
attendance. Team leader Furqan Nazeeri accepted the resolution on behalf of the


2




July Meeting, 1993


team and spoke of the team's hopes for winning the world championship later in
the year.
1993-94 General Fund Operating Budget and Student Fees, Ann Arbor
Campus
President Duderstadt called on Provost Whitaker to present the proposed
1993-94 General Fund Operating Budget.
Provost Whitaker reviewed the underlying principals, long-term goals, and
short-term objectives used in preparing the 1993-94 budget. The objectives were
to provide a significant merit increase program, to meet increases in fixed costs,
to provide resources for the highest academic priorities, to maintain and enhance
access, to reinvest in the physical infrastructure, and to insure against forecasting errors in budgeted revenue. Provost Whitaker described the four sources of
General Fund revenues as being state appropriation, tuition and fees, indirect
cost recovery, and investment income. The 1993-94 budget calls for a zero increase in state appropriation, an increase of $26.0 million in tuition and fees, an
increase of $11.4 million in indirect cost recovery, and $0.4 million in other income. He noted that the indirect cost recovery rate had been increased from the
previous year and complimented the faculty for the increase in funded grants
and contracts that had led to the increase in that category. The budget also proposes a $50/term increase in the infrastructure maintenance fee, to yield an increase of $4.3 million. The total increase in General Fund revenue is $41.6
million, or 6.6 percent.
Provost Whitaker pointed out that the proportion of General Fund revenue
funded by state appropriation versus tuition and fees has gone from nearly 80
percent in the early 1960s to under 40 percent at the current time. The president
pointed out that publicly-funded institutions in 36 states had experienced a decrease in state appropriation last year, and he credited the Michigan legislature
for protecting its higher education budget from this situation. Regent Baker
observed that the reason tuition keeps rising is because the state has failed to
maintain the historic level of funding over the past 30 years.
Provost Whitaker credited the faculty for the projected increase in the
indirect cost recovery portion of the budget for 1993-94. He pointed out some
specific efforts that individual units are undertaking to contain costs and make
funds available for innovation through substitution. He noted that a compensation program was the highest budget priority for 1993-94 and complimented the
faculty and staff for having done an outstanding job in the face of no salary
increase in 1992-93.
Provost Whitaker then described the FY 1993-94 planned incremental
expenditures of $41.6 million as follows: compensation, $16.1 million; fixed cost
increases, $5.1 million; student financial aid, $8.8 million; new academic initiatives and other critical academic needs, $5.2 million; "pass-through" revenue,
$3.0 million; and the infrastructure maintenance fee, $3.5 million. To achieve an
adequate compensation increase, he noted that unit budgets had been increased
by 2.5 percent, staff benefits funding had been increased by $5.0 million, and


3




July Meeting, 1993


that units had been requested to make additional reallocations to permit further
increases in compensation.
The provost reiterated the University's policy of meeting the demonstrated
financial need of all regularly enrolled Michigan resident undergraduate students. He displayed a chart indicating that the outcome of this policy is that the
percentage of admitted freshmen who enroll by parental income is fairly even
across income classes, meaning that enrollment is independent of family income
for resident undergraduate students.
The proposed undergraduate tuition increases are 9.5 percent for residents
and 6.9 percent for nonresidents. For graduate students, the increase is 6.9 percent for both residents and nonresidents.
Regent Baker argued that the infrastructure maintenance fee ought to be
folded in with the tuition and fee increase figures to more clearly indicate the
total increased cost to students, noting that there is no assurance that the
infrastructure maintenance fee will actually be used for its stated purpose.
Regent Power commented that maintaining buildings and classrooms is a
responsibility of stewardship, and that the expanded fee is needed and will be
used to do this. He argued that it is appropriate to break down the various fees
charged to students according to their intended purpose, rather than combining
them into one sum, as suggested by Regent Baker.
In response to a question from Regent McFee, Provost Whitaker stated that
the approximate yearly cost for an undergraduate resident student, including
room and board and other expenses, is $11,200. He displayed charts showing
that for Michigan resident undergraduates, the University's two-term tuition
increase of $514 is the lowest of any other top ranking university nationally, as is
the total tuition cost for a Michigan first-year undergraduate at the same top
universities.
1993-94 UM-Dearborn General Fund Budget/Student Fee Rates
Chancellor Renick observed that tuition and fees and state appropriation
comprise 97.0 percent of the General Fund budget at UM-Dearborn. The proposed 1993-94 incremental budget of $2,040,000 provides for a salary program of
approximately 4.5 percent and for strengthening and broadening certain instructional programs. He stated that reallocation discussions are underway for the
1994-95 fiscal year, although it should be noted that a high percentage of the
budget is spent on teaching.
The incremental budget, to be funded by a 9.5 percent tuition increase, will
fund a salary program ($1,252,000), faculty promotions ($26,000), fringe benefits
($335,000), academic programs ($262,000), student financial aid ($145,000), and
a UM cost allocation increase ($20,000).
1993-94 UM-Flint General Fund Budget/Student Fee Rates
Chancellor Jones observed that the General Fund budget at UM-Flint is
comprised solely of tuition and fees and state appropriations. Given no increase


4




July Meeting, 1993


in the latter category, the proposed incremental budget must be funded almost
entirely with tuition increases. The proposed student fee increase of 8.5 percent
will yield $1,259,500, and a 5.0 percent internal reallocation will yield $628,950,
for a total incremental budget of $1,888,450.
Incremental expenditures include a 3.0 percent salary program ($692,000)
(following an inflationary increase was given in 1992-93); staff benefits increases
($200,000); student aid ($128,600), library/Central Energy Plant debt retirement
($200,000), and programmatic initiatives ($667,850).
Chancellor Jones noted that one of the continuing challenges of his
administration has been in the area of facilities development. He observed that
major new facilities, including the central energy plant and the new library, have
been funded entirely by private funding. However, because the University is not
receiving any state support for these facilities, it is required to fund the debt service on them. Chancellor Jones reported that he was planning to speak out about
the state's new policy of not providing operating funds for self-liquidating facilities, as this has a devastating impact on the Flint campus. He said that when an
institution raises money from private sources to fund a core facility, it is inequitable when the institution is penalized by not receiving state support for operations expenses.
In the discussion that followed, Regents Brown and Varner stated that they
would support the proposed tuition increase because the University has done the
very best it can do to maintain itself as one of the state's greatest assets in the
face of no increase in state support. President Duderstadt said that he is proud of
the combination of access and quality that the University of Michigan has been
able to maintain in the face of increasing financial constraints, especially when
compared with other state-supported institutions nation-wide.
Regent Deitch observed that Board members' responsibility for stewardship
over the institution requires that they be absolutely certain they are doing the
right thing. He believes that only the Regents have the independence to make
this type of judgment. He suggested that the Regents should be tough managers;
should insist on productivity, efficiency, lack of waste, and modesty in the
economic arena; should never be afraid to ask tough questions and should insist
on excellence. The Regents should think strategically. They should insist on
access and should be compassionate and caring and insist on a diverse and
inclusive community that welcomes all of its members. Finally, Regents should
be "tireless cheerleaders for the University of Michigan," which includes participating in the capital campaign, listening to the needs of the community, and supporting the administration in its efforts to maintain and enhance the institution.
Weighing the budget presentation against these values, Regent Deitch stated that
the only choice is to support the budget.
Regent Baker observed that the Regents have an obligation to control the
costs of education to the extent they can, and this can only be done by limiting
the number of dollars that are available. For this reason, he did not intend to
support the proposed tuition increase.


5




July Meeting, 1993


Regent McFee stated that she agreed with the principles outlined by Regent
Deitch. The public needs to be assured that the Regents recognize their
responsibilities and are doing everything possible to control costs, and the measures outlined by the administration demonstrate that this is being done.
The president noted that the Regents have a responsibility to serve people
for today and at the same time preserve the institution so that it can continue to
serve future generations.
Regent McGowan expressed agreement with the previous sentiments and
added that the chancellors of the Flint and Dearborn campuses deserve equal
recognition for their budget preparations. Regent Power agreed that due to past
and present good management practices at the University, the Regents are in a
position of being able to exercise their responsibilities with relative comfort compared with what is the case at other institutions.
There being no further comments, Regent Brown moved approval of the
General Fund operating budgets and student fee rates for 1993-94 for all three
campuses. Regent Waters seconded the motion, and it was approved, with Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters in favor and
Regent Baker opposed.
Regent Power observed that the decline in state support of higher education,
which has resulted in increased reliance on tuition, indicates a significant public
policy change, and this pattern is being repeated in public universities throughout the country. The general response has been to tighten expenses where possible and to increase tuition. But he cautioned that we can't keep doing this
indefinitely, and therefore more fundamental restructuring issues need to be examined. He suggested that the University should begin to look at the roles, missions, costs, and revenues associated with being a great public university.
There followed a ten-minute break at 10:55 a.im
The Regents reconvened at 11:05 a.m.
Minutes
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of June 1993.
Reports
Vice President Womack submitted reports of investments, plant extension,
litigation, personnel-labor relations, and noncompetitive purchases over $2,000.
Vice President Kelly submitted reports of projects established and summaries of
a selection of current research.
Voluntary Support
The report of voluntary support for the month of June will be included in
the September agenda.

July Meeting, 1993

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
voted unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoirs:
Janice A. Clark, associate professor of music (music education) in the
School of Music and lecturer in education in the School of Education, retired
from active faculty status on May 31, 1993.
Professor Clark was born and raised in Canton, Ohio, where she was active
in public school music programs. She continued her studies at Westminster
Choir College in Princeton, New Jersey, where she graduated with her B.M. degree in 1951. She taught music at the Charles Ellis School for Girls in Pennsylvania from 1951-54; concurrently, she served as the organist-choir director at
Marple Presbyterian Church in Bromall, Pennsylvania. In 1954, Professor Clark
journeyed west to enroll as a graduate student at the University of Michigan,


14




July Meeting, 1993


where she received her M.Mus. degree in 1956. In 1955, she began an association
with the Dixboro Methodist Church as organist (later director of music) that
extends to the present. Following completion of her graduate studies, Professor
Clark became a consultant in elementary vocal music for the Livonia Public
Schools. She was appointed to the University of Michigan faculty as a lecturer
(music education) in 1958, was promoted to assistant professor in 1962, and to
associate professor in 1969.
An active participant in music educators' associations at state and national
levels, Professor Clark has been especially energetic as a traveler to International
Society of Music Education meetings in Perth (1974), Montreux (1976), Warsaw
(1980), and Bristol (1982).
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Janice A Clark associate professor emerita of music (music education) and lecturer emeritus in
education.
Louis A. Ferman, professor of social work in the School of Social Work
and co-divisional director and research scientist in the Institute of Labor and
Industrial Relations, retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1993.
Professor Ferman received his B.A degree from Brown University in 1952,
his M.A degree from Boston University in 1953, and his Ph.D. degree in sociology and industrial relations from Cornell University in 1961. He served as an
instructor and research associate at Wayne State University from 1957-63 and
joined the Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations (ILIR) at the University of
Michigan as a research associate in 1959. He was named research director of
ILIR in 1965 and associate professor of social work in 1966. He was promoted to
professor of social work in 1969 and named divisional director (later, codivisional director) of ILIR in 1971. He received his appointment as research
scientist in 1988.
Since 1961, Professor Ferman's research has focused on the human problems of industrial societies. His research interests have included coping with
unemployment, plant shutdowns, manpower development, participative management, joint union-management training, and the informal ("off-the-books") economy. Regarded as the "father of informal economy research," Professor Ferman
has lectured, conducted seminars, and consulted both here and abroad on a wide
range of industrial topics. His publications include Poverty in America, Negroes
and Jobs, Job Development for the Hard-to-Employ, and Work Beyond Employment in Advanced Societies.
Professor Ferman is widely known in corporate, union, and legislative circles concerned with the development of industrial policy. Recently, he has been
involved in practical problems in economic development, such as career development of women in Third World countries, and the development of free markets
in eastern Europe.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Louis A Ferman
professor emeritus of social work and research scientist emeritus.
Warren E. Miller, research scientist in the Center for Political Studies at
the Institute for Social Research, and adjunct professor of political science in the


15




July Meeting, 1993


College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on
April 30, 1993.
Professor Miller received his B.S. and M.S. degrees from the University of
Oregon in 1948 and 1950, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from Syracuse University in 1954. He came to the University of Michigan in 1951 as an assistant
study director in the Survey Research Center and was promoted to study director
in 1953. From 1954-56, he was an assistant professor at the University of California at Berkeley. He returned to the University of Michigan in 1956 as an
assistant professor of political science and research associate in the Survey
Research Center. He was promoted to associate professor in 1958, to research
scientist in 1959, and to professor in 1963. He was named the Arthur W.
Bromage Professor of Political Science in 1981. Since 1982, he has been a professor of political science at Arizona State University.
Professor Miller has done pioneering research in electoral and political
behavior, focusing on democratic processes and how to enhance them. His
frequently-cited works time and again have set the direction for the field. At the
University of Michigan, Professor Miller founded the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research in 1962, the Center for Political Studies in
1970, and the American National Election Study in 1977. He served as executive
director of the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research
until 1970, director of the Center for Political Studies until 1981, and principal
investigator of the American National Election Studies through April 10, 1993.
Among Professor Miller's many honors are his election as a fellow of the
American Academy of Arts and Sciences (1977) and as a fellow of the American
Association for the Advancement of Science (1984). He was awarded an honorary
Doctor of Philosophy degree by the University of Goteborg in 1972, and received
the University of Michigan Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award in 1977.
He served as president of the American Political Science Association in 1979-80.
The Regents now salute this distinguished political scientist for his dedicated service by naming Warren E. Miller research scientist emeritus.
Rosemary A. Sarr, professor of social work in the School of Social Work
and faculty associate in the Center for Political Studies, Institute for Social
Research, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1993, after 34 years of
service to the University of Michigan.
Professor Sarri obtained her B.A degree from the University of Minnesota
in 1946, her M.S.W. degree from the University of Minnesota in 1955, and her
Ph.D. degree in social work and sociology from the University of Michigan in
1962. After gaining several years of professional experience in the field, Professor
Sarri joined the faculty of the University of Michigan School of Social Work in
1959 as a lecturer. She was promoted to assistant professor in 1962, associate
professor in 1964, and professor in 1966.
Scholars and professional practitioners the world over consider Professor
Sarri to be a leading expert in the areas of child/family welfare policy and juvenile
and criminal justice systems. Most recently, she has collaborated with universities in Australia and Korea on the topics of child welfare and adoption and was
appointed by the minister of education to the Russian Social Welfare


16




July Meeting, 1993


Commission to help develop educational standards and curriculum guidelines for
social work education programs in Russia.
Professor Sarri has done extensive research and published widely on public
policy issues related to families, children, women, and justice systems. She has
also served the School of Social Work, the University, and many government
agencies through her extensive committee, consulting, and community activities.
Her teaching has been inspirational and her mentorship of students noteworthy.
Her retirement marks the departure of an esteemed member of the faculty of the
School of Social Work who has been devoted to the improvement of social welfare
systems.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Rosemary A Sarri
professor emerita of social work.
Memorials
No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.

the University.

Federal Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Circular A-133,
Audit Reports and Schedules for the Years Ended June 30, 1992 and
1991, and Summary of Recommendations and Responses to Nonmaterial Responses as Reported by Ernst & Young
Vice President Womack reported that in compliance with OMB Circular
A-133, an audit was performed by the University's independent auditors, Ernst
& Young, based on the University's basic combined financial statements for each
of the two years ended June 30, 1992 and 1991. This audit is required for all
institutions of higher education and other not-for-profit organizations that
receive federal funds. Ernst & Young issued unqualified opinions in all seven
categories for the two year period, for a total of fourteen unqualified opinions.
Also contained in the agenda materials is a summary of recommendations and
responses to nonmaterial findings on specific compliance and internal control
matters, as reported by Ernst & Young.


17




July Meeting, 1993


The Regents noted that despite negative publicity that the University had
received in the recent past, the results of this audit show that the University has
been an extremely responsible steward of public funds.
Vacant Land, State of Washington
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent McGowan, the Regents
unanimously approved acceptance of a 15.36 acre parcel of vacant land located on
Fidalgo Island, Washington, and offering the land for sale at a price established
by an appraisal. Any costs required to market the property will be deducted from
the proceeds. In the event there is a question as to the environmental condition
of this parcel, it will not be accepted.
Issuance of Housing Revenue Bonds, Series 1993A
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved the following resolution amending the resolution adopted
in April 1993, which provides that the University shall use Legally Available
Funds if Net Revenues are insufficient for the annual debt service requirements.
RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AMENDING RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY
OF HOUSING REVENUE BONDS SERIES 1993A AND
PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS, the Regents of the University of Michigan (the "Issuer") adopted on April 16,
1993 a "Resolution of the Regents of the University of Michigan Authorizing the Issuance and
Delivery of Housing Revenue Bonds, Series 1993A and Providing for Other Matters Relating
Thereto" (the "Resolution"), which Resolution provided for the issuance and delivery of Housing
Revenue Bonds, Series 1993A (the "Bonds") for the purpose of providing funds to pay part of the
costs of the Project (as defined in the Resolution), refunding the Issuer's outstanding Prior Bonds
(as defined in the Resolution), to fund a debt service reserve fund for the Bonds, and to pay
certain costs incurred in connection with the issuance and sale of the Bonds and the refunding,
and
WHEREAS, it is now appropriate to amend the Resolution to permit the Issuer to covenant in the Indenture (as defined in the Resolution) to use Legally Available Funds of the Issuer
to pay debt service on the Bonds in the event the Net Revenues of the System are insufficient
therefor,
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:
1. The Resolution is hereby amended as follows:
The first paragraph of Section 2 of the Resolution is hereby amended to read as follows:
'"The Bonds shall be limited and not general obligations of the Issuer payable from and
equally and ratably secured by an irrevocable pledge of the Net Revenues (as shall be defined in
the Indenture) of the University's Housing System (as shall be described and defined in the
Indenture) and moneys from time to time on deposit in certain of the funds created pursuant to
the Indenture. The lien created by the Indenture on the portion of the Net Revenues previously
pledged for debt service on the Prior Bonds shall be subordinated to the liens thereon securing
the Prior Bonds until the respective related issues of the Prior Bonds are defeased or paid. The
Authorized Officers, or either of them, are authorized, if appropriate, to renegotiate the security
for any of the Prior Bonds listed on Exhibit A, to place it on a parity with the Bonds authorized
hereby. The Issuer may also covenant in the Indenture, in addition to other requirements, that
the Issuer shall use Legally Available Funds, as shall be defined in the Indenture, to pay debt
service on the Bonds in the event the Net Revenues of the System are insufficient therefor.


18




July Meeting, 1993


2. All resolutions or parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the Issuer in conflict hereof
be and the same are hereby repealed insofar as such conflict exists. As amended hereby, the Resolution is ratified and confirmed.
Real Estate Investment
Regent Brown moved, Regent McFee seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved commitment of $10 million of the University Endowment Fund
to Realty Associates Fund III, pending the general counsel's review of the partnership agreement for legal acceptability.

Regent Brown moved, Regent Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved commitment of an additional $5 million of the University
Endowment Fund to Restart Partners, L.P. and commitment of $10 million of
the University Endowment Fund to Belmont II, L.P., pending the general counsel's review of the partnership agreement for legal acceptability.
International Common Stock Management for University Endowment
Fund
Regent Power moved, Regent Brown seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved Emerging Markets Investments, L.P., as a vehicle for making
investments in emerging markets within the allocation for international common
stock investments.
Endowment Advisors is the companion organization to the Common Fund
that organizes investments for educational institutions in assets other than marketable securities, and Fairfield Partners, Inc., is a wholly owned subsidiary of
Endowment Advisors. Fairfield Partners is the general partner of and exercises
policy control over Emerging Markets Investments. Because Vice President
Womack serves as a trustee of both Endowment Advisors and Fairfield Partners,
this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The
following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the contracts (partnership agreement) will be the University of
Michigan and Emerging Markets Investments, L.P.
2.   The duration of the contract with Emerging Markets Investments, L.P., will be
open-ended. The partnership will invest University Endowment Fund assets.
Vice President Farris W. Womack or a University representative will attend
meetings of the boards and related committees, as had been the case prior to Dr.
Womack's service on the boards.
3.  Vice President Womack has no pecuniary interest in these contracts. For
Emerging Markets Investments, L.P., Fairfield Partners will receive no management fee, but will receive a two percent interest in the profits and losses of
the partnership.

Purchasing Contract between the University of Michigan and Rebus
Planning Associates, Inc.
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved a purchasing contract between the University of Michigan and Rebus Planning Associates, Inc. Because the owner of Rebus Planning
Associates, Inc., Samuel J. Meisels, is also a University employee, this contract
falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the purchase contract will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and Rebus Planning Associates, Inc.
2.  The terms of the contract to support three University of Michigan research
grants include the purchase during the period of August through October 1993
from Rebus Planning Associates, Inc., of 100 classroom sets of Work Sampling
materials ($13,500); 140 sample packs of Work Sampling training ($6,160); and
5 participants at Work Sampling Training ($2,000).
3.  Dr. Meisels' pecuniary interest arises from his position as owner of Rebus Planning Associates, Inc..

Associates
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved a purchasing contract between the University of


20




July Meeting, 1993


Michigan and Gini Associates. Because John H. Romani, senior associate at Gini
Associates who would be providing the services, is also a University employee,
this contract falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The
following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the purchase contract will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and Gini Associates.
2.   The terms of the contract to support the leadership seminar to be held at the
UM on October 12 and 13, 1993, include the purchase from Gini Associates of
Dr. Romani's services to plan and conduct the leadership seminar plus Gini Associates' support for a total cost of $3,931.
3.   Dr. Romani has no pecuniary interest in Gini Associates. He is employed by
Gini as an independent contractor.
Agreement between the University of Michigan and Process Biotechnology, Inc. (PBI)
Regent Brown moved, Regent Waters seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved an agreement between the University of Michigan and Process
Biotechnology, Inc., for conducting a research project under the direction of
Louis Tsui at the University of Michigan-Dearborn. Because the president of
PBI, Henry Yee-Neen Wang, is both a 50 percent shareholder in PBI and a
University employee, this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of
Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  PBI has provided a letter agreement to the Regents of the University of Michigan authorizing funding for this project.
2.   The agreement will provide $3,000, representing one-half (1/2) month salary
and benefits for Dr. Tsui, to be incurred over a ten-week period. Conduct of the
project will be consistent with standard University research policies.
3.   Dr. Wang's stock ownership is his sole pecuniary interest in this project. He will
not be compensated by the University for any activity associated with this project.

Revision of Regents' Bylaw Section 11.17 (School of Natural Resources
and Environment Executive Committee)
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Deitch, the Regents
unanimously approved a change in the Regents' Bylaws regarding the School of
Natural Resources and Environment Executive Committee. The change reduces
the period of ineligibility for reappointment to the executive committee from two


21




July Meeting, 1993


years after service on the executive committee to one year. The following is the
revised text of Regents' Bylaw Section 11.17.
Sec. 11.17. The School of Natural Resources and Environment
Executive Committee
The executive committee shall consist of the dean and four members of the tenured professorial faculty to be appointed by the Board of Regents on recommendation
by the president. The appointed members shall hold office for two years, and the terms
shall be adjusted so that two will expire each year. The appointed members shall be eligible for reappointment for one additional term but shall not thereafter be eligible for
reappointment until after the lapse of one year. The governing faculty is authorized to
arrange for students, not more than two in number, selected in accordance with procedures and for terms approved by the governing faculty, to participate in meetings of the
executive committee in an advisory capacity.
Revision of Regents' Bylaw Sections 11.151, 11.151A, and 11.151B (University of Michigan Hospitals Executive Board)
On a motion by Regent Deitch, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
unanimously approved revisions to Regents' Bylaw Sections 11.151 and 11.151A
and deletion of Regents' Bylaw Section 11.151B, to make the Regents' Bylaws
consistent with actions taken by the Regents at the meeting of November 1992.
The following is the revised text of Regents' Bylaw Sections 11.151 and 11.151A:
Sec. 11.151. The University of Michigan Hospitals Executive Board
There shall be an executive board of the University of Michigan Hospitals composed of the president; the dean of the Medical School; the dean of the School of Nursing; the vice president for academic affairs and provost; the vice president and chief
financial officer; the vice president for government relations; the vice president for development; the vice provost for medical affairs, the chief of clinical affairs of the University of Michigan Hospitals; the executive director of the University of Michigan
Hospitals; the chief of nursing affairs of the University of Michigan Hospitals, and assistant dean for clinical affairs, School of Nursing; and two nominees from the
medical/dental staff of the University of Michigan Hospitals.
The chair shall be named by the president and the Board of Regents.
The nominees of the medical/dental staff will be appointed by the Board of Regents on recommendation by the president and will serve four-year terms, so staggered
to provide one replacement every two years.
Sec. 11.151A.    The University of Michigan Hospitals Executive Board:
Powers and Duties
The Board of Regents is responsible for establishing the mission, goals, and
objectives of the University of Michigan Hospitals as set out in Sec. 11.15 and for the
quality of medical care services provided; approval of all major programs and operating budgets, including level of expenditures and rates to be charged; the approval of
capital and facility plans; appointment and delineation of hospital privileges for
medical/dental staff members, and appointment of the executive director of the University of Michigan Hospitals.
In all of the above matters, the executive board of the University of Michigan Hospitals is expected to make recommendations to the president and the Board of Regents.


22




July Meeting, 1993


The executive board of the University of Michigan Hospitals is itself charged
with responsibility and empowered to establish programs, services, and administrative
units to meet the goals and objectives of the University of Michigan Hospitals; to review
and approve medical/dental staff bylaws, rules, and regulations governing medical
care rendered, to review and approve the internal organizational structure of the University of Michigan Hospitals; to determine appropriate delegation of authority to the
executive director of the University of Michigan Hospitals within the system of general
University administration, to insure fulfillment of external requirements for Hospitals'
management; to review and approve Hospitals sponsored training programs; to review
and approve appropriate use of the University of Michigan Hospitals for clinical educational and training experience by various health schools of the University; and to
take such steps as are needed to insure periodic evaluation of Hospitals' operations to
assure that goals and objectives are achieved.
In carrying out the above delegated powers, the executive board of the University
of Michigan Hospitals will submit periodic reports to the president and the Board of
Regents. The executive board shall submit its minutes to members of the Board of
Regents.
Sec. 11.151B.   The University of Michigan Hospitals Public Advisory
Board
(Section 11:151B deleted)
In response to a comment that had been made by a speaker at the previousday's public comment session, Regent Power asked for further information about
how Medical Service Plan rates are set and the impact of this on the Regents'
Bylaws.
Medical Staff Appointments
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Waters, and on the recommendation of the UM      Hospitals Executive Board, the Regents unanimously
approved several appointments to medical staff membership.
Resolution in Honor of Vice President William            Kelly
The president called on Regent Varner, who read the following resolution on
behalf of the Board:
Regents' Resolution.
The Regents of the University happily salute and commend
William C. Kelly, who is concluding an extraordinary career as faculty
member, author, researcher, administrator, problem solver, and finally
as vice president for research at the University of Michigan.
Dr. Kelly received his Ph.D. degree at Columbia University in
1954. After a brief stint in the U.S. Army, he joined the faculty at the
University of Michigan as an instructor in 1956. He quickly rose
through the professorial ranks, carrying a full teaching load while
managing an active research program that resulted in numerous
writings on the geochemistry and mineralogy of economic mineral
deposits around the world, including the well-known          deposits in
Michigan's Upper Peninsula. He has served on scores of national


23




July Meeting, 1993


scientific panels and in 1991 was awarded the gold medal of the
International Society of Economic Geologists for his "unusually
original work in the earth sciences."
Bill's University accolades include the Distinguished Service
Award (1961) and the Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award
(1985). He was named the C. Scott Turner Distinguished Professor in
Geological Sciences in 1983. His outstanding academic career has been
peppered with administrative chores which he carried off with great
distinction: chair of the Geology Department from 1978-81, interim
director of the Institute of Science and Technology in 1986, associate
vice president (1989), interim vice president (1990), and finally, vice
president for research from September 1990 to the present.
In all of these administrative posts, Bill Kelly had the nose of a
trouble-shooter. He took on the knottiest of problems and engineered
solutions that will serve the University for years to come. And perhaps
his crowning achievement was to see the University's federal research
volume become the largest in the nation.
The Regents acknowledge with deep appreciation the lifetime of
service that this distinguished scientist has given the University. Bill
and his wife Anna have left indelible marks on the life of this University
with their gracious leadership and good humor. The Regents wish them
all the best and thank them for having served so long and so well. The
sign that will hang on Bill Kelly's office door come September 1 tells it
all: "Gone fishin'."
The resolution was adopted by acclamation, and there followed a round of
applause. Vice President Kelly responded that he appreciated the sentiments
expressed in the resolution and thanked the Board for the privilege of serving in
this position. He also thanked the executive officers and his staff for their dedicated service during his tenure.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting will be held on September 23 and 24, 1993. Regents' expenses for the
month of June 1993 totalled $4,240.50.
RiChard L.   nnedy, Secr    dry


24




SEPTEMBER MEETING, 1993


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, September 23, 1993
The Regents assembled at 9:10 am. in the Regents' Room. Present were
Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters.
Vice President and Secretary Kennedy and Vice Presidents Hartford and
Womack were also present. President Duderstadt, Provost Whitaker, Chancellors
Jones and Renick, and Vice Presidents Cosovich and Neal were absent.
Regent Brown called the meeting to order and called on Regent Deitch, who
made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Section 8(a) of the Open Meetings Act, as amended
by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed
session on September 23, 1993, at 10:00 a.m., for the purpose of
considering a periodic personnel evaluation of a person who has
requested confidentiality. Regent Varner seconded the motion, and it
was approved unanimously, after which the Regents immediately
met in closed session.
Public Comments
At 4:00 p.m., the Regents reassembled in the Anderson Room of the Michigan Union to hear Public Comments. All Regents were present.
The Regents heard comments from the following individuals, on the topics
indicated: Marlon Ross, Anne Herrmann, Don Herzog, Van Harrison, and Virginia Gordan, faculty members, and Camille Brewer, student, in favor of revising
Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 to include sexual orientation; James K. Huggins,
Heather Brunsink, Peter Payne, Meredith Uy, and Christine L. Chilimigras, students, against revising Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 to include sexual orientation; and John Erwin Hunter, Sr., and John Erwin Hunter II, on Law School
admissions.
Friday, September 24, 1993
The Regents met at 9:00 am. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power,
Varner, and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy,
and Vice Presidents Cosovich, Hartford, Neal, and Womack were also present, as
were Chancellors Jones and Renick.


25




September Meeting, 1993


President Duderstadt welcomed Vice President Neal to his first Regents'
Meeting. He then called on Regent Deitch.
Revision of Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06
Regent Deitch stated that he was going to move revision of Regents' Bylaw
Section 14.06 by replacing it in its entirety, and that Regent McGowan would be
seconding the motion. Regent Varner then would be offering an amendment to
the motion.
Regent Deitch moved that Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 be revised to read
as follows:
The University of Michigan is committed to a policy of
nondiscrimination and equal opportunity for all persons regardless
of race, sex, color, religion, creed, national origin or ancestry, age,
marital status, sexual orientation, disability, or Vietnam era veteran
status.
Further, he moved that:
"The sexual orientation provision of this policy shall not
prohibit the University from   maintaining relationships with
agencies of the federal government. Nothing in this action request
shall be deemed to limit rights and benefits which are currently
granted. Because the University wishes to study how particular
employment benefits, family housing, financial aid packages, and
student residency status would be affected by the addition of the
sexual orientation provision, that provision shall not apply to those
subjects at this time. Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 will apply to
those subjects only after the president or his delegate determines,
following that study, how and to what degree the bylaw should
apply to those areas."
Regent McGowan seconded the motion, and Regent Deitch explained that
he and Regent McGowan had decided to cosponsor it for four reasons: 1) failure
of the University to move its institutional commitment to nondiscrimination for
the gay/lesbian community from the level of presidential policy to the Regents'
bylaw level implies that discrimination against these individuals is less significant than discrimination against others enumerated in the bylaw; 2) the issue is
one of campus climate in which students should be taught that people's lives are
private and that "all are welcome here: no ifs, ands, or buts"; 3) a truly serious
commitment to academic excellence means that we must stop devaluing distinguished members of our faculty, today; and 4) the plan, with its undertaking of a
study of how the bylaw will affect other aspects of University life such as staff
benefits and family housing, offers a sound and measured approach to change.
Regent Deitch stated that he was proud to be offering the motion, and following some comments describing his personal commitment to not countenancing discrimination against any group on the basis of status, he yielded the floor
to Regent McGowan. (A copy of Regent Deitch's prepared remarks is on file in
the Office of the Secretary of the University.)


26




September Meeting, 1993


Regent McGowan observed that it is a fact that many students, faculty, and
staff at the University are gay, lesbian, or bisexual. She noted that President
Shapiro had recognized this in 1984 by instituting the presidential policy protecting the gay community from discrimination, and that the Board of Regents had
affirmed that policy in 1988. But she noted that in the eyes of the University
community, it is the Regents who create the atmosphere for its campuses. Therefore, it is time for the Regents to say that its own bylaws protect every member of
its community from discrimination based on who they are, and to extend the protections of the bylaws to all.
Regent McGowan observed that over 150 other American public and private
colleges and universities, including Wayne State and Michigan State Universities, most other Big Ten universities, and many of our peer institutions had already subscribed to such a policy, as had prominent Americans such as Barry
Goldwater and Coretta Scott King. Most important, however, was the fact that
the University's own community had been urging the Regents to "end the pain
of omission of the members of the homosexual community o.. and to express our
commitment to nondiscrimination and equal opportunity," and that she believed
the Board was prepared to do so. She then yielded the floor to Regent Varner.
(The full text of Regent McGowan's remarks is on file in the Office of the Secretary of the University.)
Regent Varner stated that she fully supports the recommendation to change
the bylaw, noting that it had been part of the University's values since President
Shapiro's presidential policy on sexual orientation was proffered in the
mid-1980s. In recognition of the historical struggles at the University for equal
opportunities for minority and women students and faculty, she was offering the
following amendment to the language in Regent Deitch's motion to make it eminently clear that the Board would not be taking away the University's commitment to affirmative action:
"The University is also committed to compliance with all
applicable laws regarding nondiscrimination   and  affirmative
action."
Regent Brown supported the amendment.
President Duderstadt observed that the University had lagged behind many
other educational institutions in prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual
orientation. Although the University had the presidential policy statement, the
absence of the statement in the Regents' Bylaws put valued members of the University community at some risk and sent a signal that gay, lesbian, and bisexuals
are less valued members of the campus community. He believed that their full
participation in the life of the University must be protected and reaffirmed. He
stated his belief that the change in the bylaw is necessary, is consistent with
Michigan's long tradition of full participation by all groups and individuals, that
it is simply the right thing to do, and that he supported it in the strongest possible terms. He then called on Provost Whitaker.


27




September Meeting, 1993


Provost Whitaker said that this disparity had been a subject of discussion
throughout his 15-year tenure as both dean and provost. A 1991 study of the climate for gays and lesbians at the University, conducted by the Affirmative Action
Office, had raised many important concerns about discrimination among the
deans. At that time, there was unanimous support among the deans that University policy should include nondiscrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
He had appointed a subcommittee of deans, chaired by Dean Bollinger of the
Law School, which had made the recommendation that Regents' Bylaw Section
14.06 should be revised to include sexual orientation, and that he fully supported
that recommendation. Furthermore, the deans and the faculty senate have indicated that the faculty also overwhelmingly supports revision of the bylaw.
Dean Bollinger reported that the deans unanimously support amending the
bylaw to include sexual orientation. Vice President Hartford stated that she personally supported the bylaw change, and that she and her staff, in their work
with the gay/lesbian/bisexual student community, have observed first hand the
need for this change. Furthermore, she had met with a wide variety of student
leaders who also all supported the proposed change.
Regent Baker expressed his views by reading from a prepared statement, a
copy of which is on file in the Office of the Secretary of the University. Regent
Baker recounted the history of efforts to include the phrase "sexual orientation"
in Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06, noting that it had been a contentious issue
since the group LaGROC first advocated for this in 1984. That effort had led to
President Shapiro's "Presidential Policy Statement on Sexual Orientation,"
which was reaffirmed by the Regents in 1988.
Regent Baker observed that Regents Deitch and McGowan had initiated discussions with the president and provost, Dean Bollinger, and the University's
general counsel, Elsa Cole, to amend Bylaw 14.06 soon after their election to the
Board in 1992. He himself had not learned of the existence of a July 1993 legal
opinion from a Washington law firm related to making this change until several
days ago. Regent Baker expressed concern that the other Regents were given
only one week's notice by Regents Deitch and McGowan of their intention to propose the bylaw change, which is the minimum time required, and that because
the president had waived the usual practice of publishing the proposed bylaw
change in advance in the University Record, the public was not given notice of
the proposed change until the first day of the Regents' meeting (September 23,
1993). University faculty, students, and staff were thus denied the right to comment on the issue.
Regent Baker stated that the reason that "sexual orientation" hasn't been
included in the bylaws in the past is because discrimination on this basis is different than the other categories of discrimination named in the bylaws. He further
observed that all qualified individuals at the University are treated equally regardless of their sexual orientation.
Regent Baker pointed out that there are many support and advocacy organizations for gay men, lesbians, and bisexuals at the University, and that these
groups have influenced University policy by making it unacceptable and


28




September Meeting, 1993


sometimes punishable to criticize homosexual and lesbian lifestyles at freshman
orientation, in the dormitory system, and in the classroom. He further noted that
University religious groups have expressed concern about the effect of the proposed bylaw change on their constitutional rights to freedom of association, freedom of religion, and freedom of speech. He quoted from a letter to the Regents
from Mr. Steven T. McFarland, director of the Center for Law and Religious
Freedom, which expressed his reservations regarding the proposed bylaw change
and requested that such a revision contain a "religious conscience" exemption.
(The text of the letter is included in Regent Baker's statement.)
Regent Baker argued that because of the strong political pressures that will
be exerted by homosexual and lesbian organizations, the recommendations of the
committee that will be appointed to study the effect of the bylaw change on other
areas of University life will most likely be fully implemented by the University
administration. Regent Baker noted that he has long argued that University policies regarding speech and conduct restrict both freedom of speech and freedom of
religion on the part of non-homosexual/lesbian students.
Regent Baker opined that the real issue is not alleged discrimination, but
rather, the establishment in the bylaws of the concept of "equivalency" of homosexual and lesbian sexual practices and lifestyles as equal to and as acceptable as
heterosexual sexual practices and lifestyles. According to Regent Baker, the future of our society is at risk and the structure of the family is being crushed by all
of the attacks on its historical religious, moral and ethical bases and the destruction of traditional values. The discussion of the bylaw change represents only one
aspect of that decline.
Regent Baker's prepared remarks concluded with a quote from an article by
Mr. Dennis Prager, from a 1990 issue of his journal, Ultimate Issues (copy included in the prepared statement on file) about the importance of family life in
the maintenance of western civilization. In this article, Mr. Prager asserts that
"the acceptance of homosexuality as the equal of heterosexual married love signifies the decline of western civilization..."
Regent Baker observed that two years ago, a student religious group had
been denied recognition by the Michigan Student Assembly because it would not
allow leaders of the group to be homosexual or lesbian, and the administration
had not intervened. Regent Baker asserted that the issues raised by revision of
the bylaw should be studied and debated prior to its being approved, rather than
by a committee to be formed following the revision, as has been proposed in the
motion. Otherwise the committee's recommendations will be "railroaded"
through, according to Regent Baker.
Regent Baker moved that the motion to amend the bylaws be tabled until a
committee can be appointed to study the implications of such an amendment.
This motion was not seconded.
President Duderstadt reported that if the bylaw change is approved, he intended to appoint a broadly representative commission to study the issues raised
by the change at the earliest possible opportunity. He said he would bring any


29




September Meeting, 1993


significant recommendations for changes in policies or practices to the Board for
firther discussion before implementation.
Regent Brown responded to Regent Baker's comments by noting that the
requirements for notice regarding the proposed bylaw change had been met, and
the notice was sufficient for him. He also disputed some of Regent Baker's assertions about freshman orientation, stating that Regent Baker was wrong in stating that individuals tried to change student's views about homosexuality. Regent
Brown praised the speakers at the Public Comments session for their reasoned
arguments. However, he observed that it would not be in the Board's power to
supersede the guarantees of freedom of religion, association, and assembly that
are contained in the Constitution. He further pointed out that the proposed
bylaw amendment is not a statement of approval or disapproval of any lifestyle;
it merely attempts to prohibit discrimination against the various conditions listed
in the bylaw. Thus, he was prepared to support the bylaw amendment.
In response, Regent Baker stated that he had received numerous calls about
the orientation program and the policies with respect to choice of roommate and
noted that the pressure not to speak up about such issues at the University is
tremendous. He cited some examples of instances involving orientation and
roommate selection.
Regent McGowan responded to Regent Baker's comments regarding the
process that had been followed in proposing the bylaw amendment, noting that it
was not done in secret and that the procedures had been followed to the letter.
She stated that the attorney in the Washington law firm referred to by Regent
Baker was a distinguished alumnus of the University. In response to Regent
Baker's assertion that Regent McGowan had been supported by gay rights activists in her campaign for election to the Board, Regent McGowan stated that her
support of the amendment was not being done as a sort of political payback for
the nearly two million citizens who voted for her, and that she was dismayed that
Regent Baker would make such an assertion. Regent Power expressed agreement
with Regent McGowan.
Regent Deitch observed that the reason that the issue had been a contentious one at the University for the past ten years had been because of Regent
Baker and his personal obsession with it. Noting that in his earlier comments he
had credited his Judaism with having framed his value system and that Regent
Baker was active in the Presbyterian church, he said that people's values, even at
a secular institution, are often framed by their religious beliefs. Regent Deitch
observed that New York governor Mario Cuomo, a Catholic, had framed the issue properly in a 1984 speech on abortion in which he stated that as a Catholic
public official he lived by the political truth that "to assure our freedom, we must
allow others the same freedom, even if occasionally it produces conduct by them
which we would hold to be sinful. We know that the problem with seeking to
force our beliefs on others is that they might someday force theirs on us."
Regent Deitch also noted that his election campaign had been endorsed by
gay and lesbian groups, among others, and that he was proud of that fact.


30




September Meeting, 1993


In regard to the ramifications of the proposed amendment, Regent McFee
recounted her personal experiences of having come of age when women were still
discriminated against in the workplace. She also noted that with the signing of a
marriage contract, people give up some of their independence, and that women
have long sought to protect their rights to equal benefits based on the family income. She said she was very concerned that the contractual obligations and responsibilities that are agreed to in the marriage contract be respected and that
any extension of those contractual rights be in the context of similar contracts,
and not be granted without that kind of commitment.
Regent Power called the question on Regent Deitch's motion to amend the
bylaws. Regent Baker moved that an exception to the amendment be provided
for religious organizations. There being no second to Regent Baker's motion, the
vote was taken on Regent Varner's motion to amend Regent Deitch and McGowan's original motion, and it carried on a vote of seven to one, with Regent Baker
opposed. Finally, the vote was taken on the amended motion to amend Regents'
Bylaw Section 14.06, and it carried, with Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee,
McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters in favor and Regent Baker opposed. The
following is the text of the revised bylaw:
Sec. 14.06. Nondiscrimination and Affirmative Action
The University of Michigan is committed to a policy of nondiscrimination and
equal opportunity for all persons regardless of race, sex, color, religion, creed, national
origin or ancestry, age, marital status, sexual orientation, disability, or Vietnam era
veteran status.
The University also is committed to compliance with all applicable laws regarding nondiscrimination and affirmative action.
There followed a ten-minute break, after which the Regents reconvened at
10:22 a.m.
University Annual Financial Statements for 1992-93; Year End Financial Information
Vice President Womack introduced the financial statements by pointing out
that in each instance, the opinion of the independent auditors, Ernst & Young,
was unqualified and contains the following statement
"In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above
present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the
University of Michigan at June 30, 1993, and the changes in fund
balances and the current funds revenues, expenditures and
transfers for the year then ended are in conformity with generally
accepted accounting principles."
Vice President Womack expressed his appreciation to the many members of
the University community who contributed to the University's being in such a
strong financial condition. He then introduced Mr. Chandler Matthews, associate
vice president for finance, and Mr. Robert Moenart, controller and director of financial operations, to present the financial statements.


31




September Meeting, 1993


Mr. Moenart reviewed current funds revenues through a slide presentation.
He pointed out that the current funds consist of the General, Designated, and
Expendable Restricted Funds (which together comprise the Educational and
General Funds), and the Auxiliary Activities Funds, student fees, state appropriations, and total government programs constitute approximately 82 percent of
the educational and general activities in the Current Funds. The General Fund's
primary function is instruction and research; the Designated Fund constitutes
conferences and continuing education; the Expendable Restricted Fund consists
primarily of federal research funding; and the Auxiliary Activities Fund records
the activities of units that generate their own revenues, such as the hospitals and
housing and athletics.
Over the past ten years, state appropriations as a source of revenue in the
Educational and General categories have decreased from 32.0 percent to 25.0
percent of the total, while student fees have increased from 28.0 percent to 31.0
percent and government programs have increased from 23.0 percent to 26.0 percent. Total Educational and General Funds revenues for 1992-93 were $1.173 billion; the growth rate over the past ten years (adjusted for inflation) has been 5.1
percent.
The expenditure categories of the Educational and General portion of the
Current Funds include salaries and wages, staff benefits, scholarships and fellowships, supplies, and equipment and plant. Over the past ten years, total compensation (salaries and wages plus staff benefits) has gone from 63.0 percent of the
total in 1983-84 to 59.0 percent in 1992-93, with staff benefits as a portion of the
expenditures increasing from 11.0 percent to 13.0 percent and salaries and wages
decreasing from 52.0 percent to 46.0 percent of the total. Scholarships and fellowships have grown over this time period, from 7.0 percent of the total to 10.0 percent of the total. Supplies expenditures have remained relatively constant, at
about 21.0 percent of the total. Equipment and plant expenditures have increased from 8.0 percent to 10.0 percent of the total. The total compound real
growth rate for expenditures and transfers in the Educational and General Current Funds has been 5.1 percent since Fiscal Year 1984.
Auxiliary Activities Funds have grown from 39 percent of total revenues in
1983-84 to 46 percent, while General Fund revenues have decreased from 39 percent of the total to 33 percent. Total revenues over this period have grown from
$890 million to $2.162 billion.
Mr. Moenart displayed charts detailing the components of the growth in
staff benefits from $87.1 million in 1983-84 (16 percent of total compensation) to
$238.9 million in 1992-93 (20 percent of total compensation). Health care costs
for retired and active employees have grown from 28 percent of staff benefits
costs to 37 percent.
Mr. Moenart concluded by observing that the University's bond rating remains at AA or above, and the debt service ratio has dropped from 3.0 percent in
1992 to 2.4 percent in 1993, as a result of refinancing over the past year.


32




September Meeting, 1993


Regent Baker moved adoption of the annual financial statements for
1992-93. Regent McFee seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Regent Brown was away from the table when the vote was taken.
1993-94 Revenue and Expenditure Budgets
Vice President Womack began the presentation by displaying charts comparing the 1992-93 and 1993-94 current funds budget totals in terms of revenues,
expenditures, state appropriations, and student tuition and fees. Total revenues
in the General, Designated, Auxiliary Activities, and Expendable Restricted
Funds will increase by 7.8 percent in 1993-94, to $2.255 billion, while expenditures will increase by 7.7 percent to a total of $2.143 billion.
Over the past ten years, the University's budget has increased from about
$900 million in 1985 to $2.25 billion for the coming year. In the 1993-94 revenue
budget, Auxiliary Activities-Medical areas account for 40 percent ($904 million);
Auxiliary-Other, 6 percent ($121 million); the General Fund, 33 percent ($748
million); Expendable-Restricted Fund, 18 percent ($411 million); and the Designated Fund, 3 percent ($71 million). Vice President Womack then turned to Provost Whitaker to present the proposed General Fund budget.
Provost Whitaker reported that the 1993-94 General Fund revenue budget
of $748 million would consist of $387 million from tuition and fees (52 percent),
$293 million from state appropriation (39 percent), $56 million from indirect cost
reimbursement (7 percent), and $12 million from other sources (2 percent). Provost Whitaker also reviewed the 1993-94 General Fund budgeted expenditures by
function, by object, by school or college, by vice presidential area, and by unit. He
discussed detailed budgets for the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts,
the College of Engineering, the Medical School, the School of Social Work, and
the University Library.
Regarding the University of Michigan-Flint budget, Chancellor Jones commented that state appropriation comprises almost 50 percent of the budget,
whereas nine years ago it had been 38 percent. He also explained that the mandatory transfer figure of 5 percent is at the recommended maximum, and that is
due to the debt service required for the new parking deck and the central energy
plant expansion and library. This situation occurred because the Flint campus
was forced to borrow funds for critically needed facilities that it had hoped the
state would have been able to fund.
Vice President Womack took over the presentation at this point and reviewed the Designated Fund revenue budget of $71 million, the Auxiliary Activities budget of $1.025 billion, and the Expendable Restricted Fund budget of $411
million. He pointed out that 88 percent of the Auxiliary Activities revenue budget
comes from Hospital and other medical sources. In the Expendable Restricted
Fund, 67 percent comes from government sponsored programs and 26 percent
comes from private gifts.


33




September Meeting, 1993


Following Vice President Womack's presentation, Regent Baker moved approval of the 1993-94 revenue and expenditure budgets. Regent Varner seconded
the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Consent Agenda
The following consent agenda items were submitted to the Regents: the
minutes of the July 1993 meeting, reports of investments, plant extension, litigation, personnel-labor relations, projects established, summaries of a selection of
current research, and voluntary support; personnel actions; personnel reports;
and retirement memoirs.
Regent McGowan noted that she was very pleased with the appointment of
Susan Lipschutz as associate provost for academic affairs and expressed the hope
that more women would be appointed to high level positions in the future. President Duderstadt responded that he shared Regent McGowan's concerns, and
that he was committed to appointing women to leadership positions in the University. Regent Varner recognized the outstanding contributions of Vice President Womack and Jack Weidenbach. Regent Power welcomed Vice President
Homer Neal to the table and congratulated Walt Harrison on his appointment as
vice president for university relations and Provost Whitaker and Vice President
Womack on the change in their titles to executive vice president. Regent Baker
concurred.
Director of Intercollegiate Athletics. President Duderstadt announced
his recommendation for the appointment of Mr. M. Joseph Roberson as athletic
director. He noted that Mr. Roberson is a proven administrator, with strong athletic credentials, but most important, he is first and foremost an educator.
Regent Brown moved the appointment of M. Joseph Roberson as director of
intercollegiate athletics; Regent Waters seconded the motion.
Regent Baker read from a prepared statement in which he expressed his
view that the search process for the position of athletic director was faulted and
resulted in the unfair treatment of Mr. Fritz Seyferth as a candidate for the position. To protest this treatment of Mr. Seyferth, Regent Baker announced that although he would support Mr. Roberson in his new position as athletic director,
he intended to vote against the appointment. (A copy of Regent Baker's remarks
is on file in the Office of the Secretary of the University.)
Regents McFee, Brown, and Power expressed their support for Mr. Roberson and noted that they do not accept Regent Baker's statements as an accurate
depiction of the search process. President Duderstadt asserted that the process
was followed to the letter and that much of the information that had been leaked
to the media during the search was incorrect.
Following further comments, the vote was taken on the motion to approve
M. Joseph Roberson as director of intercollegiate athletics, and it was approved,
with Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters in
favor and Regent Baker opposed.

September Meeting, 1993
