TERMINATIONS OF REGULAR INSTRUCTIONAL STAFF
School of Dentistry
Kazumasa Kaya, Lecturer in Dentistry, June 30, 1993 (retired, previously reported as resigned)
UM-Dearborn School of Management
Paul R. Wheaton, Lecturer in Business Administration, June 30, 1993 (retired, previously
reported as term complete)
Retirement Memoirs
Allan R. Beaudoin, professor of anatomy and cell biology, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1993, after a productive and balanced career of
teaching, research, and administration at the University of Michigan.
A native of Connecticut, Professor Beaudoin received his B.S. degree in 1949
and his M.S. degree in 1951 from the University of Connecticut and his Ph.D. degree in 1954 from the State University of Iowa. He was an instructor at Vassar
College from 1954-56 and an instructor and then assistant professor at the University of Florida from 1956-61. He joined the University of Michigan as assistant
professor of anatomy in 1961. He was promoted to associate professor in 1964
and professor in 1969.
During his tenure at the University of Florida, Professor Beaudoin became
associated with some of the pioneer researchers in the field of experimental teratology, and this provided the basis for his scientific career. When he moved to the
University of Michigan, he continued his research in experimental teratology and


69




September Meeting, 1993


taught medical histology and embryology. On several occasions Professor Beaudoin was also called upon to serve in departmental administrative posts, including acting chair of the department (1977-78) and interim chair (1986-89).
Professor Beaudoin's professional contributions have been well recognized
locally and nationally. He has served on many national panels and review groups
and has been elected to many offices of the Teratology Society, including president in 1978-79. His research has been reported in numerous peer-reviewed journal articles and book chapters.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his dedicated
service by naming Allan R. Beaudoin professor emeritus of anatomy and cell
biology.
LeVerne S. Collet, professor of education, retired from active faculty
status on July 31, 1993, after 25 years of service to the University of Michigan.
Born in Canada, Professor Collet received his B.Ed. and M.Ed. degrees from
the University of Alberta in 1956 and 1964, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree
from the University of Washington in 1968. From 1955-68, he served successively
as a classroom teacher, assistant principal and guidance counselor, and acting
principal at Wilson Junior High School in Lethbridge, Alberta, Canada. Professor
Collet joined the faculty of the University of Michigan School of Education as an
assistant professor in 1968; he was promoted to associate professor in 1972 and
professor in 1977.
During his years with the School of Education, Professor Collet taught
courses in research design, measurement, and program evaluation. He provided
extensive assistance to students and colleagues in designing research methodologies and conducting empirical research and field evaluations of educational programs. He has also served on the school's Curriculum Committee, Research
Coordinating Committee, and Executive Committee.
Professor Collet has also been very active in professional organizations, including the Association for Supervision and Curriculum and the National Council on Measurement in Education and has regularly presented papers at the
annual meetings of the American Educational Research Association. He has produced program evaluation reports for such groups as the Kennedy Center PreVocational Training Program, the National Kidney Foundation of Michigan's
School Blood Pressure Program, and the Ferndale School District's Program for
Academic Challenge and Enrichment. He has also served as a consultant for
Domino's Pizza, Inc., the Republic Steel Corporation, and the Howell Public
Schools.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming LeVerne S. Collet
professor emeritus of education.
Robert G. Craig, Marcus L. Ward Professor of Dentistry, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1993.
Professor Craig received his B.S. degree in 1944, his M.S. degree in 1951,
and his Ph.D. degree in 1954, all from the University of Michigan. He worked as
a researcher for two companies in New York State before joining the University
of Michigan in 1955 as a research associate in the Engineering Research Institute. He joined the faculty of the School of Dentistry as an assistant professor in


70




September Meeting, 1993


1957 and was promoted to associate professor in 1961 and professor in 1965. He
also served as chair of the Dental Materials Department from 1969-87.
Since coming to the University, Professor Craig has distinguished himself as
a dental scholar, researcher, administrator, and teacher, who has had a direct impact on the practice of dentistry worldwide. He is the editor of Restorative Dental
Materials, 9th edition (1993) and co-author of Dental Materials: Properties and
Manipulation, 5th edition (1992), two books used as texts and references
throughout the world, as well as co-author of seven other textbooks and author
of over 250 publications in scientific journals. His main research interests include
biocompatibility of materials, properties of polymers (both elastomers and composites), surface effects of materials, and experimental stress analysis.
Professor Craig has served on almost all of the standing committees within
the School of Dentistry and has served as a member and chair of the University's
Budget Priorities Committee. He is active in many professional organizations,
has served on the editorial boards of the Journal of Oral Implantology and the
Journal of Oral Rehabilitation, and has been the assistant editor of the Journal
of Biomedical Materials since 1983. Among his honors are the prestigious Wilmer Souder Award in Dental Materials (1975), the Clemson Award for Basic Research in Biomaterials (1978), and the Hollenback Memorial Prize from the
Academy of Operative Dentistry (1991). He was awarded an honorary degree by
the University of Geneva in Switzerland in 1989 and was named the Marcus L.
Ward Professor of Dentistry at the University of Michigan in 1990.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health sciences editor by naming
Robert G. Craig the Marcus L. Ward Professor Emeritus of Dentistry.
Whitmore Gray, professor of law, retired from active faculty status on
May 31, 1993, after a distinguished, 33-year career of teaching and research.
Born in Monroe, Michigan, in 1932, Professor Gray received his A.B. degree
from Princpia College in 1954 and his J.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1957. While in law school, he served as editor-in-chief of the Michigan
Law Review. Following graduation, he studied at the University of Paris and
practiced law in New York City. He was awarded his LL.D. degree by Adrian College in 1982.
Professor Gray joined the faculty of the University of Michigan Law School
as an assistant professor in 1960; he was promoted to associate professor in 1963
and professor in 1966. He has held visiting appointments at a number of distinguished law schools on three continents, including the University of Tokyo.
Professor Gray's work as a scholar and teacher has focused on three main
areas: contract law, alternate dispute resolution, and comparative law. He has
compiled extensive sets of teaching materials in all of these fields. Professor Gray
was an early leader in teaching and writing about alternate dispute resolution,
and one of his articles on this subject has been reprinted in at least six sets of dispute resolution materials. His work in comparative law has helped to inform domestic audiences about the law of such countries as Russia, Japan, and China,
and also has helped to inform audiences in many other countries about the law of
the United States. Professor Gray's teaching is noteworthy for the remarkable
opportunities for individual student work and attention to his students that he
has provided. He has also been actively involved in many professional


71




September Meeting, 1993


organizations, enriching his own resources as a teacher and scholar and adding
luster to the University's reputation.
The Regents now salute this accomplished scholar and educator by naming
Whitmore Gray professor emeritus of law.
Keith S. Henley, M.D., professor of internal medicine, retired from active
faculty status on June 30, 1993, after a notable career as a teacher, clinician, and
researcher.
Dr. Henley received his M.B.B.S. degree from King's College, University of
Durham, in England in 1948, his M.R.C.P. degree from the Royal College of Physicians in London in 1950, and his M.D. degree from the University of Durham
in 1957. From 1950-54 he trained in hospitals in West Africa and London before
emigrating to the United States and joining the University of Michigan as an instructor in the Department of Internal Medicine in 1954. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1956, associate professor in 1960, and professor in 1968.
Working with the late Dr. Marvin Pollard, Dr. Henley played a key role in
establishing one of the first divisions of gastroenterology in this country. He succeeded Dr. Pollard as chief of the Division of Gastroenterology in 1973. During
his tenure, Dr. Henley revitalized the division, creating a research environment
conducive for the recruitment of promising young investigators and providing
the foundation for the division's emergence as one of the nation's leading GI
programs.
Dr. Henley's pioneering work in the field of clinical enzymology resulted in
the identification of a marker for liver damage that is still widely used in clinical
practice to evaluate hepatocellular injury. Dr. Henley was among the first investigators to successfully isolate parenchymal cells from rat livers, and he performed
important metabolic studies defining the role of fat in the pathogenesis of
ethanol-induced liver injury. His study on the ammoniagenesis in the mitochondria of cirrhotic liver is considered a landmark paper, and his work on the effect
of ethanol on rat liver transaminase has helped elucidate the intracellular biochemical pathway by which ethanol produces damage to the liver. Using a rat
model, Dr. Henley established the association between total liver collagen formation and a serum marker of fibrogenesis, and identified prostaglandins as an inhibitor of collagen formation in experimental fibrogenesis in the rat.
An excellent clinician and inspiring teacher, Dr. Henley has trained many
academic hepatologists, some of whom have themselves gone on to become leaders in the field. He has also pioneered and developed one of the best liver transplant programs in the United States. Over the past three years, Dr. Henley has
single-handedly conducted the largest single-institution drug trial to evaluate the
effectiveness of prostaglandin in the prevention of rejection in liver transplantation; the results of his studies have far-reaching clinical implications in the handling of patients receiving liver transplants.
The Regents now salute this distinguished educator and researcher for his
dedicated service by naming Keith S. Henley professor emeritus of internal
medicine.


72




September Meeting, 1993


Jan Kmenta, professor of economics and professor of statistics, retired
from active faculty status on May 31, 1993, after a most productive career in
teaching and research.
Bor in Prague, Czechoslovakia, Professor Kmenta attended the Czech University of Technology in Prague (1947-49) and the University of Sydney in Australia (1952-55), receiving his Bachelor of Economics degree from the latter in
1955. He then received his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in 1958 and 1964, respectively, from Stanford University. He taught at the University of Wisconsin
(1964-65) and Michigan State University (1965-73) before joining the University
of Michigan as professor of economics in 1973. He received the additional appointment of professor of statistics in 1977. Professor Kmenta has been a visiting
professor at the universities of North Carolina, Bonn, Alberta, and the Saarland,
where he was awarded an honorary doctorate in 1989. He also spent a year as a
fellow of the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study in 1987-88.
Considered to be one of the foremost econometric theorists in the world,
Professor Kmenta published the definitive textbook on the subject, Elements of
Econometrics, in 1971. The second edition of that text, published in 1986, continues to be widely used in graduate-level courses and to be cited as the authoritative source for econometric methodology. In addition to this text, Professor
Kmenta is the author of numerous articles in the top journals of economics and
the editor of two books. He has an unsurpassed reputation for rigorous thinking
and attention to detail.
Professor Kmenta is best known for his detailed studies of the properties of
various econometric estimators; these include several series of papers reporting
the results of his substantial research on seemingly unrelated regressions, estimation with missing observations, and estimation of production functions. He
has served as associate editor of the Journal of the American Statistical Association and the Review of Economics and Statistics and is a fellow of the American
Statistical Association. Over the years, he has been a frequent participant in professional conferences and meetings all over the world.
The Regents now salute this distinguished economist for his dedicated service by naming Jan Kmenta professor emeritus of economics and professor emeritus of statistics.
Dale L. Oxender, professor of biological chemistry, retired from active faculty status on July 31, 1990, after a highly-productive career as a teacher and scientific investigator.
Professor Oxender received his AB. degree in chemistry from Manchester
College, North Manchester, Indiana in 1954, and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees
from Purdue University in 1956 and 1959, respectively. He joined the University
of Michigan in 1958 as a research associate in the Department of Biological
Chemistry. He was promoted to instructor in 1959, assistant professor in 1963,
associate professor in 1967, and professor in 1975. He also served as director of
the Center of Molecular Genetics from 1986-90.
Professor Oxender has been vigorous in research and teaching, has contributed heavily to the present strength of the Department of Biological Chemistry,
and is known internationally for his innovative research contributions in the
areas of biochemistry of proteins, bacterial cell transport, and genetics.


73




September Meeting, 1993


Throughout his distinguished career, he has been dedicated both to being a conscientious and effective teacher and to improving the state of health and education of society.
The Regents now salute this distinguished scientist and health educator for
his dedicated service by naming Dale L. Oxender professor emeritus of biological
chemistry.
Donald J. Portman, professor of atmospheric, oceanic, and space sciences,
retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1993, after serving the University
and the college for almost 40 years.
Professor Portman received his B.S. degree in physics from the University of
Michigan in 1946 and his Ph.D. degree in physical sciences-micrometeorology
from Johns Hopkins University in 1955. Following a period of employment in industry, he returned to the University of Michigan in 1956 as a lecturer at the
Willow Run Laboratories. A founding member of the Department of Meteorology
and Oceanography, he was appointed professor of meteorology in 1962.
Professor Portman established one of the first courses in the then emerging
field of micrometeorology, stressing the need to compare theory with measurement through simple yet sophisticated experiments. Many of today's leaders in
the discipline were students in those early courses. In his weather and climate
course, he introduced many non-science majors in the University to the underlying scientific principles that control the atmosphere, stressing the insight that
can be gained from simple observations. Under his supervision, students in
weather forecasting were invited to prepare and present forecasts to participants
in soaring and hot air balloon meets, and in sailboat races, activities in which
their safety depends on accurate weather information. Professor Portman initiated a program which trained students for the media radio, television, and
newspapers.
Professor Portman's research in micrometeorology has contributed to the
understanding of the exchange of energy and momentum between the atmosphere and the surface of the earth and of the oceans. Professor Portman participated in the Great Plains Turbulence Program, an experimental program that is
still widely cited. Later, he was an investigator in the International Indian Ocean
Expedition and in the Barbados Oceanographic and Meteorological Expedition.
Closer to home, Professor Portman conducted measurements in the Keweenaw
Peninsula over snow and frozen ground. He is perhaps best known for his studies of turbulence through the optical propagation of a laser beam through the atmosphere. Professor Portman served as a consultant to industry on the dispersal
of pollutants from power plants.
Professor Portman's service included membership in SACUA for three years
on the Research Policies Committee, which he chaired for one year. He has also
served in the Senate Assembly for two three-year terms. In addition, he served
with distinction on many college and department committees.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Donald J. Portman
professor emeritus of atmospheric, oceanic, and space sciences.
John H. Romani, professor of public health administration in the School
of Public Health, will retire from active faculty status on September 30, 1993.


74




September Meeting, 1993


Bor in Italy, Professor Romani received his B.A and M.A degrees from the
University of New Hampshire in 1949 and his Ph.D. degree from the University
of Michigan in 1955. He worked at the Brookings Institution and the Cleveland
Metropolitan Services Commission and taught at Western Michigan University
and the University of Pittsburgh before coming to the University of Michigan as
associate professor of public health in 1961. He was promoted to professor in
1965 and also served as assistant dean (1962-66) and associate dean (1966-69) of
the School of Public Health. Professor Romani left the University of Michigan in
1969 to serve as vice chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee. He
returned in 1971 as professor of public health administration and associate vice
president for academic affairs. He held the latter position until 1975, at which
time he became the first person to chair the Department of Health Planning and
Administration (later renamed the Department of Health Policy and Administration). He served in that role for five years, and then again as interim chair in
1991.
Throughout most of his tenure, Professor Romani was one of the principal
academic resources in the area of public health administration in the School of
Public Health. He was also active in faculty governance and University affairs,
serving on the Senate Assembly, SACUA, and the School of Public Health Executive Committee. Professor Romani was also revered as a teacher and counselor
by several generations of students, and he still maintains contact with many of
them.
Professor Romani is renowned statewide and nationally for his many contributions to public health. He chaired a committee charged with reorganization of
the Michigan Department of Public Health and a working group of the Public
Health Statute Revision Project. He consults frequently with local, state, national, and international health organizations. He has served as president of the
American Public Health Association (APHA) and chaired the committee that led
to the formation of the public health school accrediting body, the Council for
Education in Public Health.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming John
H. Romani professor emeritus of public health administration.
Robert L. Shaffer, Lewis E. Wehmeyer and Elaine Prince Wehmeyer Professor of Fungal Taxonomy in the Department of Biology and curator of fungi in
the Herbarium, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1993.
Professor Shaffer received his B.S. (1951) and M.S. (1952) degrees from
Kansas State College and his Ph.D. degree (1955) from Cornell University. He
taught at the University of Chicago from 1955-60 and then joined the faculty of
the University of Michigan in 1960 as assistant professor of botany. He was promoted to associate professor in 1963 and professor in 1970.
Professor Shaffer also served as curator of fungi and director (1975-86) of
the Herbarium. During his tenure as director, the Herbarium received a series of
curatorial grants from the National Science Foundation worth over $1 million.
These grants enabled the Herbarium to purchase much-needed equipment and
achieve new levels of curatorial excellence.
In the area of research, Professor Shaffer has centered on Russula, a large
and difficult genus of fleshy fungi, and through a series of publications he has


75




September Meeting, 1993


established himself as a leading expert in the systematics of Russula. As an instructor, he has taught introductory courses in botany and biology, as well as
"Introduction to Mycology," a course essential for students in such diverse areas
as the Medical School and the School of Natural Resources and Environment.
His formal courses have always been marked by meticulous preparation and a
sincere commitment to giving his best to his students. Professor Shaffer is also
well-known among area mushroom fanciers for his popular adult education
course on Michigan mushrooms.
Professor Shaffer has also been active in the Mycological Society of America
(including a term as president) and the North American Mycological Association.
He has also served as either member or chair of most of the important committees in his department.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Robert L. Shaffer the Lewis E. Wehmeyer and Elaine Prince
Wehmeyer Professor Emeritus of Fungal Taxonomy and curator emeritus of
fungi.
Mary Ann P. Swain, professor of nursing in the School of Nursing and
associate vice president for academic affairs, retired from the University of
Michigan on August 13, 1993, to assume the position of provost at the State University of New York at Binghamton. This concludes a career at Michigan that
spanned nearly 25 years.
Professor Swain received her B.A degree in psychology from DePauw University in 1963 and her M.A and Ph.D. degrees in psychology from the University of Michigan in 1964 and 1969, respectively. She joined the faculty of the
School of Nursing in 1970 as an associate professor of psychology in nursing and
was promoted to professor of psychology in nursing in 1975. At the School of
Nursing, she served as director of the doctoral program and as chair for the Department of Nursing Research.
In 1983, Professor Swain was appointed associate vice president for academic affairs. Other administrative positions she held include interim co-director
of personnel (1986-88), interim director of the Affirmative Action Office
(1988-89), and interim vice president for student services (1990-92). Professor
Swain also served on a variety of committees, including the Committee on the
Status of Women in Higher Education, which she chaired from 1978-79, and the
Budget Priorities Committee, which she chaired from 1981-83.
In recognition of her dedicated service and her many contributions to the
School of Nursing, the Office of Academic Affairs, and the entire University community, the Regents now name Mary Ann P. Swain professor emerita of nursing.
Richard G. Teske, professor of astronomy, retired from active faculty
status on May 31, 1993, after a productive career as a teacher and researcher.
Born and raised in Ohio, Professor Teske received his B.S. degree in 1952
from Bowling Green State University, his M.S. degree in 1956 from The Ohio
State University, and his Ph.D. degree in 1961 from Harvard University. While a
student at Harvard, he was employed as an astronomer at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, where he was in charge of tracking the first American
artificial satellite in 1958.


76




September Meeting, 1993


Astrophysical Observatory, where he was in charge of tracking the first American
artificial satellite in 1958.
Professor Teske came to the University of Michigan in 1960 as an instructor
in astronomy. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1962, associate professor in 1967, and professor in 1977. In 1962, at the University's McMath-Hulbert
solar observatory, Professor Teske was principal investigator for a solar x-ray detector flown on the Third Orbiting Solar Observatory (OSO III), one of the earliest space experiments to be launched by an American university. The OSO III
x-ray experiment provided the first comprehensive details and statistical data
about soft x-ray emission from solar flares, and the results were incorporated
into many publications and two doctoral theses, thus exposing many graduate
students to space research at an early point in its history.
After making strong contributions to solar and coronal physics, Professor
Teske switched to the study of supernova remnants in 1984, where he drew upon
his knowledge of coronal x-rays to make original contributions to research on the
physics of these objects. From 1987-92, he was interim director and then director
of the Michigan-Dartmouth-M.I.T. Observatory, a facility located on Kitt Peak in
Arizona and operated jointly by the three institutions.
Professor Teske has served as a consultant to NASA's Solar Physical Subcommittee of the Astronomy Missions Board and has served on various NASA
satellite payload selection committees and peer review panels. He has taught
classes, with distinction, at all levels within the Department of Astronomy, from
basic introductory courses to graduate courses on the sun and solar system.
The Regents now salute this distinguished astronomer and educator for his
dedicated service by naming Richard G. Teske professor emeritus of astronomy.
Memorials
No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees
There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved the consent agenda as listed above.
The University's Investments as of June 30, 1993
Vice President Womack submitted a separately-bound report of the University's investments at June 30, 1993.
Norman Herberts Election to The Conmmon Fund Board of Governors
Vice President Womack reported that he expected that Norman G. Herbert,
treasurer and investment officer, would be elected to the board of trustees of The
Common Fund at its annual meeting on September 28, 1993. Vice President
Womack also reported that he would be resigning from his own position on the
Endowment Advisors Board of Trustees.


77




September Meeting, 1993


Contract of Participation between the Regents of the University of
Michigan and The Common Fund
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Deitch, the Regents
unanimously approved continuation of a contract of participation with The Common Fund. Because Norman Herbert, a University employee, is being elected to
the board of trustees of The Common Fund, this arrangement falls under the
state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the participation contract are the Regents of the University of Michigan and The Common Fund, a nonprofit corporation.
2.  The terms of the participation contract include the University's ability, from
time to time, to invest various minimum amounts in funds established by The
Common Fund. The funds in which the investments are made are managed by
managers selected by The Common Fund, and The Common Fund receives fees
based on the type of asset and the size of the University's participation to cover
the expenses of The Common Fund. Other than the transfer of funds, no University services, facilities, or employees are utilized in the performance of this
participation contract.
3.  As a trustee of The Common Fund, Mr. Herbert will receive a fee of approximately $14,000 annually plus reimbursement of his expenses.
Sale of $20,060,000 Housing Revenue Bonds, Series 1993A
The Regents were informed of the sale of $20,060,000 Housing Revenue
Bonds, Series 1993A, which provide a savings of $1,712,335.84 during the next 17
years.
Sale of $3,170,000 Intercollegiate Athletic Revenue Refunding Bonds,
Series 1993
The Regents were informed of the sale of $3,170,000 Intercollegiate Athletic
Revenue Bonds, Series 1993, which provide a savings of $148,015.83 during the
next 5 years.
Residential Property, Birmingham, Michigan
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Deitch, the Regents
unanimously approved acceptance of a gift of residential property in Birmingham, Michigan, and offering the property for sale at a price established by the
University's appraisal, according to the terms outlined in the Regents
Communication.
Issuance of Hospital Revenue Bonds, Medical Service Plan Revenue
Bonds, and/or Medical Service Plan Refunding Bonds

vice president and chief financial officer to issue Hospital Revenue Bonds, Medical Service Plan Revenue Bonds, or Medical Service Plan Refunding Bonds, or a
combination of them, and:

1. together with the underwriters, develop the terms and legal

Hospital (U.S.V.A) was requesting permission to demolish a house at 330 Oakway and carry out grading work on University property, as described in the Regents Communication, in preparation for the expansion of the U.S.V.A and
relocation of Oakway Boulevard. Regent Varner moved authorization for permitting the U.S.V.A to demolish the house at 330 Oakway and carry out the grading

unanimously.

plan for extending the roadway to the east, towards Huron Parkway.

with Helicopter Aviation Services Corporation for the lease of two Bell 230 helicopters, at a cost of $5.7 million, to replace the two Survival Flight helicopters
currently in service.


80




September Meeting, 1993


Memorandum of Agreement between the University of Michigan and
Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory (GLERL)
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved a memorandum of agreement between the University of
Michigan and the Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory (GLERL) for
receipt of data from the CoastWatch Program of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Because the director of GLERL, Alfred Beeton, is also
a University employee, this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict
of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with
statutory requirements:
1.   Dr. Beeton has provided an agreement to the Regents of the University of
Michigan making available products from the CoastWatch Program.
2.   The agreement will provide data produced for the research community by the
CoastWatch Regional Site. The agreement is open-ended and there will be no
transfer of funds.
3.   Dr. Beeton is the director of Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory.
His University appointment is adjunct, without salary.
Proposed Subcontract between the Regents of the University of Michigan and Michigan Critical Care Consultants, Inc.
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
unanimously approved a subcontract between the University of Michigan and
Michigan Critical Care Consultants, Inc., as described in the Regents Communication. Because the owner of Michigan Critical Care Consultants, Inc., Dr. Robert H. Bartlett, is also a University employee, this subcontract falls under the
state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement will be Michigan Critical Care Consultants, Inc. (the
"Company") and the Regents of the University of Michigan.
2.   The proposed agreement is a standard University research contract. There are
no restrictions on publication or openness of the research. The project involves
the testing of a pump system design and the development of a safe and least
hemolytic blood driver for use in extracorporeal circulation and other therapeutic applications. Approval has been obtained for use of animal subjects in the research.
The subcontract will cover animal and animal care costs, laboratory supplies,
and equipment use charges totaling $14,950 over a six month period. Dr.
Bartlett will supervise the project and act as project director. Dr. Bartlett will
not be reimbursed for his time on the project as a University employee.
Collection of a portion of the indirect cost of this project will be deferred until
such time as the Company owes the University a royalty payment due to revenue received from sale of the pump (indirect cost of $6,760 assessed at 52 percent, $1,950 collected at 15 percent, $810 deferred).
3.   Dr. Bartlett participates as a member of the board of directors of the Company
without compensation and owns 33 percent of the Company.


81




September Meeting, 1993


College of Pharmacy, UM-Ann Arbor, Student Fee Rates for 1993-94
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
unanimously approved fees of $4,449 per term for residents and $8,347 per term
for nonresidents. This action corrects the incorrect fee schedule for the College of
Pharmacy that had been approved by the Regents in July 1993.
Establishment of the International Institute
Provost Whitaker gave a historical review of the University's initiatives in
the international arena, and noted that the purpose of the International Institute
is to enhance the University's ability to deal with international issues. There will
be administrative cost savings in the administration of the international centers,
and additional costs in the additional funds being allocated to support international education. The institute will be housed in LS&A, but will support campuswide international education and research activities. Provost Whitaker observed
that this will be an important step toward the international, global theme that
has been stressed by President Duderstadt.
Regent Power moved approval of the establishment of the International Institute. Regent Varner seconded the motion. Following some discussion, the motion was approved unanimously.
New Degree Program for UM-Flint College of Arts and Sciences
Chancellor Jones described this proposal for creating a new degree program,
Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree in Studio Art, in the College of Arts and Sciences at
UM-Flint. Following some discussion, Regent McGowan moved approval to establish the Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree in Studio Art in the College of Arts and
Sciences at the UM-Flint. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
UM-Flint Faculty Code
This Regents Communication was withdrawn from the agenda until the following month.
Medical Staff Appointments
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Waters, and on the recommendation of the UM Hospitals Executive Board, the Regents unanimously
approved several appointments to medical staff membership.
Ann Arbor Technology Park/Comshare Property
Vice President Womack reported that a committee representing the medical
center, central administration, and the University's planning consultants, Johnson Johnson & Roy/inc., had been established to identify an appropriate site in
northeast Ann Arbor that would enable the Medical Center to expand its services. He called on Dr. Zuidema, who observed that the trend in patient care, both
nationally and locally, was toward the ambulatory environment, rather than the
inpatient environment. The proposed site would be ideal for expanding ambulatory care services, with easy access for patients, students, and faculty. It would


82




September Meeting, 1993


also provide improved educational opportunities for students and faculty, and
would permit improved efficiency and economy of scale.
Vice President Womack explained that the terms of the proposal provide for
purchasing one 37.5-acre parcel of the Ann Arbor Technology Park and a 97.18
acre parcel from Comshare now, with a one-year option to acquire a second,
51.5-acre parcel, and a one-year right of first refusal to acquire the remaining
204.1 acres of the Ann Arbor Technology Park, according to the terms described
in the Regents Communication. Regent Baker stated that because he had served
as a receiver for the property one and one-half years ago, he would therefore neither comment on nor vote on this proposal.
Regent Brown moved that the University purchase parcel R of the Ann Arbor Technology Park (AATP) and the Comshare property as described in the Regents Communication, and further, that the University enter into an option
agreement for parcel S and a right of first refusal for the remaining AATP parcels. If it is determined that the additional acreage is needed, the University will
proceed with the acquisition of the properties at the terms outlined in the Regents Communication. Regent Waters seconded the motion. Following some discussion about why this particular site location, as opposed to property already
owned by the University, was deemed most appropriate for the Medical Center's
needs, the vote was taken and the motion was approved, with Regents Brown,
Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters in favor and Regent Baker
abstaining.
Presidential Salary
Regent Brown noted that the Board usually sets the salary of the president
at its September meeting. He observed that because of the University of Michigan's ranking as among the best in the nation, its overall policy is to compensate
its president at a level commensurate with the top public universities in the
country. He also noted that recent financial constraints have led to the fact that
the president's compensation has fallen behind that of other peer institutions.
The Regents intend to provide President Duderstadt with a merit salary increase as well as a program of equity adjustment that would bring his compensation in line with the University's compensation policy. The equity adjustment
program would be phased in over a three-year period, and would be fimded from
the Auxiliary Activities Fund, rather than from the General Fund. The Regents
would continue to review annually both the president's performance in office and
the extent to which the equity adjustment program has caught up with compensation with peer institutions.
Regent Brown moved that the president receive a 5 percent merit salary increase of $9,019 on his current base salary of $180,385, and an equity adjustment
of $16,666, bringing his total compensation to $206,070 for the 1994 fiscal year.
In addition, he proposed that the president receive an appropriate term life
insurance policy, which would be in effect so long as he serves as president.


83




September Meeting, 1993


Presidential Retirement Security Program
In accordance with retirement security provisions that have been made
available for past presidents after they end their service as president, Regent
Brown moved adoption of the following program for President Duderstadt:
Terms: This program takes effect upon retirement as president
or upon taking a leave of absence from the University, pursuant to
the regular rules in effect for faculty for that purpose, but not upon
resignation to take a position at another institution or if terminated
for malfeasance. The program ends at the age of 70, at which point
the ordinary faculty retirement program becomes effective.
Title: University professor of science and engineering (with
tenure) and president emeritus.
Duties: Teach and conduct research in any school or college
(following discussions with the provost and appropriate deans).
Reporting Line: To the provost.
Salary: A twelve-month appointment at a salary equal to the
average of the three top faculty salaries in the College of
Engineering at the time the program begins, and adjusted thereafter
on a yearly basis.
Support:  Similar to that of an endowed chair; e.g., office,
secretary, personal computer, travel funds, and supplies.
Transition:  A one-year sabbatical leave at the presidential
compensation rate at the end of his career as president, and prior to
resuming his role as a faculty member.
Regent Waters seconded the motion. Regent Baker stated that he would
vote against the motion based on the structure of the package, and that this vote
should not be interpreted as a lack of support for the president's tenure in office.
Regent Brown pointed out that the Regents had provided President Shapiro with
a similar package.
Regent Power pointed out that the equity adjustment portion of the package
would be funded through the Auxiliary Activities Fund, so that money would not
be taken away from the General Fund to bring the president's salary in line with
that of peer institutions. Regents Varner and McFee emphasized that the
Regents are committed to bringing about equity in the president's salary in the
face of widespread funding constraints in higher education, which is why the equity portion must be phased in.
The vote was then taken, and the motion carried, with Regents Brown,
Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters in favor and Regent Baker
opposed.


84




September Meeting, 1993


There being no further discussion, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting will be held on October 21 and 22, 1993. Regents' expenses for the
months of July and August, 1993, totalled $366.18 and 371.27, respectively.

SEPTEMBER MEETING, 1993


APPENDIX A
RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY OF HOSPITAL REVENUE
BONDS AND MEDICAL SERVICE PLAN REVENUE BONDS, AND
PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS, the Regents of the University of Michigan (the "Issuer") constitutes a constitutional body corporate established pursuant to Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, as amended, with the general supervision of the University of Michigan (the
"University") and the control and direction of all expenditures from the University's funds; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has determined it is necessary and desirable to acquire, construct,
furnish and equip the Cancer and Geriatrics Centers Project and to undertake site preparation
and adjacent facility renovations related to the future North Entrance Parking Structure (collectively the "Projects"), all for use by the University of Michigan Hospitals (the "Hospital") and the
Medical School of the University (the "School"); and
WHEREAS, the Issuer entered into a master indenture, as supplemented (the "Master Indenture") dated as of May 1, 1986 with Comerica Bank as Master Trustee (the "Master Trustee"), pursuant to which revenue obligations for the benefit of the Hospital have been and will be
issued and secured; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has previously issued under the Master Indenture its $65,115,000
Hospital Revenue Bonds, Series 1990, dated as of December 15, 1990 (the "Prior Hospital
Bonds") and, by Resolution adopted May 7, 1993 (the "May 7 Resolution"), has determined it
may be appropriate and in the best interest of the Issuer to refund all or a portion of the Prior
Hospital Bonds, as determined by an Authorized Officer (hereinafter defined) (the portion of the
Prior Hospital Bonds to be refunded being herein called the "Hospital Refunded Bonds") and has
authorized the issuance of hospital revenue bonds under the Master Indenture for the purposes
of refunding the Hospital Refunded Bonds; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has previously issued its $53,542,444.75 Medical Service Plan
Revenue Bonds, Series 1991, dated as of November 15, 1991 and December 10, 1991 (the "Prior
MSP Bonds"); and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has previously established its Medical Service Plan (the "Medical
Service Plan") as the mechanism for the managing of, and billing and collecting charges for, the
clinical practice activities of the faculty of the clinical departments of the School; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has determined it may be appropriate and in the best interest of
the Issuer to refund all or a portion of the Prior MSP Bonds, as determined by an Authorized Officer (hereinafter defined) (the portion of the Prior MSP Bonds to be refunded being herein called
the "MSP Refunded Bonds"); and
WHEREAS, in the exercise of its constitutional duties, and in order to prudently control
and direct expenditures from the University's funds, the Issuer determines it is necessary and desirable to authorize the issuance of revenue obligations (the "Bonds"), comprised of hospital revenue bonds (the "Hospital Bonds") or Medical Service Plan Revenue Bonds (the "MSP Bonds") or
a combination thereof, in the aggregate original principal amount (exclusive of the principal
amount of hospital revenue bonds authorized by the May 7 Resolution) of not to exceed One
Hundred Sixty Five Million Dollars ($165,000,000) to provide funds which, together with other
available funds, may be used for one or more of the following purposes: to pay all or a portion of
the costs of the Projects; to refund the MSP Refunded Bonds; and to pay certain costs incurred in
connection with the issuance and sale of the Bonds and the refunding of the MSP Refunded
Bonds, including capitalized interest; and


87




September Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


WHEREAS, the Hospital Bonds will be issued pursuant to a trust indenture (the "Series
Indenture") to be entered into by and between the Issuer and a trustee (the "Series Trustee") to
be selected by the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, or Associate Vice President for
Finance of the University (each an "Authorized Officer") as a series of revenue obligations under
the Master Indenture; and
WHEREAS, the MSP Bonds will be issued pursuant to a trust indenture (the "MSP Indenture") to be entered into by and between the Issuer and a trustee (the "Trustee") to be selected by an Authorized Officer as a series of revenue obligations; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer shall retain Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated as the senior underwriter for the Bonds, and any other underwriters to be designated by an Authorized Officer
(collectively called the "Underwriter"), as underwriter to undertake market analysis with respect
to the sale of the Bonds and to submit an offer or offers to purchase the Bonds pursuant to a
Bond Purchase Agreement or Agreements (collectively the "Bond Purchase Agreement") to be
negotiated with the Underwriter and executed and delivered on behalf of the Issuer by an
Authorized Officer; and
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:
1. The Issuer hereby authorizes the issuance, execution and delivery under the Master Indenture of hospital revenue bonds of the Issuer (herein called the "Hospital Bonds") in one or
more series to be designated as shall be determined by an Authorized Officer (but which designation shall include the words "HOSPITAL REVENUE BONDS" or if appropriate, "HOSPITAL
REVENUE AND REFUNDING BONDS") with appropriate series designations, in the aggregate
original principal amount to be established by an Authorized Officer, but not to exceed the principal amount necessary to produce proceeds of $65,000,000 (but the total aggregate principal
amount of the Hospital Bonds and the MSP Bonds shall not exceed $165,000,000), to be dated as
of the date or dates established by an Authorized Officer, for the purpose of providing funds
which, together with other available funds, may be used to pay all or a portion of the costs of the
Projects and to pay costs incidental to the issuance of the Hospital Bonds, including capitalized
interest for such period, if any, as an Authorized Officer may deem appropriate. The Hospital
Bonds shall be serial bonds, or term bonds, which may be subject to redemption requirements, or
both, as shall be established by an Authorized Officer, but the first maturity shall be not earlier
than December 1, 1993 and the last maturity shall be no later than December 1, 2027. The Hospital Bonds may bear no interest or may bear interest at stated fixed rates for the respective maturities thereof as shall be established by an Authorized Officer, but the highest fixed rate of
interest for any maturity shall not exceed 7% per annum, and the Bonds may be issued in whole
or in part as capital appreciation bonds, which for their term or any part thereof bear no interest
but appreciate in principal amount over time at compounded rate (not in excess of 7% per annum) to be determined by an Authorized Officer. Alternatively, all or part of the Hospital Bonds
may bear interest at a variable rate of interest for all or a portion of their term, and the variable
rate of interest shall not exceed the maximum rate permitted by law. In addition, all or part of
the Bonds may be issued in related series, one of which bears interest at a variable rate and one
of which bears interest at a residual rate determined by subtracting the variable rate from the
fixed rate paid by the Issuer, but the combined rate on such Hospital Bonds, taking the two related series together, which shall be determined by an Authorized Officer, shall not exceed 7%
per annum The Hospital Bonds may be subject to redemption or call for purchase prior to maturity at the times and prices and in the manner as shall be established by an Authorized Officer.
The maximum annual principal and interest requirements on the Hospital Bonds, taking into account any swap or other arrangements described below, and assuming the variable rate on any
Hospital Bonds not also subject to a swap or other arrangement, and not issued as part of related
series as described above, is equal to 7% per annum, shall not exceed $10,000,000. Interest on the
Hospital Bonds shall be payable at the times as shall be specified by an Authorized Officer. The
Hospital Bonds shall be issued in fully registered form in denominations, shall be payable as to
principal and interest in the manner, shall be subject to transfer and exchange, and shall be executed and authenticated, all as shall be provided in the Series Indenture. The Hospital Bonds
shall be sold to the Underwriter pursuant to the Bond Purchase Agreement for a price to be established by an Authorized Officer (but the Underwriter's discount, exclusive of original issue
discount, shall not exceed 0.8% of the principal amount thereof) plus accrued interest, if any,
from the dated date of the Hospital Bonds to the date of delivery thereof. In connection with the
issuance of the Hospital Bonds, either of the Authorized Officers may, on behalf of and as the act


88




September Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


of the Issuer, enter into an interest rate swap, cap or similar agreement or agreements (collectively, the "Hospital Swap Agreement") with a counter-party or counter-parties to be selected by
the Authorized Officer. Such Hospital Swap Agreement shall provide for payments between the
Issuer and the counter-party related to interest on the Hospital Bonds or indexed or market established rates. The effective interest rates on the Hospital Bonds, taking into account the effect
of the Hospital Swap Agreement, shall be within the limitations set forth herein.
The Hospital Bonds may be issued as part of a single issue or series with the hospital revenue bonds authorized by the May 7 Resolution, in which event the designation of those bonds
may be as provided herein for the Hospital Bonds. The limitations as to the Hospital Bonds, and
the bonds authorized by the May 7 Resolution, contained herein and the May 7 Resolution, respectively, shall be applied separately to the Hospital Bonds and the bonds authorized by the
May 7 Resolution, even if all such bonds are issued as part of a single series.
2. The Issuer hereby authorizes the issuance, execution and delivery of medical service
plan revenue bonds of the Issuer (herein called the 'MSP Bonds") in one or more series to be
designated as shall be determined by an Authorized Officer (but which designation shall include
the words "MEDICAL SERVICE PLAN REVENUE BONDS", or, if appropriate, "MEDICAL
SERVICE PLAN REVENUE AND REFUNDING BONDS"), with appropriate series designations, in the aggregate original principal amount to be established by an Authorized Officer, but
not to exceed the principal amount necessary to produce proceeds of $125,000,000 (but the total
aggregate principal amount of the MSP Bonds and the Hospital Bonds shall not exceed
$165,000,000) to be dated as of the date or dates established by an Authorized Officer, for the
purpose of providing funds which, together with other available funds, may be used for one or
more of the following purposes: to pay all or part of the costs of the Projects; to refund the MSP
Refunded Bonds; and to pay costs incidental to the refunding and to the issuance of the MSP
Bonds, including capitalized interest for such period if any, as an Authorized Officer may deem
appropriate. The MSP Bonds shall be serial bonds, or term bonds, which may be subject to redemption requirements, or both, as shall be established by an Authorized Officer, but the first
maturity shall be not earlier than December 1, 1993 and the last maturity shall be no later than
December 1, 2027. The MSP Bonds may bear no interest or may bear interest at stated fixed
rates for the respective maturities thereof as shall be established by an Authorized Officer, but
the highest fixed rate of interest for any maturity shall not exceed 7% per annum, and the MSP
Bonds may be issued in whole or in part as capital appreciation bonds, which for their term or
any part thereof bear no interest but appreciate in principal amount over time at compounded
rate (not in excess of 7% per annum) to be determined by an Authorized Officer. Alternatively,
all or part of the MSP Bonds may bear interest at a variable rate of interest for all or a portion of
their term, and the variable rate of interest shall not exceed the maximum rate permitted by law.
In addition, all or part of the MSP Bonds may be issued in related series, one of which bears interest at a variable rate and one of which bears interest at a residual rate determined by subtracting the variable rate from the fixed rate paid by the Issuer, but the combined rate on such
MSP Bonds, taking the two related series together, which shall be determined by an Authorized
Officer, shall not exceed 7% per annum. The MSP Bonds may be subject to redemption or call for
purchase prior to maturity at the times and prices and in the manner as shall be established by
an Authorized Officer. The maximum annual principal and interest requirements on the MSP
Bonds, taking into account any swap or other arrangements described below, and assuming the
variable rate on any MSP Bonds not also subject to a swap or other arrangement, and not issued
as part of related series as described above, is equal to 7% per annum, shall not exceed
$9,000,000. Interest on the MSP Bonds shall be payable at the times as shall be specified by an
Authorized Officer. The MSP Bonds shall be issued in fully registered form in denominations,
shall be payable as to principal and interest in the manner, shall be subject to transfer and exchange, and shall be executed and authenticated, all as shall be provided in the MSP Indenture.
The MSP Bonds shall be sold to the Underwriter pursuant to the Bond Purchase Agreement for
a price to be established by an Authorized Officer (but the Underwriter's discount, exclusive of
original issue discount, shall not exceed 0.8% of the principal amount thereof) plus accrued interest, if any, from the dated date of the MSP Bonds to the date of delivery thereof. In connection
with the issuance of the MSP Bonds, either of the Authorized Officers may, on behalf of and as
the act of the Issuer enter into an interest rate swap, cap or similar agreement or agreements
(collectively, the '"M~P Swap Agreement") with a counter-party or counter-parties to be selected
by the Authorized Officer. Such MSP Swap Agreement shall provide for payments between the
Issuer and the counter-party related to interest on the MSP Bonds or indexed or market established rates. The effective interest rates on the MSP Bonds, taking into account the effect of the
MSP Swap Agreement, shall be within the limitations set forth herein.


89




September Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


3. The Hospital Bonds, and the obligations of the Issuer under the Hospital Swap Agreement, shall be limited and not general obligations of the Issuer payable from Hospital Gross
Revenues (as defined in the Master Indenture) and equally and ratably secured with all other
Revenue Obligations (as defined in the Master Indenture) by an irrevocable pledge of the Pledged
Hospital Gross Revenues (as defined in the Master Indenture) and the funds from time to time
on deposit in certain of the funds created pursuant to the Master Indenture and shall be additionally secured by the funds from time to time on deposit in certain of the funds created pursuant to the Series Indenture.
Except as provided in the Master Indenture and the Series Indenture, no recourse shall be
had for the payment of the principal amount of or interest or premium on the Hospital Bonds or
any obligation of the Issuer under the Master Indenture, the Series Indenture or the Hospital
Swap Agreement, or any claim based thereon against the State of Michigan, the Issuer, or any officer or agent thereof, as individuals, either directly or indirectly, nor shall the Hospital Bonds or
any obligation of the Issuer under the Master Indenture, the Series Indenture, or the Hospital
Swap Agreement become a lien on or be secured by any property, real, personal or mixed of the
State of Michigan or the Issuer or the University, other than the Pledged Hospital Gross Revenues and the moneys from time to time on deposit in certain of the funds established by the Master Indenture and the Series Indenture.
Notwithstanding anything herein or in the May 7 Resolution, any obligations of the Issuer
under the Hospital Swap Agreement or the swap agreement authorized by the May 7 Resolution
may be payable and secured on a subordinated basis to the Hospital Bonds and other Revenue
Obligations.
4. The MSP Bonds, and any obligations of the Issuer under the MSP Swap Agreement,
shall be limited and not general obligations of the Issuer payable from and equally and ratably
secured by an irrevocable pledge of the Medical Service Plan Revenues (as defined in the MSP Indenture) on a parity basis with the Prior MSP Bonds and shall be additionally secured by the
funds from time to time on deposit in certain of the funds created pursuant to the MSP
Indenture.
Except as provided in the MSP Indenture, no recourse shall be had for the payment of the
principal amount of or interest or premium on the MSP Bonds or any obligation of the Issuer
under the MSP Indenture or the MSP Swap Agreement, or any claim based thereon against the
State of Michigan, the Issuer, or any officer of agent thereof, as individuals, either directly or indirectly, nor shall the MSP Bonds or any obligation of the Issuer under the MSP Indenture, or
the MSP Swap Agreement become a lien on or be secured by any property, real, personal or
mixed of the State of Michigan or the Issuer or the University, other than the Medical Service
Plan Revenues and the moneys from time to time on deposit in certain of the funds established
by the MSP Indenture.
Notwithstanding anything herein, any obligation of the Issuer under the MSP Swap Agreement may be payable and secured on a subordinated basis to the MSP Bonds and the Prior MSP
Bonds.
5. The right is reserved to issue additional bonds, notes or other obligations payable from
Hospital Gross Revenues or Medical Service Plan Revenues, respectively, or secured on a parity
basis with the Hospital Bonds or the MSP Bonds from the Pledged Hospital Gross Revenues or
the Medical Service Plan Revenues, respectively, upon compliance with the terms and conditions
set forth in the Master Indenture or the MSP Indenture.
6. Either Authorized Officer is hereby authorized and directed, in the name and on behalf
of the Issuer and as its corporate act and deed, to retain a financial advisor, if deemed necessary
by the Authorized Officer, to designate any underwriters in addition to Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated, to negotiate, execute and deliver the Series Indenture, the MSP Indenture, the Bond
Purchase Agreement or Agreements, the Hospital Swap Agreement and the MSP Swap Agreement, in each case subject to the terms hereof. Any of said documents may, in the discretion of an
Authorized Officer, also be executed by the Treasurer and Investment Officer of the University.
7. Either Authorized Officer is hereby authorized, empowered and directed, in the name
and on behalf of the Issuer, and as its corporate act and deed, to execute the Hospital Bonds and
the MSP Bonds by placing his manual or facsimile signature thereon, and to deliver the separate


90




September Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


issues of the Bonds to the Underwriter in exchange for the purchase price thereof, as shall be
provided in the Bond Purchase Agreement or Agreements.
8. Either Authorized Officer is hereby authorized to prepare or arrange to be prepared the
Preliminary Official Statement or Statements with respect to the Bonds and to prepare or arrange to be prepared, and to execute and deliver on behalf of the Issuer the Official Statement or
Statements with respect to the Bonds and such supplements or amendments to the Official Statement or Statements as may be required pursuant to the Bond Purchase Agreement or Agreements. The Underwriter is hereby authorized to circulate and use the Preliminary Official
Statement or Statements and the Official Statement or Statements, as the same may be so supplemented or amended, in accordance with applicable law, in the offering, sale and remarketing
of the Bonds.
9. Each of the Authorized Officers, the Secretary, the Treasurer and Investment Officer,
the General Counsel, and any other appropriate officer of the University are hereby authorized
to perform all acts and deeds and to execute and deliver all instruments and documents for an on
behalf of the Issuer or the University required by this resolution, the Master Indenture, the Series Indenture, the MSP Indenture the Hospital Swap Agreement, the MSP Swap Agreement or
the Bond Purchase Agreement or Agreements, or necessary, expedient and proper in connection
with the issuance, sale and delivery of the Bonds or any issue or series thereof, and the ongoing
operation of the financing programs represented by the Bonds, all as contemplated hereby.
10. The Authorized Officers are, or either of them is, hereby authorized, empowered and directed, in the name of and on behalf of the Issuer, and as its corporate act and deed, to negotiate,
execute and deliver an escrow agreement relating to the MSP Refunded Bonds and the MSP
Bond proceeds therefor, in such form as an Authorized Officer shall approve upon recommendation of legal counsel, subject to the terms hereof, which approval shall be conclusively evidenced
by the execution of such escrow agreement.
11. All resolutions or parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the Issuer in conflict herewith be and the same are hereby repealed insofar as such conflict exists.


91




OCTOBER MEETING, 1993


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, October 21, 1993
The Regents assembled at 10:00 am. in the Regents' Room. Present were
President Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan,
Power, and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy,
and Vice President Harrison were also present. Executive Vice President
Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Hartford, and Neal, and Chancellors Jones
and Renick were absent. Regent Varner arrived shortly after the start of the
meeting.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Regent
Deitch, who made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Sections 8(a), 8(e), and 8(h) of the Open Meetings
Act, as amended by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents
meet in closed session on October 21, 1993, for the following
purposes: 1) to consider a periodic personnel evaluation of a person
who has requested confidentiality [Sec. 8(a)]; 2) to consult with our
attorney regarding trial or settlement strategy in connection with
specific pending litigation [Sec. 8(e)]; and 3) to consider material
exempt from discussion or disclosure by the Michigan Freedom of
Information Act [Sec. 8(h)]. Such exempt material consists of a
written opinion from the Board's legal counsel.
Regent McGowan seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously,
after which the Regents immediately met in closed session.
A Thoughtful Discussion of Political Correctness and Academic Values
The Regents reconvened at 1:00 p.m. in the East Conference Room of the
Horace H. Rackham Building and participated in a panel discussion about political correctness and academic values. Panelists included Professors Elizabeth Anderson, Lee Bollinger, James Jackson, Rebecca Scott, and James Turner. Audio
and video tapes of the discussion are on file in the Office of the Secretary of the
University.
Friday, October 22, 1993
The Regents met at 9:20 am. in the Harding Mott University Center on the
campus of the University of Michigan-Flint. Present were President Duderstadt


93




October Meeting, 1993


and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and
Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy was also present, as were Provost
Whitaker, Executive Vice President Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, and Chancellors Jones and Renick
Ernst & Young Management Report and Responses
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order, and called on Executive
Vice President Womack to introduce the external auditor's report. Executive Vice
President Womack introduced Messrs. Robert Emde and Harold Miller, of Ernst
& Young, and George Johnson, a certified public accountant who assisted in the
audit.
Mr. Emde noted that Ernst & Young's opinion on the financial statements,
submitted in September, had been a "clean, unqualified opinion," which present
fairly the financial position of the University, as well as each of its constituent organizations (the Hospitals, Dental Faculty Associates, M-Care, Veritas) and
closely aligned organizations (the Alumni Association, the University Musical Society, and the William Davidson Institute).
Regarding the report on procedures and controls, Mr. Emde stated that
these were found to be working very efficiently, with no material weaknesses. He
noted that the University concurs with each of the recommendations in the management letter and has taken steps to implement them.
Mr. Emde observed that his firm continues to receive excellent cooperation
in performing its audit. He then responded to questions from the Regents and
noted that Ernst & Young would not hesitate to bring to the attention of the Regents any matters that would be of concern.
1994-95 State Budget Request
Ann Arbor Campus. President Duderstadt called on Provost Whitaker to
present the budget request for the Ann Arbor campus. Provost Whitaker observed that there had been no increase in the state appropriation for the past two
years, which had led to an increasing reliance on tuition to make up the General
Fund budget. The state appropriation currently comprises 37 percent of this
budget, while tuition makes up 52 percent. Provost Whitaker pointed out that as
tuition increases, the cost of maintaining access also rises; therefore, increased
state support is essential to the University's ability to maintain access.
Given the state's financial situation, only a modest increase in state appropriation is proposed, consisting of $10.1 million as an inflation component (3.7
percent), $1.7 million for operating costs of facilities openings for FY95; and $3.5
million for maintenance improvement, for a total requested increase of $15.3
million.
UM-Flint Campus, Chancellor Jones observed that the UM-Flint budget
was derived from two revenue streams: state appropriation and tuition and fees.
The continuing decline in state support has led to increased reliance on tuition
and fees, and the difficulty this creates for students is of great concern.


94




October Meeting, 1993


Enrollment growth has stabilized because of lack of funds for hiring more filltime faculty to teach more class sections.
The incremental budget request of 6.7 percent ($2,250,000) over the 1993-94
appropriation includes, in order of priority, $500,000 for facilities openings; a 3.7
percent inflationary increase for both salaries and operating expenses
($1,250,000); and $500,000 for various program initiatives.
UM-Dearbon. Following some discussion, President Duderstadt called on
Chancellor Renick to present the 1994-95 UM-Dearbor budget request. Chancellor Renick stated that the funding situation at UM-Dearborn is similar to that
of the other two campuses. The 1994-95 incremental budget request of
$1,684,000 reflects two priorities: an inflation component of 3.7 percent for
maintenance of quality educational programming, and $1,000,000 for the Center
for Environmental Education.
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved the 1994-95 state budget requests for all three campuses.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Consideration of the minutes of the September 1993 meeting was
deferred until the following month.
Reports. The following reports were submitted to the Regents: reports of
investments, plant extension, litigation, personnel-labor relations, noncompetitive purchases over $2,000 from single sources, projects established, and summaries of a selection of current research.
Executive Vice President Womack observed that treasury bond interest
rates are currently at record-low levels and described the implications of that on
the economy and the University's investment portfolio. He also reported that the
University's equity managers have exceeded performance guidelines for one-year
and three-year periods. He commented on the University's strategy for diversification of investments and the effects of the strategy on performance and
volatility.
Executive Vice President Womack also announced that in the near future he
would be presenting the Regents with a proposal designed to enhance investment
returns of the investment pool through longer term investments of the core portion of the pool.
Investments in South Africa. Following some discussion of the investment report, Regent Power observed that negotiations toward racial power sharing now taking place in South Africa had led to a request by Mr. Nelson Mandela
for an end to the economic boycott of South Africa, and that President Clinton
had recently issued an executive order changing American policy. Regent Power
stated that it may be time for the University of Michigan, prudently and deliberately, to consider its options with regard to its current investment policy of avoiding investing in corporations which do business in South Africa. He moved that
the administration report back to the Board of Regents its recommendations as


95




October Meeting, 1993


to this policy and other policies directed toward investments in corporations conducting business activities in South Africa. Regent Varner seconded the motion.
Regent Baker observed that there was a state law prohibiting the University from   changing its current investment policy in South Africa. Regent Power
reported that legislation recently had been proposed in the state legislature to
change the state's position on investing in South Africa and also pointed out that
this was an autonomy issue that should be considered independent of the state's
position on the issue.
Regent Baker commented that the University had prevailed in the Court of
Appeals on the autonomy issue, and that although he thought the motion tended
toward grandstanding, he was in favor of it.
The vote was then taken, and the motion was approved unanimously.
Consent Agenda, continued
Investment Report. Regent Baker asked for a report on the endowment
which would disclose gifts and transfers as well as appreciation. The Regents
complimented Executive Vice President Womack and his staff on their competent management of the University's endowment find.
Voluntary Support. Vice President Cosovich presented the report of voluntary support.
