Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted the following retirement memoirs:
Jesse E. Gordon, professor of social work in the School of Social Work and
professor of psychology in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired
from active faculty status on May 31, 1993, after 34 years of service to the University of Michigan.
Professor Gordon obtained his B.S. degree from New York University in
1950, his M.A degree from New York University in 1951, and his Ph.D. degree in
psychology from Pennsylvania State University in 1956. After applying his psychology education in a variety of arenas, he joined the faculty of the Department
of Psychology in 1959 as an assistant professor. In 1964, he was appointed associate professor of social work and associate professor of psychology; he was promoted to professor of social work and professor of psychology in 1966.
One of the school's leading instructors in the area of research, Professor
Gordon played a major role in the integration of research and clinical practice.
His expertise was shared with the U.S. Department of Labor for many years, first
in establishing selection, assessment, and training procedures for the Youth
Opportunity Program, and then as head of a social service organization in which
social science knowledge was to be applied to the development of training materials for employment agency personnel. While at the University and School of Social Work, Professor Gordon served on numerous committees to which he was
elected by his colleagues. His knowledge of funding sources and grantmanship
led to securing research grants and contracts for the University community.
Included in Professor Gordon's extensive publication record is the college-level
text Personality and Behavior. His retirement marks the departure of an
outstanding member of the faculty of the School of Social Work and leader of the
University community.


107




October Meeting, 1993


The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Jesse E. Gordon
professor emeritus of social work and professor emeritus of psychology.
E. Lawrence McMahon, associate professor of electrical engineering and
computer science, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1993, after 34
years of service.
Professor McMahon earned his B.S. degree (electrical engineering) from
Fournier Institute in Lamont, Illinois, in 1952, and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees
from the University of Illinois in 1953 and 1955, respectively. After graduation,
Professor McMahon served as a research engineer at Hughes Aircraft Corporation from 1955-56 and as an assistant professor at Michigan State University
from 1956-59. He joined the University of Michigan as an assistant professor in
the Department of Electrical Engineering in 1959 and was promoted to associate
professor in 1963.
From the time he joined the University of Michigan faculty, Professor
McMahon was highly dedicated to students. From 1965-69, he administered the
department's graduate fellowship program. He then assisted in the coordination
of the graduate admissions program. Professor McMahon has made many contributions to the department's instructional programs, both in teaching and in new
course development. These contributions were recognized in 1982 when he received the Eta Kappa Nu Faculty Award for outstanding performance in teaching and student-faculty relations. Professor McMahon has served on both
departmental and College of Engineering curriculum committees. He has also
been active in advising both graduate and undergraduate students and has provided invaluable service as a counselor for undergraduate electrical engineering
students.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his many years of service
by naming E. Lawrence McMahon associate professor emeritus of electrical engineering and computer science.
Bernard Van't Hul, associate professor of English language and literature, will retire from active faculty status on October 31, 1993, following 23 years
of service.
A native of Rock Valley, Iowa, Professor Van't Hul attended Calvin College
in Grand Rapids from which he received his B.A degree in 1959. Dutch was the
language of his home, and his military service in Europe honed his fluency in
German. As an undergraduate, he deepened his knowledge of languages, particularly those bearing on medieval Europe. He continued his studies at Northwestern University where he received his M.A degree in 1961 and his Ph.D. degree in
1971. While completing his doctoral work, he held a faculty position at Calvin
College and, in 1969, he joined the University of Michigan faculty with a joint appointment in the Department of English and the Middle English Dictionary. He
was promoted to associate professor in 1972.
Lexicography requires the exacting attention to detail which has been a hallmark of Professor Van't Hul's teaching and scholarship, and his contributions to
the Middle English Dictionary added to the excellence of this monumental work.
At the same time, he was drawn to public service through a concern for the
teaching of English in Michigan schools. One of the founding activists in the


108




October Meeting, 1993


creation of the English Composition Board, he led workshops and in-service programs for teachers in more than 300 Michigan schools. With his colleague, Jay L.
Robinson, he created a set of middle school textbooks designed to introduce students to the study of the English language. In recent years, his undergraduate
teaching has pioneered the use of computer conferencing to engage each student
in the minute study of literary texts.
Professor Van't Hul has been recognized for excellence throughout his academic career. At the beginning of his graduate studies, he was a Woodrow Wilson
Fellow; at Calvin College, he was named to a Danforth Fellowship; and, in 1981,
he received the Faculty Recognition Award at the University of Michigan.
The Regents now honor this faculty member by naming Bernard Van't Hul
associate professor emeritus of English language and literature.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved the remainder of the consent agenda as listed above.
University of Michigan Financial Report and Audited Financial Statements for the Alumni Association for the Year Ended June 30, 1993
Executive Vice President Womack submitted the University of Michigan Financial Report and Audited Financial Statements for the Alumni Association for
the Year Ended June 30, 1993.
Easement at 1327 Geddes
Executive Vice President Womack noted that the Regents Communication
responds to the Regents' previous question about the use the property owner
intended to make of the property. Regent Baker commented that if the owner of
the property, Mr. Stegeman, ever abandons the idea of building a house on the
property, it would be in the University's interest to obtain the property. He also
noted that the site is currently used as a storage area for trash and is rather
unsightly.
Regent Power moved authorization for the execution of an agreement with
John C. Stegeman and Lois U. Stegeman stating that the University will vacate
the common driveway easement at 1327 Geddes, as described in the Regents
Communication. Regent McGowan said that she would abstain from voting on
this item due to a conflict of interest. The vote was then taken, and the motion
was approved, with Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, Power, Varner, and
Waters in favor, and Regent McGowan abstaining.
Agreement between the University of Michigan and Global Rivers
Environmental Education Network (GREEN)
Regent Waters moved, Regent Varner seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, an agreement between the University of Michigan and the
Global Rivers Environmental Education Network (GREEN), a non-profit


109




October Meeting, 1993


corporation. Because two members of the board of directors of GREEN, William
Stapp and Orin Gelderloos, are also University employees, this agreement falls
under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and
Global Rivers Environmental Education Network (GREEN).
2.   At the request of General Motors, the University will transfer $110,000 to
GREEN from its General Motors Foundation grant. The University expects to
issue subcontracts to GREEN under two federally-funded projects: National
Consortium for Environmental Education and Training, about $25,000 for one
year, and National Science Foundation, about $440,000 over two years. Terms
of these agreements will be consistent with University policy and with the requirements of the prime funding agencies.
3.   Neither Dr. Stapp nor Dr. Gelderloos have a proprietary interest in GREEN.
Dr. Stapp will receive nominal compensation of up to $5,000 from GREEN for
his role as honorary director. Dr. Gelderloos will receive no compensation from
GREEN.
Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and
a Partnership owned in part by University Employees (Koren, Levine,
and Bell)
Regent Waters moved, Regent Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved the University's entering into a license agreement with a partnership owned in part by University employees Yoram Koren, Simon Levine,
and David Bell. These employees, along with Lon Bell, a person not employed at
the University, have developed a technology known as "Human Disturbance
Modeling for Adaptive Control of Human-Machine Systems" (the "Technology"),
and have also formed a partnership with the goal of developing products and
services which use the Technology. Because Messrs. Koren, Levine, and David
Bell are University employees and also have ownership interest in the partnership, this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory
requirements:
1.   Parties to the contract will be the University of Michigan and a partnership,
owned in part by Messrs. Koren, Levine, and David Bell.
2.   Terms of the contract include: a duration of the term of the last to expire of
any patents, and consideration to the University consisting of the payment of
royalties, including modest minimum annual requirements, on products covered by patents on the Technology; a share of sublicensing revenues received by
the partnership; and reimbursement of future University patent filing and
prosecution costs for the Technology, if applicable. The partnership will pay the
University royalties at a rate of 2.0 percent for products sold. The partnership
will also pay the University 15.0 percent of any sublicensing revenues the partnership receives. Minimum royalties shall commence in 1994 at $500 for the
first year, $1,000 for the second year, $3,000 for the third year, and $6,000 for
each year thereafter. The University retains ownership of all Technology. The
University retains the right to use the Technology for research, teaching and
other educationally-related purposes. The partnership shall diligently pursue
the commercial development and exploitation of the Technology covered by the
proposed license agreement. There is no use of facilities or services of the University included in the contract and no assignment of University employees for
fulfillment of the contract.


110




October Meeting, 1993


3.   The pecuniary interest of David Bell and Professors Koren and Levine in the
contract arises from their ownership of interests in the partnership. This equity
interest (as well as the equity interest of Lon Bell) will be in lieu of participation
in the sharing of royalties received by the University, in accordance with standard University policy.
Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities
Vice President Hartford submitted the second quarterly report of the Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities.
Revision of Regents' Bylaw Section 13.04 (University of Michigan
Alumni Association)
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Baker, the Regents
unanimously approved revisions to Regents' Bylaw Section 13.04, regarding the
University of Michigan Alumni Association. The following is the text of the revised bylaw:
Sec. 13.04. University of Michigan Alumni Association
The Alumni Association of the University of Michigan shall be an independent
and self-governing body governed by a board of directors to be selected in accordance
with the bylaws of the association. Between meetings of the board of directors, the affairs of the association shall be in the charge of an executive committee which shall
consist of the president of the association and at least four other members of the board
of directors, to be elected annually by the board of directors. The executive committee
shall exercise the powers of the board of directors while the board is not in session, and
shall exercise such other powers as are herein conferred upon it, or may from time to
time be delegated by the board of directors.
The Business and Financial Affairs Committee shall consist of the president of
the Alumni Association, ex officio; the treasurer of the association, ex officio; the president of the University, ex officio; the vice president for development and communication, ex officio; the vice president and chief financial officer, ex officio; two directors of
the association; one member of the administrative staff of the University and two members of the faculty of the University, these last three of whom shall be alumni, to be
elected by the board of directors annually, subject to confirmation of the Regents. The
Business and Financial Affairs Committee shall approve the budget of the association
and thereby authorize expenditures and shall secure an audit of the books and the accounts of the association.
The treasurer of the association shall be elected by the board of directors for a
term of two years and shall be an alumnus of the University. The treasurer shall supervise the accounts of the association and control its monies or funds held in trust by it
and shall make such reports showing the financial condition of the association as may
be required by the board of directors or the Business and Financial Affairs Committee.
The treasurer shall exercise the usual powers of the office of treasurer, shall furnish
adequate bond, and shall perform such other duties as may be delegated to the treasurer by the Business and Financial Affairs Committee.
Academic Calendar Revision for University of Michigan-Flint
On a motion by Regent McGowan, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
unanimously approved a revision of the academic calendar for UM-Flint for the
winter 1994 term.


111




October Meeting, 1993


Horace H. Rackham Memorial Building in Detroit
Executive Vice President Womack called on Professor Harold Johnson to describe the actions requested with respect to the Horace H. Rackham Memorial
Building. Professor Johnson reported that a committee of active members of the
community had been formed to guide the University as to how the building related to the University's mission in Detroit. The consensus was that because the
building was not suited to the University's activities and people were not making
use of it, it should not be considered as a factor in shaping future University activities in the community. The committee recommended that whatever actions
were taken be done in cooperation with the Engineering Society of Detroit, and
that whatever was done ought to enhance the cultural area.
As described in the Regents Communication, the building needs to be
brought into compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, which will cost
between $1-2 million, and to be made functional, at a cost of $5-6 million. Professor Johnson stated that Wayne State University is extremely interested in the facility and has the resources to make the improvements that would be necessary
to utilize it. The University has invited the Engineering Society to convey its
share of the building to the University, which would in turn lease the entire facility to Wayne State. At the end of the proposed 25-year lease period, the University would retain control over the entire facility if it decided to use it for some
other purpose.
Regent Varner expressed the hope that if the proposed arrangement is consummated, some priority be given on the use of the funds for the University's
programmatic initiatives in Detroit. She also recommended that the University
increase its public relations efforts to inform people in that community of the
University's activities. Professor Johnson responded that a report of University
activities in the Detroit area was scheduled to be issued in the near future.
Regent Deitch stated that he supports the arrangement, but that this support is predicated on the University's retaining control of the property at the end
of the 25-year period.
In response to a question from Regent Baker, Professor Johnson stated that
the parcel of land that may be conveyed or leased to the Engineering Society, as
described in the Regents Communication, would probably be in the Ann Arbor
area. He also responded to a question from Regent Baker about the Engineering
Society trust fund; Regent Baker pointed out that the Engineering Society has an
ongoing obligation with respect to the trust fund.
Vice President Harrison reiterated that he and Professor Johnson had been
charged with developing a direction in which to proceed for the use of this building, and that once that has been approved, Executive Vice President Womack's
staff would be in charge of working out the details.
In response to a comment from Regent Power, Chancellor Renick stated
that this action will have no effect at all on the Dearborn campus's programming
in Detroit. He recommended that UM-Dearborn's role in the region be considered as the University makes plans for increasing its presence in Detroit.


112




October Meeting, 1993


Following further discussion, Regent Waters moved authorization to negotiate a lease of the Horace H. Rackham Educational Memorial Building and the
parking structure to Wayne State University in consideration of Wayne State
University's assumption of both the responsibilities concerning the educational
activities taking place and the renovation costs necessary to meet the deferred
maintenance requirements and the Americans with Disabilities Act and other required code upgrades within the leased space, with such lease to occur after
Michigan attorney general and judicial approval are obtained. Regent McFee seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
There followed a 30-minute break, from 10:30 to 11:00 am.
Public Comments
The Regents heard comments from Marcia Federbush, citizen, on the men's
gymnastics program, and Tim Retzloff, UM-Flint staff member and student, in
support of the recent amendment to Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06. They also
heard comments from the following individuals in praise of Chancellor Jones'
service at UM-Flint: Allen D. Arnold, president of Mott Community College;
Sixto C. Olivo, member of the UM-Flint Citizens Advisory Committee; Roberto
Quiroz, director of bilingual education for the Flint Public Schools and board
member of the Spanish Speaking Information Center; Bobbie Ewing, president
of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Flint Alumnae Chapter; Representative Floyd
Clack; James B. Franklin III, president of the Black Panhellenic Council of Flint;
Olive R. Beasley, citizen; and David Ready, Flint city administrator, on behalf of
the mayor of Flint.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned at 11:40 a.m.
The next meeting will be held on November 18 and 19, 1993. Regents' expenses
for the month of September 1993 totalled $169.20.

NOVEMBER MEETING, 1993


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, November 18, 1993
The Regents assembled at 4:00 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan
Union. Present were President Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch,
McFee, McGowan, and Power. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy was also
present, as were Provost Whitaker, Executive Vice President Womack, and Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal. Regents Varner and Waters
and Chancellors Jones and Renick were absent.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Regent
Brown, who made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Section 8(e) of the Open Meetings Act, as amended
by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed
session on November 18, 1993, in the Regents' Room, immediately
following Public Comments, for the purpose of consulting with our
attorney regarding trial or settlement strategy in connection with
specific pending litigation.
Regent McFee seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.

gymnastics program; Scott Greenwood, political science student, on the decision
not to grant tenure to Jill Crystal; John Humphrey, faculty member, on administrative salary increases; Benjamin Bolger, student, on quality and accessibility of
undergraduate education; and Loretta Lee, student, on the Campus Sexual
Assault Victim's Bill of Rights.

in the Regents' Room.
Friday, November 19, 1993

Varner, and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, Provost Whitaker,

Consent Agenda
September 1993 minutes. President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called for a motion to approve the minutes of the September 1993 meeting. Regent Power moved approval of the minutes of the original draft of the
minutes of the meeting of September 23-24, 1993, and Regent Waters seconded
the motion. Regent Power noted that the original version of the minutes was an
accurate summary of the discussion that occurred at that meeting. Regent Baker
disagreed, suggesting that not including a more complete version of his comments reflected inappropriate judgments with regard to freedom of speech and
freedom of discussion. Regent Brown pointed out that the Regents' policy is to
include sunmaries of people's statements, and that Regents' verbatim statements are included in a permanent file in the secretary's office. Following further
discussion, the vote was taken and the original version of the minutes of the
September 1993 meeting was approved, with Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee,
McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters in favor and Regent Baker opposed.

the recommendation of M. Joseph Roberson as athletic director be changed to an
affirmative vote. Following some discussion, it was determined that a vote cannot
be changed once it has been made and recorded.
Report of Senate      Advisory   Committee    on  University   Affairs
(SACUA)
President Duderstadt introduced Professor Henry Griffin, chair of SACUA,
to present the report. Professor Griffin reported that SACUA's three major
concerns for the current year are grievance procedures, considerations of faculty
governance (a self-examination), and the diversity of faculty contributions to the
University's teaching and research functions. He described how faculty governance is structured, and then called on Jayne Thorson, executive assistant to
SACUA, who described the structure, function, and activities of the faculty senate office.
Professor Griffin then reported on SACUA's progress with respect to the
evaluation of the offices of the executive officers and deans, and in providing a
means for informal dispute resolution for faculty members. He also noted that
SACUA intends to undertake a study of the effectiveness of faculty governance.


116




November Meeting, 1993


Compliance with the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA)
Judith Nowack, assistant vice president for research, and John O'Shea, professor of anthropology and director of the Museum of Anthropology, presented a
report describing the University's efforts to comply with the Native American
Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA). NAGPRA is a law requiring
universities and museums that receive federal funds to first summarize or inventory, then return to Native American groups, upon request, human remains and
certain cultural objects shown to be affiliated with each Native American group.
Professor O'Shea reported that 324 objects in the Museum of Anthropology
came under the purview of NAGPRA, and that each tribe associated with each
object has been notified of its existence. At this time, no objects have been repatriated; nor have any claims been received. The action requested gives the University the freedom to negotiate with Native American groups, on an individual
basis, about possible long-term curation or other disposition of their materials.
The goal is to maintain the future accessibility of these materials for study.
Regent McGowan moved to authorize University officials to pursue negotiations with relevant Native American groups and ultimately to repatriate any of
those items and human remains which are both shown by its inquiries to be
"affiliated" and, at the end of the negotiation, requested by the Native American
group with which the affiliation exists. Regent Power seconded the motion, and it
was approved unanimously.
There followed some comments by the Regents, after which they returned
to the regular agenda.
Consent Agenda, continued

litigation, and personnel-labor relations. Vice President Neal submitted reports
of projects established and summaries of a selection of current research.

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted the following retirement memoirs:
Mara Julius, assistant research scientist in the Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1993,
after 23 years of service.


125




November Meeting, 1993


Dr. Julius earned her B.A degree in 1953, her M.S. degree in 1977, and her
Sc.D. degree in 1979, all from the University of Zagreb in Yugoslavia She first
came to the University of Michigan in 1960 as a visiting scholar at the Institute
for Social Research. From 1964-68, she was a teaching fellow and research assistant in the Department of Psychology. She joined the Department of Epidemiology in the School of Public Health in 1970 and held positions as research
associate, lecturer, and research investigator until 1986, when she was promoted
to the position of assistant research scientist.
In the Department of Epidemiology, Dr. Julius was responsible for the
psychosocial program for the Tecumseh Community Health Study, lectures in
the field of social epidemiology, research in areas of gender and ethnic differences
in health, and the impact of social support on the physical health in the elderly.
Her publications reflect a deep and continuing interest in the psychosocial risk
factors that influence the health of the elderly and their health behavior, the
family environment, and temporality in late life. Recently, her research has
centered around life events, suppressed anger, blood pressure as predictors of
mortality, and blood gluthathione as an indication of health status. Dr. Julius
served on various departmental committees, participated fully in departmental
and school affairs, and belonged to at least six professional organizations whose
activities were integral to her research and service interests.
Dr. Julius' career has been characterized by dedication to the social causes
she espoused, by psychobiological research aimed at improving the health of the
elderly, and by exemplary adherence to the highest ethical standards. The products of her research always exceeded the expectations of whatever multidisciplinary groups she worked with. Throughout her career, she earned the respect and
affection of her colleagues and students.
The Regents now salute this scientist for her dedicated service by naming
Mara Julius assistant research scientist emerita.
Dorothy A. Lee, professor of English and comparative literature at the
University of Michigan-Dearborn, will retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1993.
Professor Lee received her B.A and M.A degrees from Wayne State University in 1945 and 1947, respectively. She then pursued graduate studies at
Radcliffe College, where she received a second M.A degree in 1948. She received
her Ph.D. degree from Radcliffe College and Harvard University in 1955. After
teaching at Wayne State University and Henry Ford Community College, Professor Lee joined the University of Michigan-Dearborn as an assistant professor of
comparative literature in 1972. She was promoted to associate professor in 1974
and to professor in 1978.
A very active faculty member who has contributed to all aspects of university life, Professor Lee is held in very high esteem by her faculty colleagues. She
was instrumental in establishing the Dearborn campus' comparative literature
program and developed and taught a wide variety of courses ranging from
African-American literature to Western world literature. She is perhaps best
known, however, for her course on myth and motif in literature. Through the
years, the outstanding student evaluations for this course have attested to
Professor Lee's reputation as an excellent instructor.


126




November Meeting, 1993


In addition to her excellence as a teacher, Professor Lee has also established
herself as a scholar. She has given numerous presentations at conferences in her
field and has authored publications on figures and topics as varied as James
Baldwin, African-American drama, Miguel de Unamuno, Harriet Arnow, and
Toni Morrison. In recognition of her outstanding attributes as a faculty member,
Professor Lee was awarded the University of Michigan-Dearborn's Distinguished
Teaching Award and Women's Commission Susan B. Anthony Award in 1985,
and the Michigan Association of Governing Boards of Colleges and Universities'
Distinguished Faculty Award in 1987.
The Regents now salute this teacher-scholar for her dedicated service by
naming Dorothy A Lee professor emerita of English and comparative literature.
Theophilus S. Lynch, professor of Spanish and comparative literature at
the University of Michigan-Flint, retired from active faculty status on May 31,
1993, after a most productive career as a teacher, advisor, and department leader.
Professor Lynch received his B.A degree from Williams College in 1947,
following distinguished service in the Pacific theater of action during World War
II. He then went on to receive his M.A and Ph.D. degrees from the University of
Pennsylvania in 1951 and 1959, respectively. Professor Lynch taught at Rutgers
University and Ohio University prior to joining UM-Flint in 1966 as an associate
professor without tenure. He was awarded tenure in 1968 and was promoted to
fill professor in 1972.
A knowledgeable and caring teacher, Professor Lynch has had a following of
devoted students throughout his long career at the University. At the time of his
arrival on the Flint campus, the foreign language department had no faculty in
Spanish. Professor Lynch was responsible for founding the campus' program in
Spanish, which is currently the most popular language program at UM-Flint.
This popularity is in no small measure attributable to his wisdom, dedication,
and skill. After founding the Spanish program, Professor Lynch demonstrated an
astonishing versatility by offering classes in Portuguese and Latin. A respected
scholar in Spanish and Portuguese literature, Professor Lynch has always carried
his learning and his dedication into the classroom, along with a characteristic
touch of humor. He has been an inspiration to his students and a source of
strength to his colleagues in the college.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Theophilus S. Lynch professor emeritus of Spanish and
comparative literature.
Henryk Skolimowski, professor of humanities in the College of Engineering, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1993.
Born in Poland, Professor Skolimowski attended the Warsaw College of
Music from 1948-52. He received his M.Sc. degree from the Warsaw Institute of
Technology in 1956, his M.A degree from the University of Warsaw in 1959, and
his Ph.D. degree from Oxford University in 1964. From 1964-70, Professor Skolimowski taught at the University of Southern California. He joined the University
of Michigan as a visiting associate professor in the College of Engineering's Department of Humanities in 1970. He was promoted to professor in 1972 and
achieved tenure in 1974.


127




November Meeting, 1993


Throughout his tenure at the University of Michigan, Professor Skolimowski has pursued his study of ecological humanism and eco-philosophy. He
has also held visiting professorships at Madras University in India; the California
Institute of Integral Studies in San Francisco; and the University of Warsaw in
Poland.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his many years of dedicated
service by naming Henry Skolimowski professor emeritus of humanities.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.

University.

Executive officer salaries. Regent Baker commented that he disagreed
with the salary levels of some of the executive officers; he pointed out that these
salaries are not set by the Regents. Regent Deitch responded that he believes the
salary levels set for the executive officers are appropriate, and that it was injurious to the officers to state that he disagreed with some of the salaries for particular officers.

University of Michigan 1993 Financial Report Supplemental Schedules
for Year Ended June 30, 1993

Supplemental Schedules for the Year Ended June 30, 1993.
Six Month Report on University Audits
Executive Vice President Womack submitted the Six Month Report on
University Audits for the period April 1, 1993, through September 30, 1993.
University Real Estate
Executive Vice President Womack submitted a proposed policy regarding
acceptance of gifts of real estate. The policy would require a phase I
environmental assessment. The acceptance of a gift of real estate would then be
subject to: the donor's indemnifying the University for any liability arising out of
violation or noncompliance with environmental law or the presence of


128




November Meeting, 1993


environmental contamination, and providing a confession of judgment stating
that if the donor breaches any of the warranties in the indemnification agreement the donor would have authorized the University to enter a judgment
against the donor to rescind the transfer so that the University is removed from
the chain of title. The Regents Communication also requests certain amendments to Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07.
Executive Vice President Womack described the recent history of properties
that have been donated to the University, noting that the average holding period
of properties that have been sold is nine years, with an average holding period for
all unsold properties of twelve years. The properties that have been sold have
totalled $1 million, with expenses for holding those properties being $350,000.
Sixty percent of the total amount of property sold was derived from four
properties.
Executive Vice President Womack stated that the University did not intend
to dissuade donors from giving valuable properties to the institution. However, it
is often the case that real estate donated to the University is not very valuable.
The proposed policy yields maximum protection to the University.
Vice President Cosovich said that the development office had helped develop
the proposed policy and was in support of it. He noted that the University does
not actively seek gifts of real estate, and such gifts do not constitute a large
component of development activity.
In the discussion that followed, the Regents expressed concern over the
attempt to protect the University from liability versus creating a disincentive for
people to donate real estate. Particular concern was directed toward the "confession of judgment" provision, with Regents Power, Deitch, and Brown noting that
this could be viewed as a "donor-unfriendly" requirement that would constitute a
disincentive to donate. Regent Deitch suggested as an alternative that a deed be
placed in escrow at the time a gift is made.
Executive Vice President Womack responded that this would not solve the
problem of removing the University from the chain of title. Regent McFee stated
that the intent of the proposal, to protect the University from liability, was of
critical importance. Regent Brown expressed support for Regent Deitch's suggestion of placing a deed in escrow back to the donor, but also expressed doubt that
either a confession of judgment or a deed in escrow would totally protect the
University from liability for environmental contamination.
In response to other comments, Executive Vice President Womack pointed
out that most of the real estate donated to the University consists of vacant lots
and some residences, and the University must expend resources to cary that
property until it is sold. He also noted that the proposed policy specifically
exempts property considered for academic and research programs of the
University.
President Duderstadt suggested that the Regents consider moving forward
with the phase I environmental assessment provisions, with the understanding


129




November Meeting, 1993


that University officials exercise judgment in enforcing the confession of judgment provision.
Regent Deitch stated that the discussion had convinced him that there is
nothing wrong with the University's saying that there are certain types of gifts
that it really doesn't want. The confession of judgment makes the indemnity
stronger and helps to discourage this type of giving. He moved that the policy be
adopted with the understanding that if, in a particular circumstance, it is felt
that there is good cause for a waiver, that can be recommended to the Board.
Regent Brown seconded the motion, but suggested that language of exception be written into the policy. Regent Deitch expressed agreement with that
suggestion; Executive Vice President Womack suggested the motion be voted on
with the understanding that such language would thereafter be drafted that
would accommodate the discussion.
In response to a question from Regent Baker about the tax consequences for
the donor when a gift is accepted conditionally, Executive Vice President
Womack stated that this issue would be considered in the additional language to
be drafted.
There being no further discussion, the vote was taken, and the following
motion was approved unanimously, with the understanding that the additional
language outlined in the discussion will be incorporated and brought back to the
Regents, and that the bylaw revision will be subject to the normal bylaw revision
procedures:
Modifications to Real Estate Policy
Prior to accepting a gift of real estate, the University will require the
donor to provide a Phase I environmental assessment;
*   If the property is environmentally acceptable, the donor will be
required to execute an Agreement to Indemnify and a Confession of
Judgment, except for residential properties, in which case the
University may, under appropriate circumstances, decide not to
require a Confession of Judgment;
The donor will agree to pay all expenses associated with the land
including taxes and assessments until the property is sold. (Property
in the state of Michigan will be removed from the tax rolls in the
year following the gift.)
Bylaw Sec. 3.07, subsections la. and lb., as revised (additions underlined)
a.  All sales of donated or bequeathed real estate located outside the Ann Arbor,
Dearborn, or Flint campus areas regardless of the sales price; real estate that
funds a Unitrust for any amount or location; and bequeathed or devised real
property requiring action by an estate executor, personal representative or trustee
may be approved and authorized by the executive vice president and chief financial officer.dllfThe resulting land contracts and deeds will be executed by both


130




November Meeting, 1993


the president and the executive vice president and chief financial officer. These
transactions will be reported to the Regents in an item for information.
b.   Any sale authorized by the executive vice president and chief financial officer
must equal or exceed the appraised value except for fractional interest estate
1Qproperties. For those properties held in an estate in which the University's interest is fractional, the University will cooperate with the estate's legally appointed representative regarding terms and appraisal requirements to
accomplish a sale.
Donor Pooled Income Fund
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
voted unanimously to adopt the following resolution, which authorizes changes
in the trusteeship and investment management of the Donor Pooled Income
Fund and appointment of a custodian of the Donor Pooled Income Fund's assets.
RESOLUTION TO CHANGE THE SUCCESSOR TRUSTEE AND
INVESTMENT MANAGER OF THE DONOR POOLED INCOME FUND
AND TO AMEND THE DECLARATION OF TRUST
OF THE DONOR POOLED INCOME FUND
WHEREAS, NBD Bank, NA was appointed by the Regents of the University of Michigan
as successor trustee of the Donor Pooled Income Fund upon its creation in 1975, and now wishes
to resign as successor trustee;
WHEREAS, under the Declaration of Trust of the Donor Pooled Income Fund, the
Regents of the University of Michigan have retained authority to remove and appoint a
replacement successor trustee;
WHEREAS, subject to confirmation by the Probate Court of the resignation of NBD
Bank, NA and the University's acceptance of the bank's resignation; and,
WHEREAS, subject to confirmation by the Probate Court of the Regents' exercise of their
reserved power to appoint a replacement successor trustee;
NOW THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the Regents of the University of Michigan hereby authorize, approve, and direct the following:
1.   Acceptance of the resignation of NBD Bank, NA, as successor trustee;
2.   Appointment of the Regents of the University of Michigan to be successor
trustee, in exercise of their authority reserved in Article 2.1 of the Declaration
of Trust of the Donor Pooled Income Fund;
3.   Appointment of NBD Bank, NA as investment manager of the Donor Pooled
Income Fund;
4.   All actions necessary by the appropriate University executive officers to make
and execute amendments of the Declaration of Trust to appoint a custodian of
the Donor Pooled Income Fund.
Estate of Helen F. Weber-Real Estate
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved acceptance of the offer of St. John Real Estate Company
to purchase the NE 1/4 of the SW 1/4, the N 1/2 of the SE 1/4, and the SE 1/4 of


131




November Meeting, 1993


the SE 1/4, Section 34, T41N, R25W, Harris Township, Menominee County at a
price of $34,500, subject to the retention of the mineral rights by the University.
State Funded Capital Projects
This is a request for authorization to finance initial construction cash flow
requirements for two major projects to be financed by the State Building Authority (SBA)-the Integrated Technology Instruction Center (ITIC) and Central
Campus Renovations-through the issuance of bond anticipation notes secured
by a pledge of student fees.
Regent Brown moved the following: that the cash flow requirements, for up
to $12.0 million, be financed through the issuance of bond anticipation notes
which will mature no later than June 30, 1994. The bond anticipation notes will
ultimately be reimbursed from the SBA bond or note sale proceeds. The University believes that the SBA will be in a position to retire the University's bond
anticipation notes on a timely basis. In the unlikely event that the State/SBA are
not in a position to either retire the notes or provide for the balance of the
construction cash flow requirements, we will be obliged to return to the Regents
with an alternative financing plan which could include the issuance of renewed
notes or Student Fee Bonds which would be amortized over a period of up to
thirty years. As a final source of payment the University will covenant to use legally available funds to pay the principal and interest on the Notes. It is anticipated that the sale of the tax-exempt bond anticipation notes will be through a
public competitive bid process whereby the University will prepare and circulate
a preliminary official statement and a notice of sale requesting bids.
Regent Brown further moved adoption of a resolution (see Appendix A, page
137) that authorizes the executive vice president and chief financial officer to:
1. develop the terms and legal documentation for the Bond
Anticipation Notes, and to prepare, circulate and execute
preliminary and final official statements describing the Bond
Anticipation Notes, the University and its affairs; and
2.  apply for and obtain from   Moody's Investors Service and
Standard & Poor's Corporation their ratings on the Bond
Anticipation Notes; and
3.  publish a notice of sale, receive bids, award the Bond
Anticipation Notes to the winning bidder, execute an order
establishing the terms of notes, and execute and deliver the
notes.
Regent Varner seconded the motion. Regent Baker expressed concern that
the state will be able to follow through on its commitment to finance the projects.
In response, Vice President Kennedy stated that the State Building Authority
has given all necessary approvals; this action will merely use the University's
funds, rather than state ftinds, as cash flow to finance the early part of construction. It is anticipated that these funimds will be reimbursed by the SBA within the


132




November Meeting, 1993


first six months of 1994. Regent Baker observed that there is a high risk that the
state will not be able to follow through on this commitment.
Following further discussion, the vote was taken and the motion was
approved, with Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and
Waters in favor and Regent Baker opposed.
North Campus Bell Tower
Executive Vice President Womack reported that a potential donor has
expressed a strong interest in the construction of a bell tower to be sited
somewhere in the vicinity of the future North Campus diag.
In response to a comment from Regent Power, Executive Vice President
Womack stated that the Regents would have an opportunity to review the plans
for the structure before its construction. In response to a question from Regent
Deitch, Provost Whitaker reported that a bell tower was part of a much larger
gift and that the idea of a bell tower was very important to the donor.
Regent Baker asked for clarification as to whether the project was a carillon
or a bell tower. Provost Whitaker responded that it involves both the structure
(the bell tower) and the bells within the structure (the carillon). Regent Deitch
moved approval of initiating the design of a bell tower for North Campus and selecting Moore/Andersson Architects in conjunction with Hobbs + Black Associates, Inc., as the design architect. Regent McFee seconded the motion, and it was
approved unanimously.
Renovation/Construction Projects
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Baker, the Regents
unanimously approved replacement of the air handling unit at the University
Hospital Med Inn Building and construction of a Radrick Farms recreation
facility.
University of Michigan Hospitals Radiology Angiographic Equipment
Replacement and Renovations
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved purchase of three angiographic imaging systems and
completion of renovations for equipment installation in the Radiology
Department at University of Michigan Hospitals.
University of Michigan Hospitals Radiation Oncology Linear Accelerator Replacement
Regent Waters moved, Regent Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved submission of a Certificate of Need to the Michigan Department of Public Health for $2,266,800 to replace one of the linear accelerator
treatment machines in the Radiation Oncology Department.


133




November Meeting, 1993


University of Michigan Hospitals Supplemental Certificate of Need for
Patient Care Information System
Regent Deitch moved approval for submission of a supplemental Certificate
of Need to the Michigan Department of Public Health for a patient care information system, increasing the budget limit from $7 million to $30 million. Regent
Waters seconded the motion, and following some discussion about the specific
features of the technology, it was approved unanimously.
Restriction on Equity Investments in Companies Operating in
South Africa
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved adoption of the following resolution:
RESOLUTION REGARDING UNIVERSITY INVESTMENTS
IN ORGANIZATIONS OPERATING IN THE
REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA
WHEREAS the Regents have expressed repeatedly their conviction that the system of
apartheid and the oppressive practices of the government of the Republic of South Africa related
thereto are immoral and unconscionable; and
WHEREAS in March 1983 the Regents, acting in support of anti-apartheid efforts,
directed the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer to take prudent action to divest equity
investments in any organizations operating in the Republic of South Africa and to make no
further equity investments in such companies; and
WHEREAS Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, in an address to
the United Nations Special Committee Against Apartheid on September 4, 1993, called for an
end to economic sanctions, declaring, "To strengthen the forces of democratic change, and to
help create the necessary conditions for stability and social progress, we believe that the time has
come when the international community should lift all economic sanctions against South
Africa"; and
WHEREAS Mr. Mandela called for help in "halting the slide to a socioeconomic disaster in
South Africa," noting that millions of South Africans "have no food, no jobs, no homes"; and
WHEREAS Mr. Mandela made his statement the day after the Parliament of the Republic
of South Africa adopted a package of laws intended to provide Black citizens with a voice in the
government of their nation; and
WHEREAS President Clinton eliminated remaining U.S. trade sanctions and indicated
that his administration will encourage investment in South Africa, stating, "This call from this
courageous man who has been one of the principal victims of apartheid means that the leading
groups in South Africa now oppose the maintenance of economic sanctions on their country";
IT IS THEREFORE RESOLVED that the Board removes the investment restrictions
placed in resolutions adopted in March 1983 as modified in September 1985 and October 1988,
and directs the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer to take prudent action to
effect the change in investment policy.
Reassignment of University's Ownership Interest in Intellectual Property (Michael L. Boninger, M.D.)
Regent Brown moved, Regent Waters seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved a modified standard assignment agreement with Michael L.


134




November Meeting, 1993


Boninger, M.D., for the intellectual property "Fall Prevention Sock" (UM   File
No. 781). Because Dr. Boninger is both a party to the agreement and a University employee, this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Contract. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory
requirements:
1.   Parties to the assignment agreement(s) will be the University of Michigan and
Michael L. Boninger, M.D.
2.   Terms of the contract include: standard terms in accordance with those previously disclosed to and approved by the Regents on July 16, 1987, with the
following exceptions:
The first sentence of Paragraph 2c requiring the inventor to use due diligence
in pursuing a patent has been deleted. The inventor hopes to pursue a patent
and commercialize the invention through the University of Pittsburgh (see below) but cannot insure it.
The first sentence of paragraph 2d requiring the inventor to submit annual
reports of patenting and commercialization activity has also been deleted.
Pursuant to section 12, approval has been given to the inventor to assign his
interests in the invention to the University of Pittsburgh where he is now
employed.
3.   The pecuniary interests were previously disclosed to and approved by the
Regents on July 16, 1987, and are hereby incorporated by reference in this
action request.
Change in Name of Physics/Engineering Science Department at
UM-Flint
On a motion by Regent Deitch, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved changing the name of the Physics/Engineering Science
Department at UM-Flint to the Physics and Engineering Science Department.
Revision of Regents' Bylaws Concerning Titles of Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs and Executive Vice President
and Chief Financial Officer
Regent Deitch moved that all affected sections of the Regents' Bylaws in
which the titles "provost and vice president for academic affairs" and "vice president and chief financial officer" appear be amended to read "provost and executive vice president for academic affairs" and "executive vice president and chief
financial officer," respectively. Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was
approved unanimously.
Recommendations for Appointment to Medical Staff Membership
On the recommendation of the University of Michigan Hospitals executive
board Regent Brown moved, Regent Waters seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved several appointments to medical staff membership.

The next meeting will be held on December 16 and 17, 1993. Regents' expenses
for the month of October 1993 totalled $715.62.

136




NOVEMBER MEETING, 1993


APPENDIX A
RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND SALE OF BOND ANTICIPATION
NOTES IN THE PRINCIPAL AMOUNT OF NOT TO EXCEED $12,000,000
TO TEMPORARILY FINANCE PART OF THE COST OF ACQUISITION
CONSTRUCTION, RENOVATION AND EQUIPPING OF CERTAIN PROJECTS
AND RELATED COSTS, AND TO PROVIDE FOR THE PAYMENT OF THE
NOTES AND OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO.
WHEREAS, in the exercise of their constitutional duties and in order to properly serve the
needs of students attending The University of Michigan (the "University"), the Regents of the
University of Michigan (the "Issuer") has authorized the acquisition, construction and equipping
of an Integrated Technology Instruction Center and an Engineering Center, and the renovation
of C.C. Little and Angell Hall, each on the Ann Arbor Campus of the University (collectively, the
"Project"); and
WHEREAS, the State Building Authority has stated its intention to provide permanent financing for a portion of the costs of the Project; and
WHEREAS, in the exercise of their constitutional duties and in order to properly serve the
interests of students attending the University, and to prudently control and direct expenditures
of the University's funds the Issuer deems it necessary and advisable to issue its Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993 (hereinafter defined as the "Notes") in the principal amount of not to exceed Twelve Million Dollars ($12,000,000) for the purpose of temporarily financing part of the
cost of acquiring, constructing, renovating and equipping the Project, paying capitalized interest
on the Notes, and paying the expenses related thereto and incidental to the issuance of the Notes;
and
WHEREAS, the financing of the Project will serve proper and appropriate public purposes; and
WHEREAS, in order to market the Notes in the most economic manner it is necessary to
authorize the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, or the Associate Vice President for Finance (each an "Authorized Officer") to make determinations as to the terms of the
Notes, within the limits set forth herein; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has been created as a constitutional body corporate under the provisions of Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, and has full power under
its constitutional authority and supervision of the University, and control and direction of expenditures from the University funds, to acquire, construct, renovate and equip the Project, to pay
part of the cost thereof by issuance of the Notes;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:
ARTICLE I
DEFINITIONS
In addition to the terms defined in the preambles to the Resolution, the following terms
shall have, unless the context otherwise requires, the meanings herein specified:
"Governmental Obligations" means any of the following which at the time of investment
are legal investments for the moneys proposed to be invested therein: direct general obligations
of, or obligations the payment of the principal of and interest on which is unconditionally guaranteed by, the United States of America, or other obligations, including defeased tax-exempt securities and maturing interests in a trusteed fund or funds composed entirely of any of the


137




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


foregoing instruments, the timely payment of which is fiully secured by the payment of principal
and interest on direct general obligations of, or obligations the payment of principal of and interest on which is unconditionally guaranteed by, the United States of America.
"Investment Income" means and includes all interest or profit, when received, earned
through the investment or reinvestment of all moneys in the Note Fund.
"Issuer" means the Regents of the University of Michigan, a constitutional body corporate
having general supervision of the University and control and direction of all expenditures from
its funds.
"Legally Available Funds" means any moneys of the Issuer that may be legally used by the
Issuer to pay principal of and interest on the Notes, but shall not include any funds (a) currently
or subsequently pledged for, or committed to present or future loans, bonds or debt service on
other obligations, or other purposes to the extent so pledged or committed, or (b) the use of which
would result in the Notes herein authorized being construed as a general obligation of the Issuer
or as indebtedness of the State of Michigan under the Michigan Constitution of 1963.
"Note" or "Notes" means the Regents of the University of Michigan Bond Anticipation
Notes, Series 1993, to be issued under this Resolution in the aggregate principal amount of not to
exceed $12,000,000.
"Note Fund" means the University of Michigan Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993 Note
Fund established by Section 402 hereof.
"Noteholder" or "holder" (when used with reference to Notes) means the registered owner
of any Note.
"Note Payment Date" means the maturity date of the Notes which shall be established by
an Authorized Officer.
"Outstanding" or "Notes outstanding" means, as of any date, all Notes delivered under the
Resolution, except (i) Notes theretofore acquired by the Issuer and cancelled and (ii) Notes for
which the Issuer shall have made provision for payment in accordance with the Resolution by depositing with the Transfer Agent or other escrow agent cash or cash and Government Obligations, the principal of and interest on which when due will be sufficient to pay the principal of
and interest on said Notes as the same become due through maturity.
"Project" means the project referenced in the preambles hereto.
"Project Fund" means the University of Michigan Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993
Project Fund established by Section 401 hereof
"Resolution" means this resolution and any other resolutions amendatory or supplementary hereto in accordance with the terms hereof.
"Transfer Agent" means the Transfer Agent appointed by an Authorized Officer or any
successor Transfer Agent in accordance with the provisions of Section 301 or 308.
"University" means the University of Michigan.
ARTICLE II
NECESSITY FOR ISSUANCE OF NOTES
Section 201. Necessity for Issuance of the Notes. The Issuer, in the exercise of its
powers and authority relative to the general supervision of the University and control and direction of all expenditures from the University's funds, as provided in Article VIII, Section 5 of the
Michigan Constitution of 1963, hereby determines that the issuance of the Notes for the purposes
set forth in the preambles hereto is necessary and advisable in order to enable the Issuer to temporarily finance the cost of the acquisition, construction and equipping of the Project.


138




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


ARTICLE mI
THE NOTES
Section 301. Authorization of the Issuance of the Notes For the purposes set forth
in Article II, there shall be borrowed the sum of not to exceed Twelve Million Dollars
($12,000,000) as shall be determined by an Authorized Officer, and in evidence thereof there
shall be issued the Notes of the Issuer which shall be designated "Bond Anticipation Notes, Series
1993", in like aggregate principal amount. The Notes shall be sold, at a discount not exceeding
1% of the principal amount of the Notes, at public sale following publication of a notice of sale in
the form to be approved by an Authorized Officer, and shall be awarded to the winning bidder as
shall be determined by an Authorized Officer. The Notes shall bear such rate of interest as shall
be set forth in the winning bid, but the net interest cost for the Notes, taking into account the
rate and any discount or premium, shall not exceed 4% per annum. An Authorized Officer may
place additional limitations on the bids in the Notice of Sale and may determine to award the
Notes on the basis of either true interest cost or net interest cost.
The Notes shall be dated as of a date to be selected by an Authorized Officer, shall be payable from the sources as hereinafter set forth, shall be issued in fully-registered form in the denomination of $100,000 or integral multiples thereof and shall be numbered consecutively from 1
upwards. The Notes shall mature on the date specified by an Authorized Officer, but not later
than June 30, 1994.
The Notes shall bear interest payable on the maturity date. The principal amount of and
interest on each Note shall be payable in lawful money of the United States of America upon surrender of the Note at the principal corporate trust office of a bank or trust company designated
by the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer (the "Transfer Agent") in such coin
or currency of the United States of America as may be, on the respective dates of payment
thereof, legal tender for the payment of debts due the United States of America.
Section 302. Limited Obligation~ The Notes shall be limited obligations of the Issuer
payable solely from the sources of funds specified in Article VI, and the Notes shall not be a debt
or liability of the State of Michigan or a general obligation of the Issuer.
Section 303. Execution, Authentication and Delivery. The Notes shall be signed in
the name of and on behalf of the Issuer by facsimile signature of its Executive Vice President and
Chief Financial Officer or its Associate Vice President for Finance printed, lithographed or engraved thereon. No Note shall be valid until authenticated by an authorized officer or agent of
the Transfer Agent. The Notes, when executed and authenticated, shall be delivered by the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the Associate Vice President for Finance to
the purchaser thereof upon payment of the purchase price therefor determined pursuant to Section 1001 hereof. Executed blank Notes for registration of transfer shall be delivered to the
Transfer Agent for safekeeping concurrently with the delivery of the Notes, and from time to
time thereafter as necessary.
In case any officer a facsimile of whose signature shall appear on any Notes shall cease to
be such officer before the delivery of such Notes, either as part of the initial delivery of the Notes
or in connection with a transfer or exchange, such facsimile shall nevertheless be valid and sufficient for all purposes the same as if he had remained in office until such delivery. The Transfer
Agent's certificate of authentication of any Note shall be deemed to have been executed by it if
signed by an authorized signatory of the Transfer Agent, but it shall not be necessary that the
same person sign the certificate of authentication on all of the Notes issued hereunder.
Section 304. No Redemption of Notes. The Notes shall not be subject to redemption
prior to maturity.
Section 305. Form of Issuance and Transfer of the Notes. The Notes shall be issued
in the form of fully-registered notes without coupons. Any Note may be exchanged for Notes of
other authorized denominations or transferred upon the books required to be kept pursuant to
this section by the person in whose name it is registered, in person or by his duly authorized attorney, upon surrender of the Note to the Transfer Agent for cancellation, accompanied by delivery of a duly executed written instrument of transfer in a form approved by the Transfer Agent.
Whenever any Note or Notes shall be surrendered for transfer or exchange, the Executive Vice


139




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


President and Chief Financial Officer or the Associate Vice President for Finance of the University shall execute or cause to be executed, as specified above, and the Transfer Agent shall
authenticate and deliver a new Note or Notes, in like aggregate principal amount, and with like
interest rate and maturity. The Transfer Agent shall require the payment by the Noteholder requesting the transfer or exchange of any tax or other governmental charge required to be paid
with respect to the transfer or exchange.
The Transfer Agent shall keep or cause to be kept, at its principal office, sufficient books
for the registration and transfer or exchange of the Notes, which shall at all times be open to inspection at reasonable times by the Issuer and its auditors or their designees; and, upon presentation for such purpose, the Transfer Agent shall, under regulations as it may prescribe, transfer
or exchange or cause to be transferred or exchanged, on said books, Notes as hereinbefore
provided.
The form of the Notes shall be substantially as follows:
(Form of Note)
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
STATE OF MICHIGAN
REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
BOND ANTICIPATION NOTE,
SERIES 1993
No.                     Maturity Date:________       Principal Amount_
Interest Rate:                               Date of Original Issue:
Registered Holder: _
THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, a body corporate created by
and existing under the Constitution and laws of the State of Michigan (the "Issuer"), for value received, hereby promises to pay the Principal Amount shown above to the Registered Holder or
registered assigns, in lawful money of the United States of America on the Maturity Date shown
above, with interest thereon until maturity from the Date of Original Issue at the Interest Rate
shown above, payable on the Maturity Date. Principal of and interest on this note is payable at
the principal corporate trust office of_                in, Michigan
(the "Transfer Agent") or such other transfer agent as the Issuer may hereafter designate by notice mailed to the registered owner not less than 10 days prior to the Maturity Date.
This note is one of an issue of bonds (the "Notes"), of like tenor, except as to denomination,
aggregating the principal amount of $, all issued pursuant to a resolution adopted by
the Issuer on, 1993 (the "Resolution"), for the purpose of paying part of the cost
of the acquisition, construction, renovation and equipping of certain capital projects on the Ann
Arbor Campus of the University of Michigan, paying capitalized interest on the Notes, and paying costs related thereto and incidental to the issuance of the Notes, all in accordance with the
authority vested in the Issuer by law, particularly Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963.
The Notes, including this note, are limited and not general obligations of the Issuer payable
solely from the capitalized interest and the proceeds of debt issued by the Issuer or the Michigan
State Building Authority deposited in the Note Fund established pursuant to the Resolution, and
from Legally Available Funds, as defined in the Resolution. Except as provided above, no recourse shall be had for the payment of the principal amount of or interest on this note or any
claim based thereon against the State of Michigan, the Issuer or any officer or agent thereof or of
the University of Michigan, as individuals, either directly or indirectly nor shall these obligations
become a lien on or be secured by any property, real personal or mixed, of the State of Michigan
or the Issuer. By acceptance hereof and as a part of the consideration for the issuance hereof, the
registered owner hereof expressly waives all other recourse.


140




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


For a complete statement of the purposes for which the Notes are issued, the funds from
which and the conditions under which this note is payable, the general covenants and provisions
pursuant to which this note is issued, the rights of the holders of Notes, and the terms and conditions under which this note and the series of Notes of which this is one, or any part thereof, shall
be deemed to be no longer outstanding, reference is made to the above described Resolution. A
certified copy of the Resolution is on file at the Office of the Treasurer of the University.
The Notes shall not be subject to redemption prior to maturity.
Any Note may be exchanged for Notes of other authorized denominations or transferred by
the person in whose name it is registered, in person or by his duly authorized attorney, upon surrender of the Note to the Transfer Agent for cancellation, together with a duly executed written
instrument of transfer in a form approved by the Transfer Agent. Whenever any Note is surrendered for transfer or exchange, the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the
Associate Vice President for Finance of the University shall execute or cause to be executed, and
the Transfer Agent shall authenticate and deliver, a new Note or Notes, in like aggregate principal amount, and with like interest rate and maturity. The Transfer Agent shall require the noteholder requesting the transfer or exchange to pay any tax or other governmental charge required
to be paid with respect to the transfer or exchange.
This Note is not valid or obligatory for any purpose until the Transfer Agent's Certificate
of Authentication on this Note has been duly executed by the authorized signatory of the Transfer Agent.
IT IS HEREBY CERTIFIE          D AND RECITED that all acts, conditions and things required to be done, to happen or to be performed precedent to and in the issuance of this Note,
have been done, have happened and have been performed in due time, form and manner, as required by law.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Regents of the University of Michigan has caused this
Note to be signed for it and in its behalf by the facsimile signature of its Executive Vice President
and Chief Financial Officer, all as of, 1993.
