Section 306. Mutilated Notes. Subject to and in accordance with Act 354, Public Acts of
Michigan, 1972, as amended ("Act 354"), if any Note shall become mutilated, the Executive Vice
President and Chief Financial Officer or the Associate Vice President for Finance of the University, at the expense of the holder of the Note, shall without further action being required by the
Regents of the University of Michigan, execute or cause to be executed in the manner specified
above, and the Transfer Agent shall authenticate and deliver, a new Note of like tenor in exchange and substitution for the mutilated Note, upon surrender to the Transfer Agent of the mutilated Note and receipt by the Transfer Agent and the Issuer of indemnity satisfactory to them.
Subject to and in accordance with Act 354, if any Note issued under this Resolution shall be lost,
destroyed or stolen, evidence of the loss, destruction or theft may be submitted to the Transfer
Agent and, if this evidence is satisfactory to both the Transfer Agent and the Issuer and indemnity satisfactory to the Transfer Agent and the Issuer shall be given, the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the Associate Vice President for Finance, at the expense of
the owner, shall without further action being required by the Regents of the University of Michigan, execute or cause to be executed in the manner specified above and the Transfer Agent shall
thereupon authenticate and deliver, a new Note of like tenor and bearing the statement required
by Act 354, or any applicable Michigan law hereafter enacted, in lieu of and in substitution for
the Note so lost, destroyed or stolen. If any such Note shall have matured or shall be about to
mature, instead of issuing a substitute Note the Transfer Agent may pay the same without surrender thereof.
Section 307. Cancellation of Notes. All Notes, which have been retired by maturity, redemption or purchase shall be cancelled by the Transfer Agent and an appropriate certificate of
cancellation with respect thereto delivered to the Issuer. Unless otherwise required by applicable
law, regulation or rule as soon as practicable following the cancellation thereof, all cancelled
Notes shall be cremated and an appropriate certificate of cremation delivered to the Issuer by the
Transfer Agent.
Section 308. Resignation of Transfer Agent The Transfer Agent may resign by giving not less than thirty (30) days prior written notice to the Issuer, and the Issuer may remove
the Transfer Agent by giving not less than thirty (30) days prior written notice to the Transfer
Agent. The Issuer shall designate a successor Transfer Agent and shall mail notice of the appointment of the successor Transfer Agent to each registered owner of the Notes not less than
ten (10) days prior to the Note Payment Date. Upon the appointment of a successor Transfer
Agent, the predecessor Transfer Agent shall transfer all moneys and funds, the registration
books, and all other documents and instruments relating to the Notes held by it as Transfer
Agent to the successor Transfer Agent.
ARTICLE IV
ESTABLISHMENT OF FUNDS
Section 401. Establishment of Project Fund. There is hereby created and established
the Project Fund, which shall be a sub-account within a general banking account of the University designated by the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. There shall be deposited in the Project Fund (i) all proceeds from the sale of the Notes, except accrued and capitalized
interest to be deposited in the Note Fund pursuant to Section 501, and (ii) all investment earnings on investments of the Project Fund. All moneys in the Project Fund shall be used for the
purposes and disbursed as provided in Article V.
Section 402. Establishment of Note Fund. There is hereby created and established
with the Transfer Agent the Note Fund. There shall be deposited in the Note Fund:
1.   Any accrued interest received at the time of delivery of the Notes, together with
the amount, if any, determined by an Authorized Officer to be appropriate as
capitalized interest on the Notes.
2.   The proceeds of indebtedness issued by the Michigan State Building Authority
paid to the Issuer and required to be deposited into the Note Fund pursuant to
Section 602.


143




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


3.   The proceeds of renewal notes or of bonds of the Issuer issued for the purpose of
refunding the Notes and required to be deposited in the Note Fund pursuant to
Section 602.
4.   All Legally Available Funds required to be paid into the Note Fund pursuant to
Section 603.
5.   All Investment Income.
6.   Any moneys from the Project Fund which are directed by the Issuer to be deposited therein.
All moneys in the Note Fund shall be used for the purposes and disbursed as provided in
Article V.
ARTICLE V
FLOW AND USE OF FUNDS
Section 501. Application of Note Proceeds Immediately upon the receipt thereof, the
proceeds of the sale of the Notes shall be apportioned among and deposited in the following funds
and accounts in the following manner:
1.   Any accrued interest received on sale of the Notes and any capitalized interest
shall be deposited in the Note Fund;
2.   The balance of the proceeds of the Notes shall be deposited in the
Project Fund.
Section 502. Use of and Disbursements from Project Fund. Moneys in the Project
Fund shall be used pursuant to the following purposes:
1.   Payment of accounting, financial consulting, legal, printing and other expenses
of the Issuer in connection with the preparation, issuance, sale and delivery of
the Notes;
2.   Payments necessary to finance part of the cost of the acquisition, construction,
renovation, installation, furnishing and equipping of the Project or to reimburse the Issuer for general funds expended in connection with the foregoing.
Any amount remaining in the Project Fund after satisfaction of the foregoing priorities shall, as
directed by the Issuer, be promptly transferred to the Note Fund. In addition, upon maturity of
the Notes, or upon provision for payment of the Notes, the Issuer may direct the transfer of all or
a portion of the funds in the Project Fund to the Note Fund. The depository for the Project Fund
shall make disbursements from the Project Fund upon the order of the Issuer, and shall have no
duty or liability with respect to the manner or method in which moneys are withdrawn by the Issuer from the Project Fund or in fact are used or applied by the Issuer.
Section 503. Use of and Disbursements from Note Fund. On the Note Payment
Date, the Transfer Agent shall use moneys in the Note Fund to pay principal of and interest on
the Notes as the same are presented and surrendered. Any amount remaining in the Note Fund
after the Notes have been paid or provision made therefor under the Resolution shall be returned
to the Issuer.
Section 504. Investment of Funds. Moneys held in the Note Fund, until required for
use, shall be invested by Transfer Agent in direct obligations of, or obligations the principal and
the interest of which are guaranteed by the United States of America; or obligations of Federal
Farm Credit Banks, Federal Home Loan Banks, the Federal National Mortgage Association, the
Federal Land Bank, Federal Intermediate Credit Banks, the Export-Import Bank of the United
States, the Government National Mortgage Association, the Bank for Cooperatives, the Federal
Financing Bank, the Farmers Home Administration and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association; or tax-exempt obligations rated A or better by Moody's Investors Service and Standard
and Poor's Corporation in the case of long term obligations, or in the highest category by each


144




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


such rating agency in the case of short-term obligations; or may be deposited in a bank or banks
(including the Transfer Agent) in an interest bearing savings account or accounts, bankers' acceptances or in certificates of deposit; or may be invested in any fund or funds composed entirely
of any or all of the above described investment vehicles (provided that, with respect to tax-exempt
obligations in such funds, the obligations need not be rated A or better, but rather must be, or be
deemed to be by the Fund's sponsor or adviser, investment grade), all as shall be directed by the
Issuer. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the funds in the Note Fund may be invested as directed
by the State Building Authority, or by the Issuer to the extent required to preserve the exclusion
from gross income of the interest on the Notes, or any bonds issued by the State Building
Authority or the Issuer.
Interest or profit earned on the above investments or deposits, when received shall be deposited in the Note Fund. Any loss on the above investments or deposits shall be charged to the
Note Fund.
Moneys held in the Project Fund may be invested in any investments legally available for
University funds. All earnings, gains or losses thereon shall be credited to the Project Fund.
Section 505. Tax Covenant. The Issuer hereby covenants that it shall take all actions
within its control necessary to maintain the exclusion of the interest on the Notes from gross income for federal income tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Code"), including but not limited to actions relating to the rebate of arbitrage earnings, if required, and the
expenditure and investment of Note proceeds and moneys deemed to be Note proceeds.
ARTICLE VI
SOURCES OF PAYMENT FOR THE NOTES
Section 601. Sources of Payment for the Notes. The Notes are not debts or general
obligations of the State of Michigan, nor general obligations of the Issuer, Jut are limited obligations of the Issuer payable only from the following:
1.   All moneys in the Note Fund, including Investment Income;
2.   The proceeds of indebtedness issued by the Michigan State Building Authority
paid to the Issuer and required to be deposited in the Note Fund pursuant to
Section 602;
3.   The proceeds of renewal notes or bonds issued by the Issuer for the purpose of
refunding the Notes and required to be deposited in the Note Fund pursuant to
Section 602;
4.   Legally Available Funds required to be deposited in the Note Fund pursuant to
Section 603; and
5.   All of the proceeds of the foregoing.
Section 602. Deposit of Proceeds of Debt. To the extent necessary to pay or provide
for the payment of principal and interest on the Notes as provided in Article VII, the Issuer shall
deposit into the Note Fund amounts paid to the Issuer by the Michigan State Building Authority
with respect to the Project and derived from the issuance of indebtedness of the State Building
Authority. In addition, the Issuer shall deposit into the Note Fund amounts necessary to pay or
so provide for the payment of the Notes derived from the issuance of renewal notes of the Issuer
or bonds issued by the Issuer for the purpose of refunding the Notes.
Section 603. Covenant to Use Legally Available Funds. To the extent that on the
Note Payment Date, the amounts on deposit in the Note Fund are insufficient to make the payment of all principal of and interest on the Notes, the Issuer covenants to transfer to the Transfer Agent from any Legally Available Funds the amount sufficient to make up such payment
deficiency and the Transfer Agent shall use the amount so transferred to make up such
deficiency.


145




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


Section 604. Limitations of Obligations No recourse under any obligation, covenant,
stipulation or indenture contained in this Resolution or in any Note issued hereunder or caused
by the creation of any indebtedness hereby authorized, shall be had against the State of Michigan, or the Issuer or any member or officer of the Issuer or any officer of the University, nor
shall any such obligation ever be or become a charge against the State of Michigan, nor shall the
same become a lien on or secured by any property, real, personal or mixed, of the State of Michigan or the Issuer, it being expressly understood and agreed that the Notes and the obligations
created hereunder are payable only from the sources of funds specified in Section 601, and that
no other liability whatsoever shall attach to or be incurred by the State of Michigan, the Issuer,
or any member or officer of the Issuer or any officer of the University, or its successors; all other
liability, except as herein provided, being expressly waived.
ARTICLE VII
DEFEASANCE
If all the Notes shall have become due and payable in accordance with their terms or are to
be paid at their maturity or maturities and the whole amount of the principal and the interest so
due and payable upon all of the Notes then outstanding shall be paid or sufficient cash, or cash
and non-callable Government Obligations the principal of and the interest on which without reinvestment, when due and payable, will provide sufficient moneys for such payment, shall be held
by the Transfer Agent in the Note Fund or by any other escrow agent in trust for the benefit of
the holders of the Notes, then and in that case the Resolution shall be defeased and terminated
and all obligations of the Issuer hereunder shall thereupon cease, terminate and become void
and, on demand of the Issuer, any surplus in the Note Fund other than money held for the payment of the Notes shall be transferred to the Issuer; provided, that the applicable provisions of
this Resolution pertaining to the payment of the principal of and interest on the Notes, the registration, exchange and transfer of Notes, and the tax covenant contained in Section 505 shall be
continued in force until such have been fully paid.
Notes or portions of Notes for which cash or cash and Government Obligations (including
principal of and interest thereon) shall be held by the Transfer Agent or other escrow agent in
trust for the holders of said Notes or portions of Notes sufficient to pay all principal and interest
through maturity shall no longer be outstanding hereunder, and the holders thereof shall have
no further rights hereunder or under the Notes except the right to receive payment from the cash
or cash and Government Obligations held in trust as specified above and the right to effect transfers or exchanges of Notes as described above.
All moneys and Government Obligations held by the Transfer Agent or other escrow agent
as described above shall be held in trust and applied to the payment, when due, of the Notes payable therewith.
ARTICLE VIII
FURTHER COVENANTS
The Issuer covenants and agrees with the holders of the Notes as follows:
(1)  The Issuer shall faithfully perform all of its covenants, undertakings, provisions and agreements contained in the Resolution and in any Note executed and delivered hereunder and in all other proceedings of the Issuer
pertaining thereto.
(2)  The Issuer is duly authorized under the Constitution and laws of the State
of Michigan to adopt the Resolution, to issue the Notes, and to acquire
construct, renovate and equip the Project as contemplated by this Resolution; all action on its part relating to the adoption of the Resolution and
the issuance, execution and delivery of any Notes has been or will be duly
and effectively taken prior to the delivery of such Notes; and the Notes in
the hands of the holders and owners thereof are and will be valid and enforceable limited obligations of the Issuer according to their terms.


146




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


ARTICLE IX
SUPPLEMENTAL RESOLUTIONS
Section 901. Supplemental Resolutions Not ReGuiring Consent of Noteholders
The Issuer may without the consent of the Noteholders adopt resolutions supplemental to the
Resolution as shall not be inconsistent with the terms and provisions hereof for any one or more
of the following purposes:
(a)   To add additional covenants and agreements of the Issuer for the
purpose of further securing the payment of the Notes;
(b)   To cure any ambiguity or formal defect or omission in the
Resolution;
(c)   To amend or subtract from or make substitutions for the Project.
Section 902. Supplemental Resolutions Requiring Consent of Noteholders. Exclusive of supplemental resolutions covered by Section 901 for which consent of Noteholders is
not required, the holders of not less than 51% in the aggregate principal amount of the Notes
outstanding shall have the right to consent to the adoption by the Issuer of such other supplemental or amendatory resolutions as shall be deemed necessary and desirable by the Issuer; provided, however, that nothing contained in this Section shall permit, or be construed as
permitting, (i) an extension of the maturity of the principal of or the interest on any Note issued
hereunder, or (ii) a reduction in the principal amount of any Note or the rate of interest thereon,
or (iii) a privilege or priority of any Note or Notes over any other Note or Notes, or (iv) a reduction in the aggregate principal amount of the Notes required for consent to such supplemental or
amendatory resolution.
If the Issuer shall propose to adopt a supplemental resolution requiring consent of the
Noteholders, it shall cause notice of the proposed adoption of such supplemental resolution to be
mailed to each registered owner at the registered address as shown on the books of the Issuer
kept by the Transfer Agent. Such notice shall briefly set forth the nature of the proposed supplemental or amendatory resolution and shall state that copies thereof are on file at the Office of the
Treasurer of the University for inspection by all Noteholders. If within six months following the
publication of such notice, the holders of not less than 51% in aggregate principal amount of the
Notes outstanding at the time of the mailing of such notice have consented in writing to the
adoption thereof, upon the adoption of such supplemental or amendatory resolution, the Resolution shall be deemed to be amended in accordance therewith.
ARTICLE X
MISCELLANEOUS
Section 1001. Authorization of Official Statement, Preliminary Official Statement, and Official Notice of Sale. The Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer,
or the Associate Vice President for Finance, or either of them are hereby authorized to cause to
be prepared and circulated a Preliminary Official Statement with respect to the Notes, to cause
to be prepared and published an Official Notice of Sale, and to cause to be prepared, and to execute and deliver on behalf of the Issuer an Official Statement substantially in the form of the previously prepared Preliminary Official Statement, relating to the Notes. The distribution and use
of the Preliminary Official Statement in accordance with applicable laws, in connection with the
sale of the Notes, is hereby ratified and confirmed, and the distribution and use of the Official
Statement in accordance with applicable laws by the successful bidder, in connection with the
marketing of the Notes, is hereby authorized and approved.
Section 1002. Resolution Constitutes Contract. The provisions of the Resolution
shall constitute a contract between the Issuer and Noteholders to the equal and ratable benefit
and protection of each Noteholder, and after delivery of the Notes, no change, variation, or alteration of the provisions of the Resolution may be made except in accordance with its terms.


147




November Meeting, 1993 - Appendix A


Section 1003. Enforcement of Contract. The contract constituted by the Resolution
shall be enforceable by appropriate proceedings taken by the Noteholder(s) under the law.
Section 1004. Other Documentation, The Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the University, the Secretary of the University, the Associate Vice President for Finance of the University, the Treasurer and Investment Officer of the University, and any other
appropriate officers or representatives of the Issuer or the University, and each of them, are
authorized to perform all acts and deeds and execute and deliver all instruments and documents
for and on behalf of the Issuer required by this Resolution, or necessary, expedient and proper in
connection with the issuance, sale and delivery of the Notes, and the acquisition, construction,
renovation and equipping of the Project all as contemplated hereby.
Subsequent to the issuance of the Notes, all actions permitted or required by the Issuer
may be made or undertaken by the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or Associate Vice President for Finance, or any other duly authorized officer of the Issuer or the University. All determination of Note terms required to be made by the Executive Vice President and
Chief Financial Officer or Associate Vice President for Finance shall be made by him within the
ranges or other limitations set forth herein.
Section 1005. Severability. If any one or more sections, clauses or provisions of the
Resolution shall be determined by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or ineffective for
any reason, such determination shall in no way affect the validity and effectiveness of the remaining sections, clauses and provisions of the Resolution.
Section 1006. Headings. Any headings shall be solely for convenience of reference and
shall not constitute a part of the Resolution, nor shall they affect its meaning, construction or
effect.
Section 1007. Conflict. All resolutions or parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the
Issuer in conflict herewith be and the same are repealed insofar as such conflict exists.
Section 1008. Effective Date. The Resolution shall take effect immediately upon its
adoption.


148




DECEMBER MEETING, 1993


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, December 16, 1993
The Regents met at 1:15 p.m. in the Regents' Room and heard a presentation by Mr. Theodore Spencer, director of undergraduate admissions, on activities of the undergraduate admissions office. Present were President Duderstadt
and Regents Brown, McFee, McGowan, Power, and Waters. Vice President and
Secretary Kennedy was also present, as were Provost Whitaker, Executive Vice
President Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, and
Chancellor Renick. Regents Baker, Deitch, and Varner and Chancellor Jones
were absent; Provost Wong attended in place of Chancellor Jones.
The presentation concluded at 3:15 p.m.
Public Comments
The Regents assembled at 4:00 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan
Union. Present were President Duderstadt and Regents Brown, McFee,
McGowan, and Power. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, Provost Whitaker,
Executive Vice President Womack, and Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison,
Hartford, and Neal were also present. Regents Baker, Deitch, Varner, and
Waters and Chancellors Jones and Renick were absent.
The Regents heard comments from the following people, on the topics indicated: Christopher Martin, student, on the tenure status of Professor Richard
Campbell; and Brian Winkler, member, and Robert Darden, head coach, men's
gymnastics team, on the decision to drop the men's gymnastics team.
Friday, December 17, 1993
The Regents met at 9:15 a.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner, and
Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, Provost Whitaker, Executive
Vice President Womack, and Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and
Neal were also present, as was Chancellor Renick. Chancellor Jones was absent;
Provost Wong attended in his place.
Resolution in Honor of 1994 Rhodes Scholar
President Duderstadt called on Regent Varner, who read the following
resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan commend Leah N.
Niederstadt on her selection as a 1994 Rhodes Scholar.


149




December Meeting, 1993


One of 32 students nationwide chosen to receive a Rhodes scholarship, Leah is the first woman from the University of Michigan and
the first UM student since 1980 to be selected for this most prestigious honor.
Leah Niederstadt has taken full advantage of the wealth of opportunities available at the University, and the University in turn
has been enriched by her presence. With a dual major in political
science and Afroamerican and African studies, she has not only received numerous academic honors, but has been captain of the
women's rugby team, held leadership positions in her sorority, and
served as a volunteer for student, Greek, and community groups, all
while completely financing her education through employment in
various positions both within the University and elsewhere. Described by her professors as "a student of extraordinary talent and
ability," Leah plans to use her Rhodes scholarship to pursue a
master's degree in social anthropology at Oxford University.
It is with great pride that the Regents commend this outstanding young woman of Michigan for her remarkable achievement in
being named a 1994 Rhodes Scholar.
Ms. Niederstadt came forward to receive her resolution. There followed a
round of applause, and the motion was adopted by acclamation. Ms. Niederstadt
expressed her gratitude at the educational opportunities that the University had
provided her.
Resolution in Honor of 1994 British Marshall Scholar
President Duderstadt called on Regent Power, a former Marshall Scholar
from the University of Michigan, who read the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan commend Michael K.
Weiss on his selection as a 1994 British Marshall Scholar.
A native of West Bloomfield, Michigan, Michael is an honors
student with a triple major in math, physics, and English and a
nearly perfect grade point average. He is the University's first
Marshall Scholar since 1987.
Described by one of his professors as "one of the most brilliant
students I have ever encountered in my 27-year career at Michigan,"
Michael Weiss is a multifaceted young man who also excels in creative writing and participates in community theater. He plans to use
his British Marshall scholarship to study mathematics at Cambridge
University in England.
The Regents take great pride in adding Michael K. Weiss to the
roster of the University of Michigan's "leaders and best."
The motion was approved by acclamation; Ms. Niederstadt accepted the
resolution on behalf of Mr. Weiss, who was not present.


150




December Meeting, 1993


CESF Report, Ann Arbor Campus
President Duderstadt called on Professor John Tropman, chair of the
Committee on the Economic Status of the Faculty, to present the CESF Report.
Professor Tropman expressed appreciation for the 1993 salary program and
urged that consideration be given to expanding and enhancing it. He noted that
SACUA had asked CESF to transmit its request for a 10 percent salary program
in 1994-95, but pointed out that CESF was not recommending a specific percentage increase. Professor Tropman observed that among faculty, there is a perception that there is a greater difference between academic and administrative
compensation than is actually the case.
Professor Tropman also noted that CESF is working with the administration to explore innovative compensation practices. CESF is also evaluating the
experimental program of one-time salary increases that are not added to base
pay. In addition, CESF has also been involved in the process of developing a flexible benefits program.
President Duderstadt stated that the advice and counsel of CESF has been
very important in the development of a flexible benefits program. He then gave a
presentation on the current faculty and executive officer compensation strategy,
the details of which are on file in the Office of the Secretary of the University.
Professor Tropman commented on various aspects of the compensation policy and gave suggestions as to how compensation issues might be further
explored.
Regents Power and Deitch commented about the usefulness of such discussions about compensation policy and about the importance of having a policy in
place and publicly articulated.
Campus Safety
Regent McGowan observed that a woman had been raped in a University
parking lot outside of a residence hall at the end of November. She noted that the
president had written a letter to the community and had asked Vice Presidents
Hartford and Womack to report on what could be done to minimize the chances
of this occurring again.
President Duderstadt stated that he was horrified by the incident and called
on Vice President Hartford to comment on the current situation. Vice President
Hartford reported on the activities of staff from the Department of Public Safety,
the Dean of Students' Office, the Sexual Assault Awareness and Prevention Center (SAPAC), the University Planner's Office, and other areas with regard to
dealing with this situation. She reported that three action steps were being taken
immediately: an assessment of lighting, both on campus and in nearby areas;
education about safety for both men and women to be provided by a variety of
methods, including self-defense classes; and an assessment of safety issues associated with the medical campus. The Department of Public Safety was also going
to increase the number of staff on the streets and in the parking structures.


151




December Meeting, 1993


Following further discussion, the president noted that he is personally
involved in studying these issues, and that they would receive fill attention at
the highest levels of the administration.
Annual Report on Research for 1993
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Neal to present the annual
report on research. Vice President Neal stated that the four goals of the Office of
the Vice President for Research (OVPR) are to 1) promote research, scholarship,
and creative activities; 2) help set national research priorities; 3) assure that
conduct of research is consistent with the University's mission and principles;
and 4) facilitate the transfer of knowledge. He then reviewed progress towards
those goals by reporting that the University ranks number one in total research
and development expenditures among the top twenty public universities and
colleges and number two in expenditures among all universities and colleges,
with total research expenditures of $373.7 million in FY 1993. Federal research
expenditures have increased over the past ten years, while non-federal and
university expenditures have remained flat.
Vice President Neal then reviewed the factors influencing both the national
and local environments for research support and the challenges these factors
pose for the future of the U.S. research university. The OVPR is currently focusing its efforts on developing policies and an agenda regarding research integrity
issues; assessing internal research funding needs; advancing new research initiatives; developing a long-range research plan for the campus; influencing the
national research agenda; developing the local campus infrastructure; and promoting economic development.
Vice President Neal concluded by reviewing several specific initiatives being
undertaken by his office in the area of academic integrity and internal funding
issues. Following some discussion, the Regents turned to consideration of the
regular agenda.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Deitch, the
Regents unanimously approved the minutes for the November 1993 meeting.
Reports. Executive Vice President Womack submitted reports of investments, plant extension, litigation, and personnel-labor relations and Vice President Neal submitted reports of projects established and summaries of a selection
of current research.
Voluntary Support. Vice President Cosovich submitted the report of voluntary support.

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted the following retir
ment memoirs:
Lawrence S. Bartell, the Philip J. Elving Professor of Chemistry, w
retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1993.
A native of Ann Arbor, Professor Bartell received his B.S. degree in 194
his M.S. degree in 1947, and his Ph.D. degree in 1952, all from the University
Michigan. He was a faculty member at Iowa State University from 1953-6
when he came to the University of Michigan as a professor of chemistry. He w<
named the Philip J. Elving Professor in 1987.
Among Professor Bartell's many honors are the University of MichigDistinguished Faculty Achievement Award (1981), the Michigan Association
Governing Boards Distinguished Faculty Award (1982), the National Scien,
Foundation Creativity Award (1982), and Michigan Scientist of the Year (198(
He has served as chair of the Division of Chemical Physics of the AmericE
Physical Society (1977-78) and on the editorial boards of the Journal of Chemic
Physics (1963-66), the Journal of Computational Chemistry (1979-90), ar
Chemical Physics Letters (1981-84).


161




December Meeting, 1993


Professor Bartell's research involves the use of electron diffraction to examine the structure of molecules in the gas and, more recently, the structure of matter in the condensed phases. He has published over 261 journal articles and 10
textbook chapters. His pioneering efforts have extended the precision of the electron diffraction technique and revealed many new areas in which to apply it. The
first photographs of single atoms and molecules were produced by Professor Bartell's ingenious holographic method, based on the combination of electron
diffraction and laser illumination. He has also made significant contributions
towards understanding the basic quantum mechanical paradoxes raised by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen.
Professor Bartell has been a leader in the field of molecular mechanics to
describe molecular structure and conformational changes. He has consistently
upheld the highest standards of scholarly performance and teaching excellence,
and has contributed broadly in many areas of both the Department of Chemistry
and the University of Michigan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physical chemist by naming
Lawrence S. Bartell the Philip J. Elving Professor Emeritus of Chemistry.
Ben F. Barton, professor of electrical engineering and computer science in
the College of Engineering, will retire from active faculty status on December 31,
1993, after a career of 36 years on the faculty of the University of Michigan.
Professor Barton earned his B.S. degree in 1947, his M.S. degree in 1952,
and his Ph.D. degree in 1957, all in electrical engineering, and all from the University of Michigan.
From 1947-48, Professor Barton was employed as an engineer at the General Motors Proving Ground. He then worked for three years at MC Manufacturing Company, where he was involved in the research and development of
extremely high performance compressors for the United States Army Air Force.
Professor Barton joined the faculty of the Department of Electrical Engineering
as an assistant professor in 1957; he was promoted to associate professor in 1958
and professor in 1964. He served as the director of Cooley Laboratory from
1961-65.
In the Department of Electrical Engineering, Professor Barton was responsible for introducing several courses in circuits and electronics, with strong
design and laboratory components. In recent years, his research interest has
turned to the field of technical communications, where he and his wife,
Marthalee Barton, who is a lecturer in the college's technical communications
program, have been widely recognized for their joint work They have received
several awards, including an Outstanding Paper award from the Society for
Technical Communications in 1985 and Best Paper award from the National
Council of Teachers of English in 1988 and again in 1992.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his distinguished service by
naming Ben F. Barton professor emeritus of electrical engineering and computer
science.
Clark E. Chastain, professor of accounting in the School of Management
at the University of Michigan-Flint, will retire from active faculty status on
December 31, 1993, after a most productive career as teacher and researcher.


162




December Meeting, 1993


A native of Arkansas, Professor Chastain received his B.S. degree in 1953
and his M.B.A degree in 1955, both from the University of Arkansas. He received his Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1958.
Professor Chastain served as an accountant at the U.S. Securities and
Exchange Commission from 1958-59 and then as an operations analyst at The
John Hopkins Office of Research Administration in 1960. He was a research
associate and lecturer at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor campus from
1961-64 and then served as an assistant professor at UM-Dearborn from 1964-68.
Professor Chastain moved to the University of Michigan-Flint in 1968; he was
promoted to associate professor in 1973 and to professor in 1977.
On the Flint campus, Professor Chastain quickly became an important and
active member of the School of Management accounting faculty. He has received
two faculty awards for scholarly achievement (1981 and 1983), a manuscript
award from the National Association of Accountants (1984 and 1987), and was
named an Outstanding Educator of America in 1975. In addition to his teaching,
research, and honors, he has been involved with the student accounting fraternity, Beta Alpha Psi. Professor Chastain has been an avid researcher through the
years and continues to write and publish in many leading journals.
The Regents now salute this distinguished educator for his dedicated service
by naming Clark E. Chastain professor emeritus of accounting.
Walter HL Clark, Jr., associate professor of English language and literature, will retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1993, after a productive career as a writer and teacher.
A native of Massachusetts, Professor Clark received his B.A degree from
Swarthmore College (1954) and his Ph.D. degree from Harvard University
(1965). He came to the University of Michigan as an assistant professor in 1965
and was promoted to associate professor in 1970. Professor Clark received the
University's Distinguished Faculty Service Award in 1970 and the Amoco Outstanding Teaching Award in 1987. He served as director of freshman composition from 1973-76 and has been director of the Residential College freshman
seminar program since 1981. He has served on the Commission on Literature of
the National Council of Teachers of English and on various editorial boards and
was a Fulbright lecturer at the University of Graz in Australia in 1971-72.
Professor Clark has published numerous articles on education and on such
writers as Robert Frost and J. F. Powers and, more recently, on teaching environmental literature. His poetry has appeared widely in Harvard Magazine, The
New York Times, The Iowa Review, and The Michigan Quarterly Review, among
other places. A book of his poetry, View From Mount Paugus (1976), was nominated for the Lamont Award.
In the course of an outstanding teaching career at Michigan, Professor
Clark has taught courses ranging from introductory composition to problems in
critical theory. He has been particularly active in preparing students for teaching
English at the secondary level. In 1975, Professor Clark, with the help of a colleague, founded the New England Literature Program offered in New Hampshire during the spring half-term and devoted to reading New England authors
in the setting in which they wrote. The program continues in vigorous health
today and is regarded by many students who have participated in it as the


163




December Meeting, 1993


highlight of their undergraduate experiencee The New England Literature Program is recognized nationally as a model of environmentally based education
largely due to Professor Clark's dedicated and imaginative commitment to
nurturing and publicizing this innovative educational experiment.
The Regents now salute this distinguished writer and teacher by naming
Walter H. Clark, Jr., associate professor emeritus of English language and
literature.
Sylvia S. Hacker, associate professor of community health nursing in the
School of Nursing and associate professor of population planning and international health in the School of Public Health, will retire from active faculty status
on December 31, 1993.
A native of New York City, Professor Hacker completed her B.A degree in
1946 at Brooklyn College, her M.S. degree in 1966 at the State University of New
York at Cortland, and her Ph.D. degree in 1977 at the University of Michigan.
Since joining the University of Michigan faculty in 1975, Professor Hacker
has become widely known within the University, the state, and the nation for her
expertise in the area of human sexuality and her skill in communicating this
expertise to others. She has published extensively, both in professional journals
and lay magazines, and her new book, What Teenagers REALLY Want to Know
About Sex, co-authored with her daughter, has just been published. She was
certified as a sex educator in 1988 by the American Association of Sex Educators,
Counselors, and Therapists.
Professor Hacker is well known and respected for her forthrightness and
ability to stimulate and manage constructive dialogue in the often controversial
area of human sexuality in secondary schools, colleges and universities, and
community organizations. She engages and challenges her audience, with humor,
to identify and examine their values and positions on sensitive social and political
issues and to continuously pursue credible evidence in forming their positions.
Professor Hacker has shown remarkable personal and professional courage in
the face of provocation and conflict and has made effective use of the mass media
in doing so. She hosts a community access call-in television program, "Sexy
Minutes;" has been interviewed on numerous radio and television shows, including "The Phil Donahue Show"; and has been cited in many national publications.
She also serves as a consultant to the teen magazine, Sassy.
Professor Hacker has received awards from the Michigan Department of
Public Health, Mensa, and lesbian and gay male civil rights groups. At the University, she received the Mae Edna Doyle Teacher of the Year Award from the
School of Nursing in May 1993. Evaluations of her teaching skills indicate that
she challenges people's values, stimulates their thinking, and helps them develop,
articulate, and defend their positions in the area of human sexuality.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Sylvia S. Hacker
associate professor emerita of community health nursing and associate professor
emerita of population planning and international health.
Regent Deitch noted the retirement of Professor Bernard Klein, and
observed that "he is a man of uncommon good sense, good humor, grace, and a
distinguished Michigan citizen".


164




December Meeting, 1993


Bernard W. Klein, professor of political science in the College of Arts,
Sciences, and Letters and professor of public administration in the School of
Education at the University of Michigan-Dearborn, will retire from active faculty
status on December 31, 1993.
A native of New York City, Professor Klein earned his AB. degree in 1950
from Brooklyn College, his AM. degree in 1954 from the University of Missouri,
and his Ph.D. degree in 1965 from Michigan State University. He served as
assistant director of workmen's compensation in the state of Michigan from
1956-61, and from 1961-67 was supervisor of the Lansing office of the University
of Michigan's Institute of Public Administration. Professor Klein served as
controller of the city of Detroit from 1967-70. In 1970, he was appointed visiting
professor in the University of Michigan's School of Social Work. He then went to
Wayne County Community College, serving as vice president for administration
from 1970-71. He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan-Dearborn in
1971 as professor of political science. During this time, Professor Klein also
served as president of the Detroit Charter Revision Commission from 1970-73.
He was appointed acting chancellor of the Dearborn campus from 1979-80 and
then took a leave of absence in 1980-81 to serve as vice president for labor, urban
and metropolitan studies, and then interim provost at Wayne State University.
He returned to the UM-Dearborn to resume his professorship in 1981; he
received the additional appointment of professor of public administration in 1992
and led the campus again as interim chancellor of the Dearborn campus in
1992-93.
As a teacher-scholar, Professor Klein introduced into the curriculum such
new areas of study as urban politics, public administration, and public sector
labor relations. Professor Klein resisted becoming a full-time administrator in order to return to his first love, teaching. He received the UM-Dearborn's Distinguished Teaching Award, tenured category, in 1990 and the Distinguished
Faculty Award- from the Michigan Association of Governing Boards of State
Universities in 1991. Professor Klein authored and co-authored a number of
articles in the area of public administration and state and local government and
acted as confident and advisor to governors, mayors, and legislators of both
political parties. He is currently in Romania serving as a Fulbright Lecturer in
political science at the Technical University of Iassi.
The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and administrator for his
dedicated service by naming Bernard W. Klein professor emeritus of political
science and professor emeritus of public administration.
E. Richard McPhee, D.D.S., professor of dentistry in the School of Dentistry, will retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1993.
A native of Detroit, Dr. McPhee studied electrical engineering at the Chrysler Institute of Engineering and attended the University of Detroit from 1959-64.
He earned his D.D.S. degree in 1966 and his M.S. degree in restorative dentistry
in 1969, both at the University of Michigan. Dr. McPhee joined the faculty of the
University of Michigan as an assistant professor of dentistry in 1969; he was
promoted to associate professor in 1974 and professor in 1978. He held joint
appointments in the Departments of Prosthodontics and Biomaterials.


165




December Meeting, 1993


Dr. McPhee is a member of Omicron Kappa Upsilon and Phi Kappa Phi
honor societies and received the Kingery Prosthodontics Honor Award and a
Quest for Technology Award. He has served on a number of school and University committees and has also been a member of some 20 graduate student thesis
committees. Dr. McPhee's professional affiliations include membership and
offices in the American Dental Association, the American Academy of Crown and
Bridge Prosthodontics, the American and the International Associations for
Dental Research, and the Inter-Society Color Council. He has been on the
executive council of the American Association of Dental Schools and served on
the executive committee and as president of the Francis B. Vedder Society of
Crown and Bridge.
Known for his dedication to teaching, Dr. McPhee was chosen by secondyear dental students as Instructor of the Year in both 1984 and 1985. His
research has focused on porcelain, ceramo-metal, and ceramic restorations and
techniques, and the results of his studies have been published as journal articles,
manuals, and chapters in texts. Dr. McPhee has also developed nearly 20 television teaching tapes, primarily in restorative materials and procedures.
In support of his promotion to professor, Dr. McPhee was repeatedly characterized as a "devoted worker" and a "dedicated teacher," who endeavored to
"improve teaching and advance his profession through research." Another of his
colleagues pointed out that his background in engineering added a new dimension in "helping solve departmental problems, research, and dentistry in
general."
The Regents now salute this distinguished health sciences educator by
naming E. Richard McPhee professor emeritus of dentistry.
Ilene T. Olken, professor of Italian, will retire from active faculty status on
December 31, 1993, following 33 years as a teacher and scholar of Italian,
French, and comparative literature in the Department of Romance Languages
and Literatures.
Professor Olken completed four degrees at the University of Michigan,
including an AB. degree in 1950, an AM. degree in English and education in
1952, a second AM. degree in French in 1955, and a Ph.D. degree in French and
Italian in 1959. She joined the faculty in 1960 as an instructor in French; she was
promoted to assistant professor of French and Italian in 1962, associate professor
of Italian in 1966, and professor of Italian in 1986.
Professor Olken served on many departmental and University committees,
including the Rackham Executive Board, and was the associate director of the
Program in Comparative Literature from 1972-78. Her publications include the
book, With Pleated Eye and Garnet Wing: Symmetries of Italo Calvino (1984),
two textbooks, several editions of Italian works for use in the classroom, and a
number of articles on French and Italian literature.
She will be remembered by her many former students for her affectionate
concern for their welfare, her insistence that they measure themselves against
the highest intellectual standards, and above all for the passion with which she
defended the idea of a humanistically conceived, rather than a technically or
theoretically oriented mode of criticism.


166




December Meeting, 1993


The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and scholar and recognize her many years of devoted service to the University by naming Ilene T.
Olken professor emerita of Italian.
Memorials. Provost Whitaker submitted the following memorial
statement:
The Regents of the University acknowledge with profound sadness the
death on November 26, 1993, of Marshall H. Becker, professor of health
behavior and health education in the School of Public Health and professor of
health behavior, Department of Pediatrics and Communicable Diseases, in the
Medical School.
Professor Becker was born in New York City in 1940. He received his B.S.
degree from City University of New York in 1962. He received his M.S. degree in
public health in 1964 and his Ph.D. degree in medical sociology in 1968, both
from the University of Michigan. He began his teaching and research career at
The John Hopkins University in 1969 and joined the University of Michigan
faculty in 1977.
Professor Becker's research and writing about compliance with medical regimens and factors influencing preventive and disease management actions placed
him in the forefront of health behavior research. He authored or co-authored 120
articles on these subjects. He was editor of the Health Education Quarterly from
1979-86 and served on the editorial boards of six other scholarly journals. He
chaired the Department of Health Behavior and Health Education from 1983-87
and served as associate dean for academic affairs in the School of Public Health
from 1987-93. Professor Becker was a consummate teacher whose courses consistently attracted hundreds of registrants from throughout the campus. He was
frequently honored for his accomplishments: he received the Distinguished Fellow Award from the Society for Public Health Education in 1981, the Mayhew
Derryberry Award from the Public Health Education Section of the American
Public Health Association in 1982, and the Distinguished Faculty Achievement
Award from the University of Michigan in 1988. In 1987, he was elected to the
Institute of Medicine, National Academy of Sciences.
Notwithstanding these achievements, Marshall Becker will be remembered
as well for his extraordinary wit and humanity. His sense of humor was brilliant,
his concern for students unmatched, and his pursuit of academic excellence relentless. In addition to these gifts, the astonishing courage and steadfastness he
showed in the face of intractable illness was an inspiration to all who knew him.
As we mourn his death, our condolences go to his wife Felicia, son David, and
daughter Ruth.
Regent Brown read the following memorial statement in honor of Regent
Emeritus Eugene Power:
The Regents of the University of Michigan acknowledge with great sadness
the death of their friend and colleague, Eugene B. Power.
An ingenious businessman, "Gene" Power pioneered the application of
microfilm to the storage and reproduction of scholarly materials. The company


167




December Meeting, 1993


he founded, University Microfilms, became so successful it merged with the
Xerox Corporation, and both have since prospered.
Gene Power's contributions to education and the arts were legendary. He
was both a Regent of the University and president of the National Association of
College Governing Boards. He served on the board of the National Foundation
for the Arts and was the driving force behind the now firmly established Ann
Arbor Summer Festival. His philanthropies, too numerous to recount in their
entirety, included the enabling grant for the University's Power Center for the
Performing Arts and Power Exchange Scholarships, and the Power Island
Nature Conservancy in his old home town of Traverse City. He was also a man of
boundless energy, as all will attest who ventured into the water polo competition
that was a part of his weekly regimen.
Gene Power's legacy extends broadly and deeply:  to the industry he
founded, to the university he loved, to the community he served, and to the
family he shared. The Regents extend to that family, and especially to Gene's son
Philip, who so ably serves as a Regent himself, their heartfelt sympathy and condolences at this most difficult loss.
President Duderstadt called for a moment of silence in memory of Regent
Emeritus Power. He then noted the death of Charles Moore, the architect who
designed the North Campus Engineering Center.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.
On a motion by Regent Deitch, seconded by Regents Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved the remainder of the consent agenda as indicated above.
Estate of Helen F. Weber-Real Estate
The Regents were informed of the sale of a parcel of land in Republic Township, Marquette County (the N /2 of the NE 1/4 and the SW 1/4 of the NE /4,
Section 18, T47N, R30W), at a price of $22,500.
International Equity Investments
Regent Deitch moved, Regent Power seconded, and all seven Regents
present unanimously approved an increase in the allowable range for
international equity investments from 0 - 15 percent to 0 25 percent of the University Endowment Fund and participation in The Common Fund International
Equity Fund and The Common Fund Global Equity Fund. Because Norman
Herbert, the university treasurer, is both a University employee and a trustee of
The Common Fund, this arrangement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict
of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with
statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the contract will be the University of Michigan and The Common
Fund.
2.  The duration of the contract with The Common Fund will be open-ended. The
partnership will invest University Endowment Fund assets, and Norman
Herbert will attend meetings of the boards and related committees.


168




December Meeting, 1993


3.  Norman Herbert has no pecuniary interest in these contracts. The management fee for the International Equity Fund will be 1.00 percent of the first $5
million under management, 0.90 percent of the next $5 million, 0.85 percent of
the next $15 million, 0.80 percent of the next $25 million, and 0.75 percent of
the excess per annum. The management fee for the Global Equity Fund will be
0.85 percent of the first $5 million, 0.80 percent of the next $5 million, 0.70
percent of the next $15 million, 0.60 percent of the next $25 million, and 0.55
percent of the excess per annum.
Real Estate Investment
On a motion by Regent McGowan, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved commitment of $10 million of the University Endowment
Fund to Apartment Opportunity Fund II, pending the general counsel's review
of the partnership agreement for legal acceptability.
UM-Dearborn General Campus Renovation Project, Phase II; UMDearborn Campus Support Services Facility
Chancellor Renick reported that state funding had been approved for Phase
II of the University of Michigan-Dearborn General Campus Renovation Project.
The project will be divided into two components: the Center for Engineering
Education and Practice/Professional and Continuing Education component, and
the School of Management/Lecture Halls component. Mr. Fred Mayer, university
planner, described the proposed site and site plan, with the aid of maps and schematic drawings.
Mr. Mayer then described a proposed facility to house campus support services, to be finded from UM-Dearborn ftmds.
Following Mr. Mayer's presentation, Regent Waters moved approval of the
proposed sites for both the Center for Engineering Education Practice/Professional and Continuing Education segment and the School of Management/Lecture Halls segment of the UM-Dearborn's General Campus Renovation
Project Phase II. He also moved approval of the UM-Dearborn Campus Support
Services project and site and appointment of the firm of Ghafari Associates, Inc.,
as architect. Regent Power seconded the motions, and they were approved
unanimously.
Angell/Haven Hall Connector
Executive Vice President Womack called on Mr. Douglas Hanna, university
architect, to describe the proposed design for this project. Mr. Hanna described
the proposed site plan and design, with the aid of maps, schematic drawings, and
an architectural model. Following his presentation, several Regents expressed a
number of concerns about various aspects of the proposed design, including issues of safety, concern that the "tunnel" portion of the space would attract graffiti, and the shape and footprint of the building.
Following extensive discussion, it was decided to have the design group reconsider the proposed design, taking into account the concerns brought forward
during the discussion. President Duderstadt suggested that the designers present


169




December Meeting, 1993


several other conceptual design options of how to use the space, with arguments
for and against each option.
University of Michigan Visitors Center Project and Student Activities
Building Improvements
Executive Vice President Womack described this proposal to construct an
addition to the Student Activities Building (SAB) to serve as a visitors center,
and to make certain renovations and improvements to the Student Activities
Building in conjunction with this project. The new facility will be used as a
central point of arrival for visitors to the campus. On a motion by Regent Brown,
seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents unanimously approved the Visitors
Center project and site, the SAB window replacement project, and the appointment of Fry Associates, Inc., as the architect.
Diag Renovation
Mr. Fred Mayer gave a presentation describing a plan for the renovation of
the Diag that has been prepared by the University's planning consultants, Johnson Johnson & Roy/inc. The project would be completed in phases as sites and
funding become available. Following some discussion, Regent Deitch moved
approval of the design concept for the renovation of the Central Diag and
authorization for its implementation on a phased basis as sites and funding
become available. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was approved
unanimously.
Renovations
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent McFee, the Regents
unanimously approved the following renovation projects: 1) Medical Science II
Phases II-V remodeling for the Department of Microbiology and Immunology; 2)
North Ingalls Building courtyard infill for the Department of Surgery; 3) UMDearborn Student Services Center renovations; 4) Replacement of utility service
lines to the 300 North Ingalls Building; 5) Renovation of the domestic hot water
system at the UM Hospitals Taubman Center; and 6) Renovation of the UM
Hospitals Human Resources Employment Office.
Issuance of Hospital Revenue Bonds, Medical Service Plan Revenue
Bonds or Medical Service Plan Refunding Bonds in        amount not to
exceed $170,000,000
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent McFee, the Regents
unanimously approved the following resolution, authorizing the executive vice
president and chief financial officer to increase the size of the Hospital Revenue
Bonds, Medical Service Plan Revenue Bonds or Medical Service Plan Refunding
Bonds from $165,000,000 to $170,000,000 and provide the option to use derivatives in the proposed financing.

December Meeting, 1993


RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AMENDING RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY
OF HOSPITAL REVENUE BONDS AND MEDICAL SERVICE PLAN REVENUE
BONDS, AND PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS, on September 24, 1993, the Regents of the University of Michigan (the
"Issuer") adopted its Resolution Authorizing the Issuance and Delivery of Hospital Revenue
Bonds and Medical Service Plan Revenue Bonds, and Providing for Other Matters Relating
Thereto (the "Resolution"); and
WHEREAS, it is necessary and desirable to amend the Resolution as provided herein:
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:
1. The second "Whereas" clause of the Resolution is hereby amended to include within the
definition and description of the "Projects", the remodeling, renovation and equipping of space in
Medical Science II for the Department of Microbiology and Immunology and the acquisition,
construction, furnishing and equipping of an addition to the North Ingalls Building.
2. The eighth "Whereas" clause of the Resolution is hereby amended by changing the
amount in the seventh line from "One Hundred Sixty Five Million Dollars ($165,000,000)" to
"One Hundred Seventy Million Dollars ($170,000,000)".
3. Section 1 of the Resolution is hereby amended by changing the amount in the ninth line
of the first paragraph thereof from "$165,000,000" to "$170,000,000", and further, by adding at
the end thereof the following paragraph:
Any or all of the Hospital Bonds or the hospital revenue bonds authorized by
the May 7 Resolution may be made subject to tender for purchase at the option of the
holder thereof. The obligation of the Issuer to purchase any such bonds made subject
to tender options may be made payable from available cash reserves of the University, subject to limitation to the amount of certain assets of the Hospital, or may be
made payable from a letter of credit, line of credit or other liquidity device ("the
Hospital Liquidity Device"), all as shall be determined by an Authorized Officer and
provided for in the Series Indenture. Any reimbursement obligation for draws under
the Hospital Liquidity Device shall be a limited and not general obligation of the
Issuer, payable from Hospital Gross Revenues and may be secured by a pledge of
Pledged Hospital Gross Revenues. Either Authorized Officer is authorized to execute
and deliver, for and on behalf of the Issuer, any agreements or instruments necessary
to obtain, and provide for repayments under, any Hospital Liquidity Device deemed
by such officer to be required for the purposes of this Resolution. Purchase obligations shall not be considered as "principal and interest requirements" hereunder or
under the May 7 Resolution.
4. Section 2 of the Resolution is hereby amended by changing the amounts in the seventh,
ninth and thirty-fifth lines from "$125,000,000", "$165,000,000", and "$9,000,000", respectively,
to "$130,000,000", "$170,000,000", and "$9,500,000", respectively. Section 2 of the Resolution is
firther amended by adding at the end thereof the following paragraph:
Any or all of the MSP Bonds may be made subject to tender for purchase at the
option of the holder thereof. The obligation of the Issuer to purchase any such MSP
Bonds made subject to tender options may be made payable from available cash
reserves of the University, subject to limitation to the amount of certain assets of the
Medical Service Plan or the Medical School, or may be made payable from a letter of
credit, line of credit or other liquidity device (the "MSP Liquidity Device"), all as shall
be determined by an Authorized Officer and provided for in the MSP Indenture. Any
reimbursement obligation for draws under the MSP Liquidity Device shall be a limited and not general obligation of the Issuer payable from Medical Service Plan
Revenues and may be secured by a pledge of Medical Service Plan Revenues. Either
Authorized Officer is authorized to execute and deliver, for and on behalf of the
Issuer, any agreements or instruments necessary to obtain, and provide for


171




December Meeting, 1993


repayments under, any MSP Liquidity Device deemed by such officer to be required
for the purposes of this Resolution. Purchase obligations shall not be considered as
"principal and interest requirements" hereunder.
5. As amended hereby, the Resolution is hereby ratified and confirmed. All resolutions or
parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the Issuer in conflict herewith be and the same are
hereby repealed insofar as such conflict exists.
Agreement between the University of Michigan and Medox ElectroOptics, Inc.
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved an agreement between the University of Michigan and
Medox Electro-Optics, Inc., involving a project to investigate better methods of
optical switching in laser systems. Because the project director, Gerard Mourou,
is both an employee of the University and a shareholder in Medox Electro-Optics,
Inc., this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute.
The   following   information    is  provided   in  compliance    with   statutory
requirements:
1.   The parties to the agreement will be the Regents of the University of Michigan
and Medox Electro-Optics, Inc.
2.   The agreement will provide support for one graduate student research assistant
for twelve months and indirect cost at 56 percent. Dr. Mourou will directly
advise and assist the graduate student but will receive no salary from this
contract. The agreement will be consistent with standard University research
policies.
3.   In addition to Dr. Mourou's stock ownership he receives compensation as a
consultant to the company, reimbursement for attendance at meetings and
participates in profit-sharing. He will not be compensated outside of his University salary for services related specifically to this project.
Agreement between the University of Michigan and Science and Environmental Education - NORTH (SEE-NORTH)
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved an agreement between the University of Michigan and
Science and Environmental Education - NORTH (SEE-NORTH) to conduct a
joint research project. Because the project director, Mary J. Whitmore, is both a
University of Michigan employee and executive director of SEE-NORTH, this
agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The
following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and
Science and Environmental Education -NORTH (SEE-NORTH).
2.   The agreement will be a standard Michigan subcontract for one year in the
amount of $34,726. The prime award from the Michigan Department of Education is for one year in the amount of $60,259. The proposed subcontract will
detail the scope of work and the budget.
3.   Dr. Whitmore will not be compensated outside of her University salary for this
project. However, as executive director, she will receive compensation from
SEE-NORTH.


172




December Meeting, 1993


Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and
Skills, Inc.
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved a license agreement between the University of Michigan
and Skills, Inc. ("Skills"). Because Carl Rinne, the developer of the technology for
which Skills intends to develop products and services (the "Technology"), is both
a shareholder in Skills and a University employee, this agreement falls under the
state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is
provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the contract will be the University of Michigan and Skills, a corporation owned in part by Professor Carl Rinne.
2.   Terms of the contract include: a non-exclusive license of unlimited duration;
consideration to the University consisting of the payment of royalties, including
modest minimum annual requirements, on products incorporating the Technology, and a share of sublicensing revenues received by Skills. Skills will pay the
University royalties at a rate of 8 percent for products sold during the first five
years and 4 percent for products sold during the second five years (considered
paid up at the end of ten years). Skills will also pay the University 25 percent of
any sublicensing revenues Skills receives. Minimum royalties shall be $100 in
1994, $200 in 1995, and $300 each year thereafter. The University retains ownership of all Technology. The University retains the right to use the Technology
for research, teaching, and other educationally-related purposes and may
license it to other parties (since this is a non-exclusive license to Sldlls). Skills
shall use reasonable efforts to effectively pursue the commercial development
and exploitation of the Technology covered by the proposed license agreement.
There is no use of facilities or services of the University included in the contract
and no assignment of University employees for fulfillment of the contract.
3.   The pecuniary interest of Professor Rinne in the contract arises from his
ownership of shares of Skdlls. This equity interest will be in lieu of participation
in the sharing of royalties received by the University, in accordance with
standard University policy.
Standard Assignment Agreement with Kemp B. Cease and Cortland J.
Lohff
This item was withdrawn from the table.
Resolution in Honor of Clinton B. Jones
In honor of the retirement of Chancellor Clinton B. Jones, Regent McFee
offered the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan are pleased to salute
and commend Clinton B. Jones as he concludes his term as chancellor of the University of Michigan-Flint.
Clinton Jones came to Flint in 1984 following his service as vice
chancellor for academic affairs at the University of HoustonDowntown. He has been the fourth and longest-serving chief


173




December Meeting, 1993


executive officer of this thriving young campus, his term having extended for more than nine years. Those nine years have been marked
by unprecedented growth and development, not only in the campus'
physical facilities, but in its programs and enrollment as well. The
physical plant has more than doubled in size, and with the completion of the new library facility it will provide the Flint community
with a total campus environment of unmatched beauty and
functionality.
But most important of all has been Clinton Jones' ability to
build bridges to the community, so that the campus has become not
only a focal point of community pride, but a powerful resource for
individual growth and learning that has inspired and challenged
young and old alike to become all that they can be. Throughout his
tenure, Chancellor Jones has been cited repeatedly by community
organizations for his dedication to the city of Flint. Fortunately, that
dedicated effort will continue, as he will continue to serve in his
faculty capacity as professor of political science.
In recognition of his exemplary service, and with deep appreciation and warm best wishes, the Regents now name Clinton B. Jones
chancellor emeritus of the University of Michigan-Flint.
The motion was adopted by acclamation.
There being no firther business, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting will be held on January 20 and 21, 1994. Regents' expenses for the
month of November 1993 totalled $1,659.71.

JANUARY MEETING, 1994


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, January 20, 1994
The Regents met at 1:15 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan Union
for a panel discussion on the Michigan economy, the state budget, and the outlook for state support for higher education in the coming year. Present were
President Duderstadt and Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power,
Varner, and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, Provost Whitaker,
Executive Vice President Womack, and Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison,
Hartford, and Neal were also present, as were Interim         Chancellor Kugler and
Chancellor Renick. Regent Baker was absent. Participants in the discussion included Professors Ned Gramlich and Paul Courant; Mr. Gary Olson, director of
the Senate Fiscal Agency; and Senators John Schwarz and Lana Pollack.
The discussion concluded at 3:35 p.m., and after a short break, the Regents
reassembled for their regular business meeting.
Regular Business Meeting
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order at 3:45 p.m. and welcomed
Lawrence Kugler, interim chancellor of UM-Flint, to his first Regents' Meeting.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Consideration of the minutes for the December 1993 meeting was
delayed until the next meeting.

purchases over $2,000. Vice President Neal submitted reports of projects established and summaries of a selection of current research.

NEW APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS
OF REGULAR ASSOCIATE AND FULL PROFESSOR RANKS,
WITH TENURE
