Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted the following retirement memoirs:
Jerome M. Clubb, professor of history in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts and research scientist in the Center for Political Studies, Institute for Social Research, retired from active faculty status on January 15, 1994.
A native of Washington, Professor Clubb received his B.A, M.A, and Ph.D.
degrees from the University of Washington in 1955, 1957, and 1963, respectively.
He was a faculty member at Bowling Green State University from 1961-66. He
joined the Center for Political Studies as a research associate in 1966 and was
promoted to program director in 1970 and research scientist in 1973. He was
named lecturer in history in 1968 and was promoted to associate professor in
1971 and professor in 1973. Professor Clubb also served as executive director of
the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) from
1975-91.
Professor Clubb was a pioneer in introducing quantitative techniques of
analysis to history. Through his extensive research and publications, he demonstrated that quantitative data adds precision to historical interpretations and often yields findings that are contrary to conventional wisdom. He showed that
partisan realignment followed rather than preceded critical elections in American
history, and that political elites played a crucial role in initiating realignments by
leading, rather than responding to, shifts in voter attitudes. His championing of
quantitative techniques of analysis has had an important impact on historical
studies.
As executive director of the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research, Professor Clubb shaped the social sciences globally. He expanded
the disciplinary scope of ICPSR, adding history, sociology, and social work as full
partners with political science, the consortium's founding discipline. He greatly
expanded the services that ICPSR provides to support research. During his tenure as executive director, the consortium's membership greatly increased, and its
budget grew from $1.1 million to more than $3.6 million.
Professor Clubb served on numerous national and international social science advisory boards and was a founder and president of the Social Science History Association. In 1992, he was honored by being appointed to the University's
Senior Research Scientist Lectureship.
The Regents salute this distinguished scholar by naming Jerome M. Clubb
professor emeritus of history and research scientist emeritus.
Eugene E. Dekker, professor of biological chemistry in the Medical
School, retired from active faculty status on December 31, 1993, after a most productive career as a teacher and researcher.
A native of Indiana, Professor Dekker received his AB. degree from Calvin
College in 1949 and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in 1951 and 1954, respectively,
from the University of Illinois. From 1954-56, he was an instructor in the
Department of Biological Chemistry at the University of Louisville Medical


188




January Meeting, 1994


School Professor Dekker came to the University of Michigan in 1956 as an
instructor of biological chemistry. He was promoted to assistant professor in
1958, associate professor in 1965, and professor in 1970.
Over the years, Professor Dekker has been an invaluable faculty member in
the Department of Biological Chemistry. An excellent teacher, he served as
director of several departmental courses and in 1978 was awarded the Amoco
Good Teaching Award. From 1975-88, Professor Dekker served as assistant, then
associate chair of the Department of Biological Chemistry. He also provided valuable leadership as acting chair of the department in both 1978 and 1985.
Professor Dekker has had thirty-three consecutive years of research support
by the National Institutes of Health for mammalian and bacterial studies on the
chemistry, metabolism, and enzymology of amino acids, the characterization of
new   enzymes,   and   establishing  enzyme  structure/function/regulation
interrelations. He also received ten years of support from the U.S. Department of
Agriculture and five years from the National Science Foundation for studies on
nitrogen assimilation by, unusual amino acid metabolism in, and characterization of novel enzymes from plants. Professor Dekker was also awarded three
separate National Institutes of Health special research fellowships for sabbatical
leaves.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his dedicated
service by naming Eugene E. Dekker professor emeritus of biological chemistry.
Edwin J. Thomas, Fedele F. Fauri Professor of Social Work in the School
of Social Work and professor of psychology in the College of Literature, Science,
and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on December 31, 1993, after 40
years of service to the University of Michigan.
A native of Flint, Professor Thomas obtained his A.B. and M.S.W. degrees in
1951 and 1953, respectively, from Wayne University, and his Ph.D. degree in social psychology from the University of Michigan in 1956. After serving as a research assistant at the Research Center for Group Dynamics from 1953-56, he
joined the faculty in 1956 as assistant professor of social work in the School of
Social Work and assistant professor of psychology in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts. Professor Thomas was promoted to associate professor in
both disciplines in 1959 and to professor in 1963 and was named the Fedele F.
Fauri Professor of Social Work in 1986.
Professor Thomas is recognized as a leading scholar in the areas of behavior
modification and intervention research, with particular emphasis on role theory
and group behavior. His recent research has focused on unilateral therapy with
the spouses and families of alcohol abusers. He has published an impressive body
of articles and books, many of which have been translated into foreign languages.
He has been a visiting professor at the University of Bradford in England and
LaTrobe University in Australia.
In the School of Social Work, Professor Thomas served as head of the doctoral program in social work and social science, chair of the supervising committee for the doctoral program, and for many years as head of the human behavior
and social environment area of the school's curriculum. He also was primarily responsible for the introduction and integration of social science knowledge into
the master's program in social work Professor Thomas' retirement marks the


189




January Meeting, 1994


departure of an esteemed member of the faculty of the School of Social Work who
was devoted to the development and refinement of intervention theories and
techniques, empirically based practice, and assessments.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Edwin J. Thomas
the Fedele F. Fauri Professor Emeritus of Social Work and professor emeritus of
psychology.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved the remainder of the consent agenda as listed above.
Finance-Property
Executive Vice President Womack presented proposals for investing portions of the University Endowment Fund in three specific funds specializing in
each of three different investment vehicles: alternative fixed income investments, real estate investments, and venture capital investments. Following some
discussion, the Regents took the following action with respect to investment of
the University Endowment Fund:
Alternative Fixed Income Investments
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved commitment of $15 million of the University Endowment
Fund to Summit Subordinated Debt Fund, L.P., pending the general counsel's
review of the partnership documents for legal acceptability.
Real Estate Investment
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
unanimously approved commitment of $10 million of the University Endowment
Fund to Argo Partnership (plus an additional $1 million made available as a reserve amount), pending the general counsel's review of the partnership agreement for legal acceptability.
Venture Capital Investment
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved commitment of $5 million of the University Endowment
Fund to China Walden Venture Investments Ltd., pending the outcome of the
general counsel's review of the documents for legal acceptability.
Integrated Technology Instruction Center (ITIC)
Executive Vice President Womack informed the Regents that Ellis-Don
Michigan, Inc., had submitted the lowest bid for construction of the Integrated
Technology Instruction Center and had therefore been awarded the construction
contract.


190




January Meeting, 1994


Public Comments
The Regents heard comments from Dennis Denno, president of Students for
Dr. Jack Kevorkian, on a proposal for awarding an honorary degree to Dr. Kevorkian at the May 1994 commencement.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned at 4:05 p.m.
The next meeting will be held on February 17 and 18, 1994. Regents' expenses
for the month of December 1993 totalled $1,040.46.
Richard LKenney, Seetary


191




FEBRUARY MEETING, 1994


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, February 17, 1994
The Regents met at 3:10 p.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, and
Varner. Provost Whitaker was also present, as were Executive Vice President
Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, and Interim
Chancellor Kugler. Regent Waters, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and
Chancellor Renick were absent.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and recognized Regent
McGowan, who made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Section 8(e) of the Open Meetings Act, as amended
by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed
session on February 17, 1994, in the Regents' Room, for the purpose
of consulting with our attorney regarding trial or settlement strategy
in connection with specific pending litigation.
Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously. The
meeting then continued in executive session.
Public Comments
The Regents assembled at 4:00 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan
Union and heard comments from the following individuals, on the topics indicated: Craig Greenberg, president of MSA, Brian Kight, vice president of MSA,
Vincent Keenan, chair of MSA Student Rights Commission, and Aaron Williams,
citizen, on the Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities; Marcia Federbush, citizen, Bob Darden, head coach, Sue Rottman, citizen, and Paul Bischoff,
student, on the men's gymnastics program; and James A Shields, citizen, on
miscellaneous topics.
At 5:00 p.m., following Public Comments, the Regents returned to the Regents' Room to continue meeting in executive session.
Friday, February 18, 1994
The Regents met at 9:35 am. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power,
Varner, and Waters. Provost Whitaker was also present, as were Executive Vice
President Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim Chancellor Kugler, and Chancellor Renick Vice President and Secretary
Kennedy was absent.


193




February Meeting, 1994


President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and noted that Vice President Kennedy's absence was due to surgery he had had the previous day, and
that his recovery was going very well.
Regent Baker stated he had recently been a patient in the University Hospitals for a serious illness. He noted that, as one who had been involved in the
original hospitals' planning and subsequent hospitals' policy-making over several
years, there was a great difference between being a patient and being a policy
maker. Regent Baker expressed his thanks to all of the employees of the University of Michigan Hospitals who make it the wonderful institution that it is, from
those who sweep the floors, to the administrators, and to the medical staffe
1994-95 Residence Hall and Family Housing Rates
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Hartford to present the recommendation for 1994-95 residence hall and family housing rates. Vice President
Hartford reported that both the residence hall and family housing student-staff
rate committees had met and recommended rate increases of 3&95 percent for
residence halls and 3.30 percent for family housing apartments.
In response to a question from Regent McFee, it was noted that the residence hall occupancy rate is currently at 98.30 percent. Then, there being no further discussion, Regent McGowan moved approval of a rate increase of 3.95
percent for residence halls and 3.30 percent for family housing apartments for
1994-95. Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Regent Brown was away from the table when the vote was taken.
Audited Financial Reports for WUOM/WVGR/WFUM-FM and WFUMTV for Fiscal Year Ended June 30, 1993; and, WFUM-TV and
WUOM/WVG/WFUM-FM Statements of Support, Revenue and Expenditures (Operating Fund) for Years Ended June 30, 1993 and 1992
Vice President Harrison reported that a review of WUOM/WVGR/WFUMFM (collectively known as "Michigan Radio") had been undertaken over the past
six months, conducted by Mr. Frank Williams, director of strategic planning in
the Office of University Relations; Mr. Jim Beck, director of marketing communications; and Mr. Joel Seguine, station manager of WUOM. Vice President Harrison, Mr. Williams, and Mr. Seguine then gave a presentation on the results of the
review.
Vice President Harrison stated that the reasons for the review were recurring budget deficits and concern about the slow growth in listener contributions
over the last five years, and increasing competition from both commercial and
other public radio stations for market share. Mr. Williams and Mr. Seguine presented the major findings of the review as well as the next steps that will be undertaken to ensure a robust future for Michigan Radio. Vice President Harrison
announced that WUOM will resume coverage of Michigan football beginning in
the fall of 1994.
Vice President Harrison, Mr. Seguine, and Mr. Williams responded to questions and comments from   the Regents about the report. Following some


194




February Meeting, 1994


discussion, Regent Power moved adoption of the audited financial reports for
WUOM/WVGR/WFUM-FM and WFUM-TV for the fiscal year ended June 30,
1993. Regent Varner seconded the motion, and it was adopted. Regents Deitch
and McGowan were away from the table when the vote was taken.

Retirement Memoir. Provost Whitaker submitted the following retirement memoir:
Larry Selinker, professor of linguistics, retired from active faculty status
on December 31, 1993, following a sixteen-year career at the University of
Michigan.
Professor Selinker received his B.A degree in Near Eastern Studies from
Brandeis University in 1959 and his M.A. degree in linguistics from The American University in 1960. He completed his Ph.D. degree in languages and linguistics at Georgetown University in 1966. From 1966-75, he was assistant professor
of linguistics and director of English for foreign students at the University of
Washington. He served as a Fulbright scholar at Hebrew University from
1975-76 and was on the faculty of San Jose State University from 1976-77. Professor Selinker came to the University of Michigan in 1977 as professor of linguistics with tenure and director of the English Language Institute. He served in
the latter position until 1982.
Professor Selinker was awarded his first Fulbright professorship at the Uniersity of Edinburgh in 1968-69, where he focused on psycholinguistics related to
second language learnng. In 1975-76, he was a Fulbright professor in English
Linguistics at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, where he specialized in advanced
reading in a second language for professional needs. In 1991, he received a Faculty Recognition Fund Award from the Graduate School, and that same year he
also served as a visiting professor of moder languages at Carnegie Mellon University. In 1992, Professor Selinker completed his third Fulbright professorship
at Gesamthochschule Kassel Universitaet in Germany.
Although his primary appointment was in the English Language Institute,
Professor Selinker was also on the faculty of the Department of Linguistics,
where he specialized in second language acquisition and interlanguage theory. In
recent years, he taught a popular undergraduate course, "The Good and Bad
Language Learner."
Professor Selinker is well known for his paper, "Language Transfer," which
first appeared in General Linguistics in 1969 and has since been reprinted in a
number of other journals and collections. His most recent books include Rediscovering Interlanguage (1992) and, with Susan Gass, a revised edition of Language Transfer in Language Learning (1992).
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Larry Selinker professor emeritus of linguistics.


209




February Meeting, 1994


Memorial Statement. Provost Whitaker submitted the following memorial statement:
The Regents of the University of Michigan acknowledge with profound sadness the death on January 27, 1994, of Daniel Thoburn Snyder, professor of
dentistry.
Dr. Snyder was born in Indiana, Pennsylvania, on April 5, 1931. He received
his DoD.S. degree in 1962 and his M.S. degree in restorative dentistry in 1967,
both from the University of Michigan. He joined the faculty at the University of
Michigan School of Dentistry as a clinical instructor in 1962 and proceeded
through the ranks to reach full professor in 1974. Dr. Snyder also served as interim assistant dean for clinical affairs from 1988-91.
A devoted member of the dental profession, Dr. Snyder served as practitioner, clinician, lecturer, author, editor, and administrator. He was a mentor
and friend to many, having served for several years as a sponsor of the Christian
Medical/Dental Society. He also had been an active member of the Hemophilia
Foundation of Michigan since 1966. Dr. Snyder's memberships in professional
societies included the executive board of the American Board of Operative Den~
tistry, Omicron Kappa Upsilon, and the Society of Sigma Xi.
Daniel Snyder left an enduring mark on his students and colleagues, both
through his professional accomplishments and his personal qualities of modesty,
dedication, and quiet dignity. We mourn the loss of this distinguished scholar
and teacher and our condolences go to his wife Shirley, his three children, Stephen, Mark, and Bethel, and five grandchildren, Skylar, Kelsey, Stephanie,
Amanda, and Jennifer.

portfolio.

executive vice president and chief financial officer to increase the amount of the
Hospital Revenue Bonds, Medical Service Plan Revenue Bonds, and Medical
Service Plan Refunding Bonds from  $170,000,000 to $221,000,000. Regent

unanimously. The following is the text of the approved resolution:
RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AMENDING RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY
OF HOSPITAL REVENUE BONDS AND MEDICAL SERVICE PLAN REVENUE
BONDS, AND PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS, on September 24, 1993, the Regents of the University of Michigan (the "Issuer") adopted its Resolution Authorizing the Issuance and Delivery of Hospital Revenue Bonds
and Medical Service Plan Revenue Bonds, and Providing for Other Matters Relating Thereto,
which Resolution was amended on December 17, 1993 (as amended, the "Resolution"); and
WHEREAS, it is necessary and desirable to further amend the Resolution as provided
herein:
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:


211




February Meeting, 1994


1. The second "Whereas" clause of the Resolution is hereby amended to include within the
definition and description of the "Projects", the acquisition, construction, furnishing and equipping of the North Entrance Parking Structure and the undertaking of building component and
equipment replacement and facilities renovations at the Hospital in the current and the two succeeding fiscal years.
2. The eighth 'Whereas" clause of the Resolution is hereby amended by changing the
amount in the seventh line from "One Hundred Seventy Million Dollars ($170,000,000)" to "Two
Hundred Twenty-One Million Dollars ($221,000,000)".
3. Section 1 of the Resolution is hereby amended by changing the amount in the seventh
line of the first paragraph thereof from "$65,000,000" to "$114,000,000", the amount in the
ninth line of the first paragraph thereof from "$170,000,000" to "$221,000,000", and the amount
in the thirty-fourth line thereof from "$10,000,000" to "$25,100,000"o
4. Section 2 of the Resolution is hereby amended by changing the amount in the ninth line
from "$170,000,000" to $221,000,000".
5. As amended hereby, the Resolution is hereby ratified and confirmed. All resolutions or
parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the Issuer in conflict herewith be and the same are
hereby repealed insofar as such conflict exists.
Resolution in Honor of Jack Weidenbach
Regent McFee read the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan gratefully
acknowledge the dedication and service of Jack Weidenbach as he
concludes a 28-year career at the University.
Jack first came to the University in 1966 and for 22 years held
an impressive array of positions, all of which were critical to the
University's daily operation and the development of its physical
plant. From his initial appointment as manager of Willow Run
Airport, he advanced to director of plant extension (1968), director of
physical properties (1971), and finally to director of business
operations (1977). In the latter position, he oversaw the building and
maintenance of the University's physical plant and the related areas
of purchasing, public safety, and occupational safety and
environmental health.
A quiet, self-effacing man, Jack directed the explosive growth of
the campus through some of the most turbulent periods in the
University's history while never missing a step-a gentle giant to be
sure.
And then in June of 1988, at a time when he could have been
looking ahead to a quiet life of retirement, Jack was instead thrust
into the spotlight of intercollegiate athletics when he assumed the
post of associate athletic director. Jack's accomplishments in that
post and in his subsequent positions as interim director (1990), then


212




February Meeting, 1994


director (1991) of athletics have had a phenomenal impact on both
the programs and the physical facilities of the athletic department.
He has worked tirelessly to improve academic support programs for
student athletes and to strengthen women's intercollegiate athletics
to the point where true equal opportunity is now within reach. By not
only maintaining, but enhancing the tradition of Michigan athletics,
Jack proved to be a worthy successor to his illustrious predecessors.
Under his stewardship, the athletic program achieved new heights of
excellence and national recognition in many areas.
Few people have had as broad an impact on the University as
has Jack Weidenbach. In recognition of his distinguished
contributions to the University, to the athletic department, and to the
lives of its faculty, staff, and students, the Regents now name John
P. (Jack) Weidenbach Director Emeritus of Athletics.
The motion was approved by acclamation.

Joint Venture with Foote Memorial Hospital in a Radiation Oncology
Program
Executive Vice President Womack observed that this opportunity, for the
University to establish a radiation oncology service in Jackson, will be beneficial
both to Foote Memorial Hospital and the University. It represents the kind of
networking that will be the model for such activities in the future, and more such
arrangements are anticipated with other hospitals.


213




February Meeting, 1994


Regent Deitch expressed enthusiastic support for the proposal and moved
approval of the capital investment and participation by the University through
the University of Michigan Medical Center in the Foote-University Radiation Oncology joint venture under the terms and conditions described in the Regents
Communication. Regent McGowan seconded the motion. A discussion followed,
during which Regent Power observed he shared Regent Deitch's enthusiasm for
this and other similar proposals and Executive Vice President Womack responded to questions. Regent Baker asked that the Regents be allowed to review
the final agreement before it is signed. The vote was taken and the motion was
approved unanimously.
Agreements between the University of Michigan and the William
Davidson Institute at the School of Business Administration
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent McFee, the Regents
unanimously approved a lease agreement and an administrative services agreement between the University of Michigan and the William Davidson Institute.
Because B. Joseph White, who will execute the agreements, is both president of
the William Davidson Institute and dean of the School of Business Administration, this arrangement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statuteo The following information is provided in compliance with statutory
requirements:
1.   Parties to both the Lease Agreement and the Administrative Services Agreement will be the University of Michigan and the William Davidson Institute at
the University of Michigan School of Business Administration.
2.   Terms of the Lease Agreement: Rental of 1607 sq. ft. on the ninth floor of the
School of Business Administration plus classroom and other meeting spaces at
the School assigned by the dean's office or other delegated offices of the school
at a rate of $18.00/sq. ft. or $28,927.00 annually, payable in two equal installments on September 1 and March 1 of each year. The duration of the Lease
Agreement will be three years commencing on September 1, 1993, and terminating on August 31, 1996.
The University will provide for housekeeping and custodial services and other
interior maintenance of the leased premises through its normal custodial and
service employees with appropriate recharges.
Terms of the Administrative Services Agreement: The duration of the Administrative Services Agreement will be five years, from January 1, 1994, through
December 31, 1998, with services charged at the same rate for University departments and employees.
The University will provide University support facilities and services in the areas of financial, telephone directory listing, mail services, purchasing, stores,
computer network access and related services, printing, copying and similar
services, the opportunity to purchase athletic tickets and recreational facilities
passes and parking permits, the use of University library facilities, the purchase
of University training or Human Resources Development programs, the use of
any services provided by the University's International Center, the use of any
services provided by the University Faculty and Staff Assistance Program and
the joint appointment of employees and appropriate sharing of payroll and staff
benefits assistance concerning employees. University employees will be provided as appropriate to render such support services and facilities to the institute and its employees.


214




February Meeting, 1994


3.   B. Joseph White has no pecuniary interest arising from his position as the
president of the William Davidson Institute at the University of Michigan
School of Business Administration or by virtue of the above agreements.
Proposed Research Contract.between the University of Michigan and
Therapeutic Systems Research Laboratories, Inc. (TSRL)
Regent Varner moved, Regent Waters seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved a research contract between the University of Michigan and
Therapeutic Systems Research Laboratories, Inc. (TSRL, Inc.). Because the
president of TSRL, Inc., Gordon L. Amidon, is also a University employee, this
arrangement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The
following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the contract will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and
TSRL, Inc.
2.   The contract to be signed is the University's standard research contract. The
University will be paid $168,150 in direct costs and $67,407 in indirect costs for
a two year project. The indirect cost amount reflects the University's full indirect cost rate.
3.   Professor Amidon's financial interest arises from his ownership of TSRL.
Proposed Subcontract between the University of Michigan and COSMic Co.
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent McGowan, the Regents
unanimously approved a subcontract between the University of Michigan and
COSMic Co. Because the owner of COSMic Co., Alfred L. Nuttall, is also a University employee, this arrangement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of
Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement will be COSMic Co. ("Company") and the Regents of
the University of Michigan.
2.   The proposed agreement is a standard University research contract. There are
no restrictions on publication or openness of the research.
The subcontract will cover partial salary costs for a research associate, instrument maker, and graduate student and equipment charges, all totaling $16,814
over a six-month period. Dr. Nuttall will supervise the project and act as project
director. Dr. Nuttall will not be reimbursed by the Company for his time on the
project as a University employee. No indirect cost will be charged since this is
an SBIR Phase I project.
3.   Dr. Nuttall is the president of the Company, serves without compensation, and
owns 100 percent of the Company.
Proposed Research Subcontract between the University of Michigan
and the Technical University in Munich, an Educational Institution in
Germany
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents approved a research subcontract between the University of Michigan and the


215




February Meeting, 1994


Technical University in Munich to complete a portion of a project fimded by a
grant from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute entitled "Evaluation of
Cardiac Autonomic Innervations by Positron Emission Tomography (PET)". Regent Baker abstained from voting due to a conflict of interest.
The original principal investigator of the project, Markus Schwaiger, has
since left the University of Michigan to accept a position with the Technical University in Munich. However, he remains a key collaborator and plans to continue
his participation through a subcontract issued by the National Institute of Heart,
Lung, and Blood Institute. Because Dr. Schwaiger is an adjunct professor, without remuneration, at the University of Michigan, this arrangement falls under
the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is
provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the subcontract will be the Technical University in Munich and the
Regents of the University of Michigan.
2.  The subcontract will obligate the Technical University in Munich to complete a
portion of the research project. The subcontract will cover work from June 1,
1993, through January 31, 1995, and will be in the amount of $110,687. It is expected that the agreement will be continued for an additional two years, at comparable funding levels, subject to continued funding from the National Heart,
Lung, and Blood Institute. The specific scope of work and detailed budget will
be set forth in the subcontract.
3.  Professor Schwaiger does not and will not receive a salary or other pecuniary
benefit from the University of Michigan during the life of the project.
Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities Report of Judicial
Activity
The Regents received a report of judicial activity under the Statement of
Student Rights and Responsibilities for the period January 1, 1993, to February
1, 1994.
Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities
Vice President Hartford reported that a good deal of interest had been expressed in changing the Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities, and
the statement is difficult to amend. Because of her desire to work with the interested parties in amending some of the language in the statement, she was changing her original recommendation that the Regents approve the Statement of
Student Rights and Responsibilities as a permanent policy. She now was recommending that the policy be continued as an interim University policy until April
1995. Because the Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities is a new policy, it is expected that amendments to change it will be proposed in the future.
Regents McGowan expressed her appreciation to Vice President Hartford
for her flexibility in accommodating the desires of students and others to retain
the policy as an interim policy for the time being. Regent McFee agreed that this
would allow an additional opportunity for the student body to have more input
into the amendment process, and she commended the constructive, supportive
manner in which students have sought to make modifications.


216




February Meeting, 1994


Regent Baker stated that he would vote against extending the policy as an
interim policy, as his position has not changed.
Regent Power moved to extend the Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities as an interim policy until April 1995, during which time modifications will be sought and proposed. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it
was approved, with Regents Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, Varner,
and Waters in favor and Regent Baker opposed.
Implementation of the Regents' Policy on Research Grants, Contracts,
and Agreements, FY 1993
Vice President Neal submitted a report of the implementation of the Regents' Policy on Research Grants, Contracts, and Agreements for Fiscal Year
1993.
Changes in Bylaws, Rules and Regulations of the Medical Staff
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved recommendations by the University of Michigan Hospitals Executive Board for changes in the Medical Staff Bylaws, Rules, and
Regulations.
Medical Staff Appointments
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Brown, and on the recommendation of the University of Michigan Hospitals Executive Board, the Regents unanimously approved certain specified appointments to medical staff
membership.
Sale of $12,000,000 Regents of the University of Michigan Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993
The Regents were informed of the sale of $12,000,000 Regents of the University of Michigan Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993 to Chemical Securities
Inc.

by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed
session on February 18, 1994, in the Regents' Room, immediately
following the end of this meeting, for the purpose of consulting with
our attorney regarding trial or settlement strategy in connection with
specific pending litigation.
Regent Deitch seconded the motion, and it was adopted unanimously.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned at 10:55 am.,
after which the meeting continued in executive session. The next meeting will be

held on March 10 and 11, 1994. Regents' expenses for the month of January

218




MARCH MEETING, 1994


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, March 10, 1994
The Regents met at 1:30 p.m. in the Music Room of the Henry Ford EstateFair Lane. Present were President Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown,
McFee, McGowan, Power, and Varner. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy
was also present, as were Executive Vice President Womak, Vice Presidents
Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim Chancellor Kugler, and Chancellor Renick. Regent Waters and Provost Whitaker were absent; Associate Vice
President Holbrook attended in the place of Provost Whitaker. Regent Deitch arrived at about 2:25 p.m.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and thanked Chancellor
Renick for hosting the Regents' Meeting on the Dearborn campus. He also welcomed back Vice President Kennedy. He then recognized Regent Brown, who
made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Section 8(e) of the Open Meetings Act, as amended
by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed
session on March 11, 1994, at 9:00 a.m., in the Regents' Room, for
the purpose of consulting with our attorney regarding trial or
settlement strategy in connection with specific pending litigation.
Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Annual Report on Investments
Executive Vice President Womack called on Mr. Norman Herbert, university treasurer and investment officer, Ms. Elizabeth Hokada, associate investment officer, and Ms. Maggie Blakelock, of Cambridge Associates, Inc., to present
the report on investments as of December 31, 1993. Executive Vice President
Womack observed that 1993 had been an outstanding year for the University's
Endowment Fund, with a 17.5 percent rate of return.
Mr. Herbert observed that all of the University's funds in 1993 had exceeded
the benchmarks that had been identified, and he gave details of the returns and
individual strategies that had been used for each of the funds. Mr. Herbert
observed that the long term goal for the endowment fund is to protect both the
purchasing power of the endowment principal as well as the stream of distributions that is provided for by the gift itself. In 1993, ten percentage points of real
value had been added to the portfolios of the various accounts in the endowment
fund, and on a ten-year basis, 2.4 percent per annum of value had been added to
each of the participating endowment accounts. He described the importance of
this result to the individual units with investments in the endowment fund.


219




March Meeting, 1994


Mr. Herbert acknowledged the contributions of both the Investment Advisory Committee and Cambridge Associates to the strong performance of the
Endowment Fund. He then introduced Ms. Blakelock, of Cambridge Associates,
Inc., to review the endowment strategy and performance and to introduce
proposed changes in the investment strategy for the University Investment Pool.
Ms. Blakelock referred to separately bound discussion materials from Cambridge Associates, Inc., in reviewing the endowment's strategy and performance.
She reviewed the University's current investment strategy and reported that the
University had achieved a number of its strategic goals with regard to asset allocation, common stock management, and fixed income management strategies.
She then outlined changes that would occur as the University pursued the next
steps in this strategy. Ms. Blakelock observed that the value of the endowment of
$911.8 million as of December 31, 1993 was up $227.5 million from December 31,
1992, and described specific asset allocation and performance factors associated
with that increase in value. She also presented data that compared the University's asset allocation and investment performance with that of other educational
institutions and reviewed a chart that showed trends in the University's investment performance over the past four years.
Ms. Blakelock, Mr. Herbert, and Executive Vice President Womack responded to questions and comments from the Regents about details of the report.
In response to a question from Regent Baker about the University's equity investments, Ms. Blakelock stated that the University intends to maintain its goal
of 70 percent in equity investments, but that the composition of the 70 percent
will change over time so as to have a more diversified portfolio. She and Mr.
Herbert explained that the strategy is to move towards a goal of 50 percent of the
equity investment in stocks and the balance in alternative assets, such as real
estate, oil and gas, and venture capital.
Regent Power commented on the historical significance of the fact that the
performance of all of the University's invested funds had exceeded their targets
for the calendar year 1993. He extended his compliments to Executive Vice President Womack, his staff, and Cambridge Associate, Inc., for this remarkable
performance.
University Investment Pool: Internal Bank Concept
Ms. Blakelock stated that she would be introducing the concept of the
"internal bank" to lay the framework for the specific investment proposal that
was being presented to the Regents as a discussion item. Referring to the handout from Cambridge Associates, Inc., Ms. Blakelock described the concept of the
internal bank, which invests residual cash from an institution's operating finds,
and makes distributions to "depositors" (departments) based on short-term
rates. The University would retain the difference between the actual total return
and the short-term rates paid to the depositors as a reserve to guarantee the
"depositors" no principal loss.
There followed extensive discussion about the internal bank concept. Mr.
Herbert observed that the intent is to implement the policy over a period of 5-10


220




March Meeting, 1994


years in order to be able to build a reserve so that participants in the University
Investment Pool can be assured that they will be able to take a dollar out for
every dollar deposited. Executive Vice President Womack pointed out that
another reason to implement the policy gradually is to dollar-cost average into
the various investment vehicles. This approach will help avoid a possibly negative
impact on the endowment fund.
In response to a question from Regent Power, the discussion shifted to the
distribution rate for the endowment fund. Executive Vice President Womack
pointed out that this topic is related to, but not a part of, the internal bank
concept. He stated that discussions have been held among his staff about the
need to reduce the payout rate for the endowment to less than the current 5.5
percent that was set in 1987. He and Mr. Herbert reported that the notion would
be to reduce the distribution rate over time, but emphasized that that decision is
unrelated to the internal bank decision and will be made at a later time.
Executive Vice President Womack responded to further questions firom the
Regents and noted that he intended to recommend adoption of the new investment strategy and distribution policy for the University Investment Pool at the
next meeting.
Regent Baker asked to receive information about historic rates of return on
various asset classes over the past 70-year period.
Executive Vice President Womack recognized the contributions of all of the
Regents who had attended meetings on investment strategy and worked diligently to exercise their oversight finction with regard to investments.
Real Estate Investment (Acacia Housing Fund III)
Executive Vice President Womack asked Ms. Blakelock to describe Acacia
Housing Fund III. She reported that this fund provides capital to home builders
to help them finance their finished lot inventory, and it provides historically high
rates of return for investors. She and Mr. Herbert then responded to questions
from the Regents. After learning that he represents one of the home builders
who participates in the fund, Regent Deitch disqualified himself from the
discussion.
Regent Power moved that $10 million of the University Endowment Fund
be committed to Acacia Housing Fund III, pending the general counsel's review
of the partnership agreement for legal acceptability. Regent Brown seconded the
motion. Regent Baker stated that he would be abstaining from the vote because
he was not persuaded at this time. The vote was then taken, and the motion was
approved, with Regents Brown, McFee, McGowan, Power, and Varner in favor,
and Regents Baker and Deitch abstaining.
Unversity of Michigan Hospitals Comparative Statistic Report
President Duderstadt next called on Mr. John Forsyth, executive director of
University of Michigan Hospitals, to present the UM Hospitals Comparative
Statistic Report for the fiscal year 1992-93. Mr. Forsyth gave a slide presentation


221




March Meeting, 1994


illustrating the Hospitals' financial performance compared to other hospitals, its
own five-year average, and the national average in terms of profitability, liquidity, capital structure, and patient activity, for both 1992-93 and the period
1988-1993.
The presentation demonstrated that the Hospitals' overall financial performance has been very favorable. Mr. Forsyth pointed out that the improvement in financial performance has occurred not because of increases in
admissions or clinic visits or room    rates; rather it is the result of costeffectiveness and management efficiency within the institution. He noted that
there are fewer full-time-equivalent employees now than there were several years
ago, and that the proportion of care-givers has increased in the face of a dramatic
decrease in the number and percentage of management appointments.
Mr. Forsyth reported that in a recent study the UM Hospitals had been
named one of the top one-hundred in the country and one of the top ten
academic health centers. These ratings, as well as a comparison of the Hospitals'
risk adjusted mortality ratio to that of the top ten academic hospitals in the country, are indicators of the quality of the institution.
Following some discussion, Regent Baker complimented the Hospitals management and staff on the excellent job they have done. He also raised the issue of
whether the UM Hospitals and other teaching hospitals have had a role in the
development of the national health care plan. Mr. Forsyth responded that this is
a major concern and is being addressed by leaders of these institutions.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Consideration of the minutes of the February 1993 meeting was
deferred until next month.
Reports. Executive Vice President Womack submitted reports of investments, plant extension, litigation, and personnel-labor relations. Vice President
Neal submitted reports of projects established and summaries of a selection of
current research.
President Duderstadt reported on a proposal in Washington for a one-year
pause in indirect cost reimbursement for fiscal year 1995, which would mean
that institutions that receive additional federal government sponsored research
support for that year would not receive overhead support for those awards. He
and Vice President Neal reported on their efforts to educate the administration
on the importance of indirect cost reimbursement.
Voluntary Support. Vice President Cosovich submitted the report of
voluntary support.

230




March Meeting, 1994


Retirement Memoirs. Associate Vice President Holbrook submitted the
following retirement memoir:
Vern Carroll, professor of anthropology, retired from active faculty status
on December 31, 1993, after a most productive career as a teacher and
researcher.
Professor Carroll earned a B.A degree from Yale University in 1959, a second B.A degree from Cambridge University in 1961, M.A. degrees from Yale in
1962 and Cambridge in 1966, and a Ph.D. degree from the University of Chicago
in 1966. He served on the faculty of the University of Washington from 1966-72,
and came to the University of Michigan in 1972 as an associate professor of anthropology. At that time, he had an international reputation, both as a leading
comparativist of the languages, societies, cultures, and populations of the South
Pacific, and as an innovator in anthropological fieldwork methodologies. He was
promoted to professor of anthropology in 1975.
Within the Department of Anthropology, Professor Carroll helped to extend
the range of the department's upper-division undergraduate course offerings into
emerging areas of anthropological endeavor, especially the anthropology of the
mind, and methods of cultural analysis. He was instrumental in developing a
broad spectrum of research seminars for advanced undergraduates and an
award-winning honors program in cultural anthropology, and played a major
role in undergraduate counseling and the development of the upper-division
writing program. Undergraduate students also benefited from Professor Carroll's
six years of service (five as chair) on the LSA joint Student Faculty Policy Committee, and his participation in such interdisciplinary programs as South and
Southeast Asian Studies, American culture, the English Composition Board, and
comparative literature. In all of these activities, he brought anthropological perspectives to a large cross-section of our most able students in diverse departments, many of whom continue to express appreciation for his efforts.
In 1967, Professor Carroll founded, and thereafter served in each of the officer positions of, the Association for Social Anthropology in Oceania, now the major professional organization for anthropology in Oceania He also authored and
edited a number of publications and supervised coordinated research and comparative studies in this area.
The Regents now salute this distinguished educator for his dedicated service
by naming Vern Carroll professor emeritus of anthropology.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.

Reassignment of Ownership Interest in Intellectual Property (Gary J.
Nabel, Elizabeth G. Nabel, and Stephen L. Eck)
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Deitch, all seven Regents present unanimously approved reassignment of the intellectual property
"Double-Stranded Phosphorothioate NF-kB Inhibitors" (UM File No. 810) to the
inventors, Gary J. Nabel, Elizabeth G. Nabel, and Stephen L. Eck. Because the
inventors are also University employees, this arrangement falls under the state
of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in
compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the assignment agreement(s) will be the University of Michigan and
Gary J. Nabel, M.D., Elizabeth G. Nabel, M.D., and Stephen L. Eck.
2.  The terms and pecuniary interests were previously disclosed to and approved by
the Regents on July 16, 1987, and are hereby incorporated by reference into
this action request.
Reassignment of Ownership Interest in Intellectual Property (Gary J.
Nabel)
On a motion by Regent Deitch, seconded by Regent Power, all seven Regents present unanimously approved reassignment of the intellectual property
"Introduction of HIV Protective Genes into T Cells using Particle-mediated Gene
Transfer" (UM File No. 865) to the inventor, Gary J. Nabel. Because Dr. Nabel is
also a University employee, this arrangement falls under the state of Michigan
Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance
with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the assignment agreement(s) will be the University of Michigan and
Gary J. Nabel, M.D.
2.  The terms and pecuniary interests were previously disclosed to and approved by
the Regents on July 16, 1987, and are hereby incorporated by reference into
this action request.

233




APRIL MEETING, 1994


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, April 14, 1994
The Regents met at 2:15 p.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, and
Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy was also present, as were Provost
Whitaker, Executive Vice President Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, and Chancellor Renick Regent Varner and Interim
Chancellor Kugler were absent.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Regent
Deitch, who made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Sections 8(d), 8(f), and 8(h) of the Open Meetings
Act, as amended by 1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents
meet in closed session at 2:15 p.m. on April 14, 1994, in the Regents'
Room, for the following purposes: to consider the purchase or lease
of real property [Sec. 8(d)]; to review the specific contents of
applications for employment for which the candidates have requested
confidentiality [Sec. 8(f)]; and to consider material exempt from
discussion or disclosure by the Michigan Freedom of Information
Act [Sec. 8(h)]. Such exempt material consists of a written opinion
from the Board's legal counsel.
Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously. The
meeting then continued in executive session.
Public Comments
The Regents assembled at 4:00 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan
Union, and heard comments from the following individuals, on the topics indicated: Alice Hamele, citizen, on problems with her dental work; Richard A
Campbell, faculty member, on the Department of Communication; Craig Greenberg, immediate past president of Michigan Student Assembly, on a proposal for
student representation on the Board of Regents; Julie Neenan, president of
Michigan Student Assembly, introducing herself and her plans for MSA; Brian
Kight, student, on problems with the Statement of Student Rights and Responsibilities; and Robert Darden, coach of the men's gymnastics team, on the current
status of the men's gymnastics team.
At 4:40 p.m., following Public Comments, the Regents returned to the Regents' Room to continue meeting in executive session.


235




April Meeting, 1994


Friday, April 15, 1994
The Regents met at 9:15 am. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power, and
Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, Provost Whitaker, and Executive Vice President Womack were also present, as were Vice Presidents Cosovich,
Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim  Chancellor Kugler, and Chancellor
Renick. Regent Varner was absent.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Provost
Whitaker to present the first item of business.
Reorganization of Academic/Instructional Departments Within the
School of Public Health
Provost Whitaker reported that he had appointed a School of Public Health
review committee that had been charged with a) examining the mission of the
school and recommending revisions of the mission if any were indicated by the
examination; b) identifying salient issues in the field of public health and evaluating the school's strengths and limitations in addressing those issues; c) assessing the productivity of the school relative to that of other top-ranked schools of
public health and to other schools and colleges within the University; and d) developing principles and criteria for changes that would enhance the school's ability to achieve its mission.
Provost Whitaker described the makeup of the committee and the process
the committee had undergone in carrying out its work. He reported that the committee had recommended consolidating the school's eight departments into five.
He introduced Richard Cornell, interim dean of the School of Public Health, and
Ken Warner and Noreen Clark, co-chairs of the review committee and chairs of
departments in the School of Public Health.
Regent McFee complimented the committee and Provost Whitaker about
how the review was conducted, noting that the process that had been followed
made her very comfortable in being able to support the reorganization. Regent
Power expressed agreement with Regent McFee's sentiments,
Professors Cornell, Clark, and Warner commented on the review process
and observed that the review provided an opportunity for the school to meet the
challenges posed by the national debate on health care reform. They also reported that the review had been a good experience for all involved, and that there
is a mandate for change at the School of Public Health. The reorganization would
result in a consolidation of eight units into five, with only one of the current departments remaining untouched.
Following the discussion, Regent McFee moved that the School of Public
Health faculty be consolidated into the five core departments of biostatistics, environmental and industrial health, epidemiology, health behavior and health education, and health management and policy. Regent Power seconded the motion,
and it was approved unanimously.


236




April Meeting, 1994


North Campus Bell Tower
Provost Whitaker announced that Ann Lurie, widow of UM alumnus Robert
H. Lurie, was the person who had donated $12 million for construction of a bell
tower on North Campus in memory of her late husband, and that this was the
second largest gift in the history of the University. He described Mr. Lurie's career as a student at the University and later as a successful entrepreneur, and
President Duderstadt recalled having had the privilege of working with Mr. Lurie
when he was serving as dean of the College of Engineering. Regent Deitch complimented Provost Whitaker and others who had been involved in developing this
gift.
Provost Whitaker called on Mr. Fred Mayer, university planner, to describe
the project. Mr. Mayer noted that the bell tower had been designed by noted architect and University of Michigan alumnus Charles Moore, and that this project
represents the last architectural commission he completed before he died earlier
this year. Mr. Mayer described the site for the building and reported that it had
been chosen in consultation with the University's planning consultants, Johnson
Johnson & Roy/inc. He then displayed an architectural model of the proposed
bell tower and showed renderings illustrating how it would look from various locations on the North Campus. It was noted that the project was scheduled to be
completed late in 1995, and Ms. Margo Halsted, university carillonneur, who was
in the audience, commented that an original composition would be commissioned
to commemorate the occasion.
Following the presentation, Regent McGowan moved approval of the site
and design for the North Campus bell tower. Regent Power seconded the motion,
and it was approved unanimously.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Brown, the
Regents unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of February 1994.
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of March 1994.
Reports. Executive Vice President Womack submitted reports of investments, plant extension, litigation, personnel-labor relations, and noncompetitive
purchases over $2,000 from single sources. He commented on the significant correction that had occurred in the market over the past two months. Regent Baker
expressed concerns about the University's portfolios with respect to the current
volatility of the market and noted that the risks might be more substantial than
anticipated. Executive Vice President Womack expressed his belief that the University's risks are less substantial now because of its more diversified exposure as
well as the strong state of the economy.
Vice President Neal submitted reports on projects established and summaries of a selection of current research.

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted the following retirement memoir:
Joseph A. Walton, Jr., M.D., assistant professor of internal medicine, retired from active faculty status on April 30, 1993, after a productive career as a
teacher, clinician, and researcher.
A native of Florida, Dr. Walton received his B.S. and M.D. degrees in 1956
and 1960, respectively, from the University of Florida at Gainesville. He did his
initial training in internal medicine at University Hospital at Gainesville before
coming to the University of Michigan in 1964. He finished his internal medicine
training here and then completed a cardiology fellowship before joining the faculty in 1966 as an instructor. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1969.
Dr. Walton played a key role in the development of the cardiac catheterization program  at the University of Michigan Hospitals. He directed the
catheterization laboratory for 17 years and saw the evolution of invasive cardiology from a research tool to a commonly performed procedure that has become an
integral part of our diagnostic and treatment armamentarium. He has written 50
papers focusing on the use of angioplasty and thrombolytic agents in the
treatment of acute coronary disease and was part of the pioneering group here
that dramatically changed the management of patients with acute myocardial
infarction.
Dr. Walton will be best remembered as a quiet gentleman who influenced
the careers of several generations of trainees by exposing them to the joys of
clinical patient care. He was one of the unique clinicians who could go from the
bedside to the diagnostic laboratory and back to the bedside and be able to teach
students while providing a very high level of kind, compassionate patient care.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physician for his dedicated service by naming Joseph A Walton, Jr., assistant professor emeritus of internal
medicine.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees. Provost Whitaker submitted the May 1994 Doctoral Degree List,
the December 1993 Law School Final Degree List, and changes to previously approved degree lists.
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Deitch, the Regents
unanimously approved the remainder of the consent agenda as listed above.


247




April Meeting, 1994


Bond Rating Upgrades
Executive Vice President Womack informed the Regents that Moody's
Investors Service had upgraded the ratings on University of Michigan debt from
Aa to Aal, and that this is the first time that a public university had ever
received a Moody's rating of Aal. He observed that this is a significant
achievement and is an honor to be shared by everyone in the institution. He
recognized Provost Whitaker, Vice President Kennedy, and Associate Vice
President Frederick Neidhardt for their participation in the presentation that
resulted in the rating. He also recognized Norman Herbert, university treasurer,
and Gerald Jernigan, assistant investment officer, for their efforts in preparing
for and directing the presentation.
President Duderstadt credited the Regents for their leadership and guidance
over the years, citing the comment in Moody's Credit Report that "The University ranks as the strongest public university rated by Moody's in several key indicators of financial strength."
Historical Investment Performance of Major Asset Classes
Executive Vice President Womack noted that in response to a question
raised at the March meeting, the executive summary of a report by Cambridge
Associates, Inc., entitled "Historical Capital Market Returns," had been included
with the agendas.
University Investment Pool
Executive Vice President Womack reviewed the proposal for changing the
investment strategy and distribution policy for the University Investment Pool,
illustrating the discussion with flip charts and a handout that had been prepared
by the treasurer's office. He stated that the proposed "internal bank" represents
conservative, sound financial practice typical of that of the best institutions, and
that it is expected to enhance the investment performance of the University's
working capital.
In response to a question from Regent Baker about the use of derivatives,
Executive Vice President Womack stated that the proper use of derivatives has a
place in the market, but some of the riskier strategies employed by particular
hedge funds described in the media that may generate enormous returns for investors would likely be inappropriate for use by the University. However, he emphasized that the use of financial futures, through the tactical asset allocation
strategy, conservatively managed, has been beneficial for the University.
Following finurther discussion, Regent Power moved that:
1.  a unitized Long-Term Portfolio be established as an investment vehicle for the
University's long-term capital: the University Endowment Fund and the "permanent core" assets of the University Investment Pool;
2.  the "permanent core" assets of UIP be gradually moved into the Long-Term
Portfolio over a three- to five-year period unless a significant market decline
provides the opportunity to move assets more quickly. Financial futures and
other derivatives would be used, as appropriate, to facilitate the transition;


248




April Meeting, 1994


3.  the investment objective for the University Investment Pool will be to maximize total return, not just yield. Accordingly, UIP's investment performance
will be measured on a total return basis; and
4.  a University Investment Pool distribution policy be adopted which will pay all
participants the 90-day U.S. Treasury bill rate on a quarterly basis, based on
their average daily balances.
Regent Baker seconded the motion, noting that he had asked the question
about derivatives because it had been mentioned in item 2 of the recommendation, and that his question had been adequately answered. Executive Vice President Womack pointed out that the words "as appropriate" in regard to the use of
financial futures and other derivatives are key to the intent of the
recommendation.
There being no further discussion, the vote was then taken, and the motion
was approved unanimously.
Venture Capital Investments
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent McGowan, the Regents
unanimously approved commitment of up to $5 million of the University Endowment Fund to Battery Ventures III, L.P.
Environmental Research Institute of Michigan Clean Room Space
Executive Vice President Womack informed the Regents that the University
has entered into an agreement with the Environmental Research Institute of
Michigan (ERIM) for the lease of clean room space for the College of Engineering's Center for Display Technology & Manufacturing, according to the terms described in the Regents Communication.
Refinancing of Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993
Executive Vice President Womack explained that in the event that the State
Building Authority (SBA) would be unable to provide the fiuds necessary to pay
off the Series 1993 Bond Anticipation Notes by June 30, 1994, he was seeking approval for the issuance of $30 million of Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1994 to
pay off the Series 1993 Bonds and to provide for the construction cash flow requirements for the Integrated Technology Instruction Center (ITIC), Engineering Center, and C.C. Little and Angell Hall Renovation Projects through
December 1994.
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved adoption of a resolution (see Appendix A, page 257) that
authorizes the executive vice president and chief financial officer to:
1.  develop the terms and legal documentation for the Bond Anticipation Notes,
and to prepare, circulate and execute preliminary and final official statements
describing the Bond Anticipation Notes, the University, and its affairs; and
2.  apply for and obtain from Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's
Corporation their ratings on the Bond Anticipation Notes; and


249




April Meeting, 1994


3.  publish a notice of sale, receive bids, award the Bond Anticipation Notes to the
winning bidder (or alternatively select an underwriter and execute a note purchase agreement with the underwriter), execute an order establishing the terms
of notes, and execute and deliver the notes.
Angell/Haven Hall Connector Project
Executive Vice President Womack called on Mr. Douglas Hanna, university
architect, to present a revised budget and design for the Angell/Haven Hall Connector Project. Mr. Hanna reported that the design for this project had been revised in response to concerns raised when the project was initially presented at
the December 1993 Regents' Meeting. He reviewed each of the concerns that had
been raised and showed renderings depicting four alternative design suggestions
that had been made at the December meeting, noting the pros and cons associated with each design.
Mr. Hanna then presented a revised design solution that is responsive to the
Regents' concerns but still within the available budget. He displayed a site plan,
floor plans, a rendering of the entire building, and an architectural model, and
pointed out how the revised design responds to the concerns that had been expressed by the Regents.
Following Mr. Hanna's presentation, the Regents expressed enthusiastic
support for the revised design. On a motion by Regent Deitch, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents unanimously approved the revised budget and design
for the Angell/Haven Hall Connector Project, and authorized issuing the project
for bids and awarding a construction contract, providing the project is within
budget.
CeC. Little Building Projects
Executive Vice President Womack reported that a construction contract for
the C.C. Little Renovation Project had been awarded to the lowest bidder, EllisDon Michigan, Inc. He and Provost Whitaker also described additional renovations being proposed by the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts and the
College of Pharmacy.
Following some discussion, Regent Deitch moved approval of an increase in
the budget for the functional renovations in the C.C. Little Building from the
previously approved $3,000,000 to $4,750,000 and authorization for award of a
construction contract for the first phase of this work ($921,500) to Ellis-Don
Michigan, Inc. Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved
unanimously.
Engineering Center Project
Executive Vice President Womack described the details of the funding for
the previously approved Integrated Technology Instruction Center (ITIC)/ Engineering Center Project, for which $57 million of the total project budget of $58.35
million is to be funded by the State Building Authority. Due to the fact that bids
received for the Engineering Center component came in over the architect's


250




April Meeting, 1994


estimate, he is requesting an adjustment in the budget for that component. This
can be accomplished within the original total project budget, because the ITIC
component came in under the architect's estimate. Vice President Kennedy reported that the State Building Authority is in agreement with this proposal, and
Executive Vice President Womack said that the construction accounting will
clearly identify the two projects.
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent McFee, the Regents
unanimously approved internal adjustments within the $57 million budget of the
ITIC/Engineering Center Project to reflect an increase in the budget for the Engineering Center component and a decrease in the budget of the ITIC component. They also approved award of a construction contract for the Engineering
Center component to Sorensen Gross Construction Co., Inc.
Hubbard/Beal Intersection Reconstruction
Executive Vice President Womack informed the Regents that reconstruction
of the Hubbard Road/Beal Avenue intersection on the North Campus will begin
in May 1994.
Regent Baker requested that there be a discussion at a future meeting about
access to the University from the northeast and the east.
University of Michigan Visitors Center Project
Executive Vice President Womack called on Mr. Douglas Hanna, university
architect, to describe the proposed design of this project, which is intended to
serve as a central arrival point for visitors to the campus. The project involves an
addition to the Student Activities Building and renovations to the existing Student Activities Building.
Mr. Hanna displayed a site plan, schematic drawings of each floor, a drawing of the whole building, and an architectural model of the project. Several Regents expressed concerns about the facade and the windows for the project,
noting that the existing Student Activities Building is particularly unattractive in
these two areas. Mr. Hanna pointed out that the project includes replacement of
the louvered windows in the Student Activities Building, which will greatly enhance the building's appearance. He said that he would bring to the meeting next
month a rendering of how the facade will look with the replacement windows.
Following further discussion, President Duderstadt suggested that the Regents approve the project but be presented next month with a choice of different
exterior treatments before committing to a particular facade. Regent Power
moved provisional approval of the design and authorization for completion of
working drawings and bid documents, pending a discussion of the relationship of
the exterior improvements of the Student Activities Building to the proposed exterior treatment of the addition. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was
approved unanimously.


251




April Meeting, 1994


Reassignment of University's Ownership Interest in Intellectual Property (Walter J. Loesche)
Regent Power complimented Vice President Neal for the improved format
and language of the Regents Communications having to do with intellectual
property.
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Waters, all seven Regents present unanimously approved an assignment agreement with Walter J.
Loesche, D.M.D., Ph.D. for the following intellectual properties: "Improved System for Diagnosing Periodontal Disease," "Diagnostic Test Procedure for Detection of Oral Pathologenic Bacteria," and "Solid-Phase Test for the Detection of
Periodontal Disease in Subgingival Plaque." Because Dr. Loesche is a University
employee as well as inventor of the intellectual properties, this arrangement falls
under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and Walter J. Loesche,
DM.D., Ph.D.
2.   The agreement is being executed according to the standard terms approved by
the Regents on July 16, 1987, modified as follows: contract terms include payment to the University of 15 percent of total consideration received by Dr.
Loesche; no use of University facilities or services; Dr. Loesch assumes all University responsibility towards the Bern Group with respect to royalty distribution; and the University agrees to discuss with Dr. Loesche's licensee access to
the parent technology "System for Diagnosing Periodontal Disease," Walter J.
Loesche, Salam A. Syed, and Barbara E. Laughton, inventors.
3.   Dr. Loesche's pecuniary interest arises from his right to receive royalties when
this technology is licensed. This is in lieu of participation in the sharing of royalties received by the University in accordance with University policy.
Regent Power left the meeting at this point (11:15 a.m.).
Tennis Center
On a motion by Regent Deitch, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved proceeding with the Tennis Center Project on a phased
basis, as described in the Regents Communication.

Project

moved approval of the budget; submission of a Certificate of Need (CoN) amendment to the Michigan Department of Public Health; and soliciting bids and
awarding of a construction contract, provided the contract value is within the approved budget and a CoN amendment approval is received. Regent Waters seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.

and "Master of Science in Engineering (Computer Engineering)," to be offered
by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Both programs will


253




April Meeting, 1994


operate under the auspices of the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate
Studies.
