News and Information Services
Vice President Harrison introduced Ms. Julie Peterson, who recently assumed the position of director of news and information services.
Comments by Regent Baker
Regent Baker read from prepared remarks in which he commented about
the use of restroom toilet stalls in University buildings for homosexual acts. A
copy of the statement is on file in the Office of the Secretary of the University. He
noted that the Michigan Daily had published a report by J.B. Akins in its April
11, 1994 issue about the use of restrooms in Mason Hall for homosexual sexual
acts.
Regent Baker quoted from the article, which reported that unsuspecting
custodians and students have witnessed "everything from oral and anal sex to
public or group masturbation" in the restrooms and that the Department of Public Safety stated that these encounters take place in these restrooms on a daily
basis. He also noted that custodians who work in Mason and Angell Halls have
filed a grievance objecting to the unsanitary conditions in the restrooms and to
having to clean up the bodily fluids.
Regent Baker observed that for a decade, he had been attempting to "convince University administrators to take strong action against such criminal acts,
some of which are felonies under Michigan law," and that the Regents had an obligation to provide a safe environment for students, faculty, and staff. He stated
his belief that the "climate of political correctness... has silenced nearly all critical comment on homosexual/lesbian conduct," and that University administrators have been reluctant to offend homosexual individuals even when their
conduct is against the law or "discomforts... embarrasses... or threatens members of the University community."
Regent Baker concluded his remarks by requesting "that President Duderstadt develop and put into place an aggressive policy to reduce or eliminate the
acts of gross indecency and sexually related acts on the University campus." The
policy would direct the Department of Public Safety to arrest people who violate
sections 338 and 339 of the state criminal code by their actions on University
property.
Regent Brown responded that while he agreed that the activities described
by Regent Baker are not appropriate on University property, it was incorrect to
imply that past administrations and the current administration have not tried to
correct the situation.
Regent McGowan stated that Regent Baker should not have the last word
on this issue by suggesting that the alleged behavior of a few is reflective of the


254




April Meeting, 1994


agenda of the gay and lesbian community at the University. She said that the
meeting should not end with this inappropriate impression.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting will be held on May 19 and 20, 1994. Regents' expenses for the month of
March 1994 totaled $912.77.
ichard L. Kenn   Se    ry


255




April Meeting, 1994


APPENDIX A
RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND SALE OF BOND ANTICIPATION NOTES
IN THE PRINCIPAL AMOUNT OF NOT TO EXCEED $30,000,000 TO PAY PRIOR
BOND ANTICIPATION NOTES AND TO TEMPORARILY FINANCE PART OF
THE COST OF ACQUISITION, CONSTRUCTION, RENOVATION AND EQUIPPING OF CERTAIN PROJECTS AND RELATED COSTS, AND TO PROVIDE FOR
THE PAYMENT OF THE NOTES AND OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS, in the exercise of their constitutional duties and in order to properly serve the
needs of students attending The University of Michigan (the "University"), the Regents of the
University of Michigan (the "Issuer") has authorized the acquisition, construction and equipping
of an Integrated Technology Instruction Center and an Engineering Center, and the renovation
of C.C. Little and Angell Hall, each on the Ann Arbor Campus of the University (collectively, the
"Project"); and
WHEREAS, pursuant to a resolution adopted by the Issuer on November 19 1993 (the
"Prior Resolution"), the Issuer has previously issued its Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1993
(the "Prior Notes"), dated January 15, 1994 and maturing June 30, 1994; and
WHEREAS, the State Building Authority has stated its intention to provide permanent financing for a portion of the costs of the Project; and
WHEREAS, in the exercise of their constitutional duties and in order to properly serve the
interests of students attending the University, and to prudently control and direct expenditures
of the University's funds the Issuer deems it necessary and advisable to issue its Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1994 (hereinafter defined as the "Notes") in the principal amount of not to exceed Thirty Million Dollars ($30,000,000) for the purpose of paying the Prior Notes, temporarily
financing part of the cost of acquiring, constructing, renovating and equipping the Project, if an
Authorized Officer (hereinafter defined) deems such financing necessary or appropriate, and
paying the expenses related thereto and incidental to the issuance of the Notes; and
WHEREAS, the financing of the Project and the payment of the Prior Notes will serve
proper and appropriate public purposes; and
WHEREAS, in order to market the Notes in the most economic manner it is necessary to
authorize the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, or the Associate Vice President for Finance (each an "Authorized Officer") to make determinations as to the terms of the
Notes, within the limits set forth herein and (except as modified herein or the context hereof
clearly requires otherwise) in the Prior Resolution; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has been created as a constitutional body corporate under the provisions of Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, and has full power under
its constitutional authority and supervision of the University, and control and direction of expenditures from the University funds, to acquire, construct, renovate and equip the Project, to pay
part of the cost thereof by issuance of the Notes;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:
1. Definitions. In addition to the terms defined in this Resolution (the "Resolution"), the
capitalized terms used herein shall have the same meaning assigned to them in the Prior
Resolution.
2. Necessity for Issuance of the Notes. The Issuer, in the exercise of its powers and
authority relative to the general supervision of the University and control and direction of all


257




April Meeting, 1994 - Appendix A


expenditures from the University's funds, as provided in Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan
Constitution of 1963, hereby determines that the issuance of the Notes for the purposes set forth
in the preambles hereto is necessary and advisable.
3. Authorization of the Issuance of the Notes. For the purposes set forth above there
shall, if deemed necessary by an Authorized Officer to accomplish those purposes, or any of them,
be borrowed the sum of not to exceed Thirty Million Dollars ($30,000,000) as shall be determined
by an Authorized Officer, and in evidence thereof there shall be issued the Notes of the Issuer
which shall be designated "Bond Anticipation Notes, Series 1994", or with such other series designation as determined by an Authorized Officer, in like aggregate principal amount. The Notes
shall be sold, at a discount not exceeding 1% of the principal amount of the Notes, at a negotiated
or public sale, as shall be determined by an Authorized Officer. If the Notes are sold at a negotiated sale, either Authorized Officer is hereby authorized and directed to select an underwriter
and negotiate, execute and deliver a bond purchase agreement with respect to the Notes. If the
Notes are sold at a public sale, a notice of sale in the form to be approved by an Authorized Officer shall be published and the Notes shall be awarded to the winning bidder as shall be determined by an Authorized Officer. The Notes shall bear such rate of interest as shall be set forth in
the winning bid, but the net interest cost for the Notes, taking into account the rate and any discount or premium, shall not exceed 5% per annumrL An Authorized Officer may place additional
limitations on the bids in the notice of sale and may determine to award the Notes on the basis of
either true interest cost or net interest cost.
The Notes shall be dated as of a date to be selected by an Authorized Officer, shall be payable from the sources as hereinafter set forth, and shall be issued in fully-registered form in the
denomination of $100,000 or integral multiples thereof. The Notes shall mature on the date
specified by an Authorized Officer, but not later than December 31, 1994.
The Notes shall bear interest payable on the maturity date. The principal amount of and
interest on each Note shall be payable in lawful money of the United States of America upon surrender of the Note at the principal corporate trust office of a bank or trust company designated
by the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer (the "Transfer Agent") in such coin
or currency of the United States of America as may be, on the respective dates of payment
thereof, legal tender for the payment of debts due the United States of America.
4. limited Obligation. The Notes shall be limited obligations of the Issuer payable solely
from the sources of funds specified in Article VI of the Prior Resolution, and the Notes shall not
be a debt or liability of the State of Michigan or a general obligation of the Issuer.
5. Other Note Details. Except as amended in this Resolution, all other provisions of the
Prior Resolution pertaining to the Prior Notes, including the form of note (with appropriate
modifications to reflect the provisions of this Resolution and the terms of the Notes), sources and
payment for the Prior Notes, defeasance and all covenants, are restated and incorporated herein
and shall apply to the Notes.
6. Application of Note Proceeds. Immediately upon the receipt thereof, the proceeds of
the sale of the Notes in an amount, together with any funds presently on deposit or to be deposited in the Note Fund, sufficient to pay principal and interest on the Prior Notes, shall be deposited in the Note Fund established pursuant to the Prior Resolution. The balance of the proceeds
of the Notes, if any, shall be deposited in the Project Fund established pursuant to the Prior
Resolution and used to pay cost related to the issuance of the Notes and costs of the Project, as
specified in the Prior Resolution.
7. Investment of Funds. Moneys held in the Note Fund and the Project Fund shall be
invested as provided in the Prior Resolution.
8. Tax Covenant. The Issuer hereby covenants that it shall take all actions within its
control necessary to maintain the exclusion of the interest on the Notes from gross income for
federal income tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Code"), including but
not limited to actions relating to the rebate of arbitrage earnings, if required, and the expenditure
and investment of Note proceeds and moneys deemed to be Note proceeds.


258




April Meeting, 1994 - Appendix A


9. Supplemental Resolutions. The Issuer may adopt resolutions supplemental to the
Resolution pursuant to the provisions of the Prior Resolution.
10. Authorization of Official Statement, Preliminary Official Statement, and Official Notice of Sale. The Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, or the Associate Vice President for Finance, or either of them are hereby authorized to cause to be prepared
and circulated a Preliminary Official Statement with respect to the Notes, to cause to be prepared
and published an Official Notice of Sale, and to cause to be prepared, and to execute and deliver
on behalf of the Issuer an Official Statement substantially in the form of the previously prepared
Preliminary Official Statement, relating to the Notes. The distribution and use of the Preliminary Official Statement in accordance with applicable laws, in connection with the sale of the
Notes, and the distribution and use of the Official Statement in accordance with applicable laws
by the successful bidder or underwriter, in connection with the marketing of the Notes, is hereby
authorized and approved.
11. Resolution Constitutes Contract. The provisions of the Resolution shall constitute
a contract between the Issuer and Noteholders to the equal and ratable benefit and protection of
each Noteholder, and after delivery of the Notes, no change, variation, or alteration of the provisions of the Resolution may be made except in accordance with its terms.
12. Enforcement of Contract. The contract constituted by the Resolution shall be enforceable by appropriate proceedings taken by the Noteholder(s) under the law.
13. Other Documentation. The Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of
the University, the Secretary of the University, the Associate Vice President for Finance of the
University, the Treasurer and Investment Officer of the University, and any other appropriate
officers or representatives of the Issuer or the University, and each of them, are authorized to
perform all acts and deeds and execute and deliver all instruments and documents for and on behalf of the Issuer required by this Resolution, or necessary, expedient and proper in connection
with the issuance, sale and delivery of the Notes, and the acquisition, construction, renovation
and equipping of the Project all as contemplated hereby.
Subsequent to the issuance of the Notes, all actions permitted or required by the Issuer may
be made or undertaken by the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or Associate
Vice President for Finance, or any other duly authorized officer of the Issuer or the University.
All determination of Note terms required to be made by the Executive Vice President and Chief
Financial Officer or Associate Vice President for Finance shall be made by him within the ranges
or other limitations set forth or incorporated herein.
14. Severability. If any one or more sections, clauses or provisions of the Resolution shall
be determined by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or ineffective for any reason,
such determination shall in no way affect the validity and effectiveness of the remaining sections,
clauses and provisions of the Resolution.
15. Headings. Any headings shall be solely for convenience of reference and shall not constitute a part of the Resolution, nor shall they affect its meaning, construction or effect.
16. Conflict. All resolutions or parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the Issuer in
conflict herewith be and the same are repealed insofar as such conflict exists.
17. Effective Date- The Resolution shall take effect immediately upon its adoption.


259




MAY MEETING, 1994


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, May 19, 1994
Public Comments
The Regents met at 4:00 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan Union.
Present were President Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee,
McGowan, Power, Varner, and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy,
Provost Whitaker, and Executive Vice President Womack were also present, as
were Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim Chancellor
Kugler, and Chancellor Renick.
The Regents heard comments from the following people, all regarding the
topic of the recommendations of the Bylaw 14.06 Task Force: Erik Olson, staff
member, Scott Yost, student; Jefferson Williams, student; and Cassius E. Street,
Jr., alumnus; all opposed to implementation of the task force recommendations;
and Sally Johnson, Pamela Home, Mark Erichson, Joy Paulson (staff members);
John Soluri, member of the GEO steering committee; and Jane Barney, retired
staff member; all in favor of implementation of the task force recommendations.
Following the completion of the public comments session at 5:00 p.m., the
meeting recessed until the following day.
Friday, May 20, 1994
The Regents met at 8:15 a.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power,
Varner, and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, Provost Whitaker,
and Executive Vice President Womack were also present, as were Vice Presidents
Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim Chancellor Kugler, and Chancellor Renick.
Chancellor of University of Michigan-Flint
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and announced that the
first order of business would be a recommendation for the appointment of
Charlie Nelms as chancellor of the University of Michigan-Flint. The president
commented on Dr. Nelms' background and qualifications and said that he will
provide the vision and direction needed to continue the remarkable progress of
the UM-Flint campus.
Regent Varner moved the appointment of Charlie Nelms as chancellor of
the University of Michigan-Flint, effective August 1, 1994. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.


261




May Meeting, 1994


President Duderstadt introduced Dr. Nelms and his wife, Jeanetta, both of
whom were in attendance, and invited Dr. Nelms to comment on his appointment. Dr. Nelms expressed his appreciation and excitement for his appointment
as chancellor and commented on his leadership philosophy. Following Dr. Nelms'
remarks, President Duderstadt expressed his appreciation to Dr. Kugler for his
service as interim chancellor and to Professor Harriet Wall, chair of the search
committee, and the other search committee members for their excellent work
that culminated in the selection of Charlie Nelms as chancellor.
Final Report of the Bylaw 14.06 Task Force
President Duderstadt commented that when the Regents voted in September 1993 to amend Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 to add the phrase "sexual orientation," they assigned the president and his administration the responsibility for
implementing the policy they had approved. To fulfill this responsibility, he had
appointed a committee, chaired by Bernard Machen, dean of the School of
Dentistry, to advise him on how the policy could best be implemented. The report
had been adopted unanimously and submitted to the president and was now being submitted to the Regents as an information item. The president observed
that the Board's responsibility is to approve the general policy, while not being
directly involved with the implementation of that policy.
He thanked Dean Machen and the committee for their work and stated that
the administration intended to take the committee's advice into careful consideration as it moved forward to implement the policy that the Regents had
approved. He advised the Board that he would keep them fully informed as the
administration addressed these issues. President Duderstadt observed that there
were a number of complex issues involved in implementation of the policy and
noted that the administration would be able to draw on the experience of other
higher education institutions that had already addressed these issues. He reiterated that his administration does intend to move ahead with implementation of
the general policy that the Regents had approved last September, and that he
would keep the Regents informed of their progress as they did so.
Regent Baker asked Dean Machen whether the committee had agreed to a
definition of sexual orientation, and whether pedophilia, man-boy love, and bestiality would be included in that definition. Dean Machen responded that he did
not understand how those terms relate to sexual orientation; Regent Baker
stated that if someone is oriented to those practices, they could claim that that
was their orientation. In response to Dean Baker's next question, Dean Machen
stated that the committee had been apprised of numerous instances of
discrimination against homosexuals and lesbians on campus. Regarding Regent
Baker's question of whether the University would be abrogating its responsibility
of deciding who would get benefits by relying on the City of Ann Arbor, Dean
Machen stated that the task force did not specifically define the process the
University would use. They had made suggestions that the University could
consider, but the responsibility for deciding such matters rests with the
administration.


262




May Meeting, 1994


Regent Baker observed that elected officials take an oath to uphold the state
constitution, and given that "some of the acts... which some of those people [in
the homosexual community] do are illegal under the law", questioned how the
Regents could reconcile their duty to uphold the law with codifying the recommendations of the task force. Dean Machen responded that he was unaware that
any of the recommendations of the task force would be illegal in the state of
Michigan. Regent Baker observed that such questions ought to be considered.
Regent Baker moved that the report of the Bylaw 14.06 Task Force dated
March 29, 1994, be rejected by the Regents and further that the phrase "sexual
orientation" be removed from Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06. President Duderstadt called for a second for the first motion calling for rejection of the task force
report; there being no second, the motion failed. He then called for a second on
the motion to remove the phrase "sexual orientation" from Regents' Bylaw
Section 14.06. That motion failed for lack of a second.
Comments by Regent Baker on Bylaw 14.06 Task Force Report
Regent Baker read from a prepared statement, a copy of which is on file in
the Office of the Secretary of the University. He stated that the Regents' decision
to include the term "sexual orientation" in Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 on September 24, 1993, and the present discussion of the task force report represented a
"defining moment" in the history of the University of Michigan that would have
a long-term impact on the lives of people associated with it.
Regent Baker observed that by adding the term "sexual orientation" to
Bylaw Section 14.06, the Regents were accepting the premise that homosexual
and lesbian sexual practices are equivalent to heterosexual practices, which is
contrary to the beliefs of a majority of Michigan's electorate. This "false premise"
is the basis for the task force recommendation to extend to same sex committed
partners the same university benefits now offered to heterosexual spouses.
Regent Baker observed that many Michigan residents consider the revised
bylaw and the task force report to be a direct attack on the American family because it undermines the family structure from a moral and religious perspective.
He observed that a statewide movement had been mobilized seeking to negate
the Regents' actions, which had generated more than 250 letters and nearly 4000
petition signatures; the largest reaction to any issue considered by the Regents in
his experience.
Regent Baker quoted from four letters from citizens and from a letter from
the Michigan House of Representatives Republican Task Force on Higher Education expressing their opposition to the use of tax money to equate homosexual
status with that of minorities, to "promote the homosexual agenda," and to "support homosexual legal rights and benefits." The letter from the Republican task
force warned that many of the recommendations may be in conflict with state
and federal rights and statutes. (The full text of the quotes is contained in the
statement on file.)


263




May Meeting, 1994


Regent Baker observed that members of the homosexual/lesbian community
have been successftil in advancing their political goals in Ann Arbor, both on and
off campus, and noted that the University supports a Lesbian, Gay Male, Bisexual Programs Office (LGMBPO). He reported that during freshmen orientation,
new students' views of homosexuality are challenged by lesbian and homosexual
group leaders. He quoted from a letter he'd received from a current student
describing the student's experience at freshmen orientation, in which the student
stated he or she had been ridiculed by the group's lesbian leader for the student's
"inability to have an open mind," and that the leader had "attacked [the student's] views" and lectured the student "in defense of her lifestyle."
Regent Baker stated his belief that "no criticism of homosexual/lesbian conduct is permitted in the classroom, the dormitory, or elsewhere on campus," or
by employees, and that the University does not permit "objection to having a homosexual or lesbian roommate" as sufficient mason for changing roommates. He
continued that "political correctness" has made faculty, staff, and students fearful of speaking out on issues.
Regent Baker stated that the opinions expressed by people in the state in
their letters and petitions to the Regents indicate their opposition to the bylaw
change and task force report as "an attack on the family, a wrongful expenditure
of taxpayer money, an attempt at thought control over... students, an overreaching into the responsibilities of the state legislature, an improper classification of
preference in sexual conduct as equal to racial discrimination, and... bad public
policy." Therefore, he concluded that the term "sexual orientation" should be
removed from Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 and that the Report of the Bylaw
14.06 Task Force should be rejected.
President Duderstadt noted that Regent Baker's statement represents his
own personal beliefs, and that in the view of the University administration, it
contains a "very significant number of mischaracterizations and misunderstandings," which would be corrected and would accompany the statement in the
record, rather than go unchallenged. (A copy of that statement, prepared by the
vice president for student affairs, is on file in the Office of the Secretary of the
University.)
Regent McFee thanked the members of the task force for the thoughtful
consideration they had given to all of the issues. She observed that she had also
received large numbers of letters on both sides of the issue. She noted that the
task force report is not meant to be accepted or rejected by the Regents; rather it
is meant to help guide the president in his implementation of the bylaw change
that the Regents had approved. Regent McFee noted that the Regents had
recently received a similar type of report on the issue of flexible benefits and
pointed out that, as in the case of the bylaw 14.06 report, there was definitely not
unanimous agreement on all of its recommendations.
Both task force reports, she observed, deal with the question of benefits and
their applicability to dependents. She noted that staff benefits now comprise a
significant portion of overall compensation, and that the staff employed by the
University has changed so that it now includes all possible combinations of


264




May Meeting, 1994


married and single people with or without dependents, some of whom may or
may not be employed at the University or elsewhere. Regent McFee observed
that the goal of the University's benefits package has been to alleviate the financial difficulties of providing for one's dependents. To that end, the task force
report should be reviewed in concert with the flexible benefits program and the
changing environment within the benefits arena
Regent McFee then posed the question of what the University could do to
alleviate the vulnerability of homosexuals, so they are not subject to harassment
because of their lifestyle. She recounted a telephone call she had received from a
woman who, as a Christian fundamentalist, is morally offended by homosexual
lifestyles, but who also is the mother of a homosexual college student and wanted
him to be able to live in an environment that would allow him to develop without
experiencing a life of constant harassment.
Regent McFee also reported that the Supreme Court had recently ruled that
a school board that for years had allowed a student to be ridiculed for allegations
about her sex life was responsible for allowing the harassment to continue
unabated. She urged that this type of ridicule not be allowed to take place at the
University, nor interfere with the development of students and employees.
Regent McGowan thanked the president for stating his intention to implement nondiscrimination and equal opportunity guarantees to the University's
gay and lesbian community as they pertain to employment benefits, financial aid
packages, residency requirements, and University housing, pursuant to the
Regents' action of September 24, 1993. She observed that it was the
responsibility of the president and executive officers to determine how to achieve
those policy goals, and that the president had done so by appointing a task force
to study these issues and advise him. She noted that the Board's decision had
been reinforced when Regent Baker had failed, through his motions earlier in the
meeting, to move any member of the Board.
With regard to assertions made earlier by Regent Baker, Regent Power
asked Dean Machen whether the task force had "concluded, wrongly, that 'committed same-sex' relationships (homosexual, bisexual and lesbian) are equivalent
to married spousal relationship[s] (heterosexual)." Dean Machen responded that
this statement is accurate from the perspective only of rewarding benefits.
Regent Power then asked Vice President Hartford whether Regent Baker's
assertions are true that "after school begins, no criticism of homosexual/lesbian
conduct is permitted in the classroom, the dormitory or elsewhere on the campus" and that "under University rules a student's objection to having a homosexual or lesbian roommate is not sufficient reason to allow a change of
roommates." Vice President Hartford responded that the first assertion would
be proven to be inaccurate merely upon asking any gay or lesbian student
whether criticism of them has been permitted once they arrive on campus. Regarding the second assertion, she stated that students in residence halls have a
choice of whom they live with. If a student decides he or she does not want to live
in a certain room, the housing office tries to accommodate a move, within the


265




May Meeting, 1994


limits imposed by high occupancy levels. The philosophy is that students are
adults and have a right to decide who they want to live with.
Regent Deitch observed that Regent McGowan had correctly articulated the
nature of the discussion. He stated that the purpose of the bylaw change was to
achieve equity and to make "a reality out of our commitment to diversity." He
said that he was comfortable with the process and with the task force's recommendations being in the hands of the president for further study and, he hoped,
implementation.
Regent Deitch quoted Regent Baker's comment that "Many Michigan citizens consider the Regents' action in September 1993 adding 'sexual orientation'
to Regents' Bylaw Section 14.06 and the present report of the 14.06 task force to
be a direct attack on the American family-their families-because it undermines the family structure in moral and other terms." He said that he resented
that statement and that it would be wrong to leave that impression with the
public.
Regent Deitch quoted from the remarks of Pamela Home, a University staff
member who had spoken at the public comments session in support of the recommendations of the task force. Ms. Home had noted that she was a local resident
who had been married for 20 years, was a mother of two daughters, and was an
active and practicing Christian. She had stated,
"Given my personal characteristics, it may not appear as if I
have a stake in these issues. But I do have a stake, as does every
citizen of Michigan. Whether we know it or not, we all have
colleagues, friends, and relatives who are gay and lesbian. These are
real persons of worth and dignity, but who are discriminated against
not only by individuals, but by the institutions of our society. Let us
not have the University of Michigan continue to be an institution
which contributes to intolerance and exclusion, but rather one which
leads in its commitment to respect, inclusion, and fair treatment.
Yes, I do have a stake-injustice to any one of us is injustice to us
all."
Regent Deitch concluded that he spoke in support of the recommendations
as a family person himself, who had been married for 25 years, had three children, aging parents, and other accouterments typical of American families. He
believes that "families come in all shapes, sizes, colors, and that what we judge in
people is their character, and their values.... We need to be able to say that we
respect people and that we welcome them into our community."
Regent Deitch expressed confidence that under President Duderstadt's leadership, the recommendations would be dealt with in an appropriate fashion, and
expressed hope that the University of Michigan would join a number of peer
institutions in adopting, in one form or another, the recommendations of the
task force.
Regent McFee observed that many citizens had expressed in their letters the
notion that they would be watching the outcome of this meeting. She said she


266




May Meeting, 1994


welcomed that observance and hoped that they would continue observing the
Board as it dealt with other issues in the future.
Regent Baker stated that citizens' view of the Board's actions as an attack
on the family is a legitimate one, since society today is "in shreds" in many
respects. He believes people are desperate to find ways to hold the family
together and to exemplify some of the traits described by Regent Deitch. He
stated the Board would be doing an injustice to the state's citizens if it "ignores
the hopes and aspirations of this society toward the family." This particular issue is but one manifestation, he believes, of what people view as the disintegration of the family.
Regent Baker observed that it was not easy to raise these issues, and that
when he talked about difficult issues, he tried to do it in a thoughtful, easily
understood, manner. He noted that the Board's policies change over time
according to the makeup of the Board, so that in a few years the vote could be the
opposite of what it is today. He continued that in spite of his views on this issue
or disagreement with particular policies, he loves this institution and the opportunities it provides people. He noted his long-standing involvement with civil
rights, from his military service in the early 1940s to his work with the Urban
League in Detroit. He hoped that the exchange of ideas that had occurred that
day were done in good spirit and with an understanding that there are differences in opinion, that ideas have consequences, and that they should be
discussed.
Regent McGowan pointed out that in the mid-1800s there had been a bitter
debate about whether to admit women to the University that did not conclude
until 1870, when women were admitted. As that was a good decision, today's
action will also be a good decision for the University.
President Duderstadt observed that the University of Michigan had been
"the epitome of the Jeffersonian ideal of an institution that aspires to excellence
but to provide that excellence to all of that society that creates, supports, and sustains us." He recalled a recent speech at the University by the Dalai Lama, in
which he referred to a "family of humankind" to which we all belong and which
we serve. He stated that he accepts the responsibility for implementing the
Regents' policy and will address the various issues surrounding that. He
expressed appreciation for the input of Dean Machen and the task force and the
input of the Regents, and said he would keep the Regents apprised as the administration moves to implement the policy.
There followed a short recess, after which the meeting reconvened at 9:30
a.m. Regents Brown and Waters were not present for the remainder of the
meeting.
Proposed FY 1995 University of Michigan Hospitals' Operating Budget
Executive Vice President Womack introduced Mr. John Forsyth, executive
director of University of Michigan Hospitals, to present the proposed fiscal year
1995 Hospitals' Operating Budget. Mr. Forsyth stated that the budget is based


267




May Meeting, 1994


on the Hospitals' mission, vision, values, and critical success factors, and gave a
slide presentation illustrating these concepts.
For its mission, the Hospitals' strive for excellence and leadership in terms
of patient care and service, education, and research. The vision statement is
based on assessment of the institution's strengths, and encompasses being the
first place people think of when they think of health care, being preeminent in
teaching, research and advancing medical science, and being the employer of
choice. The Hospitals are guided by the values of respect, compassion, integrity,
efficiency, and leadership. Critical success factors include several measures of
success in the clinical arena, customer satisfaction, partnership with the community, educational and research excellence, creativity and innovation, cost effectiveness, and financial viability.
Mr. Forsyth displayed a number of graphs and charts that illustrate the
Hospitals' financial viability in terms of assets, equity, FY 1994 results, cash balances, and debt capacity, noting that all measures are favorable for the current
fiscal year. He then enumerated weaknesses that had been identified in 1993,
noting that substantial progress had been made in improving many of them,
including alignment of educational and clinical strategies, making a significant
commitment toward improving aging research facilities, and moving toward
expanding the primary care network. The latter effort will be addressed in large
part by the new medical campus planned for northeast Ann Arbor. Efforts have
also been made to strengthen two other weaknesses that had been identified in
1993, including establishing joint ventures and affiliations with other institutions
and improving cost structure and utilization.
Mr. Forsyth reviewed options for the Medical Center in the marketplace and
health care reform environment, with possible roles as a supplier to multiple
HMOs (Health Maintenance Organizations)/AHPs (Allied Health Plans), a partner in a delivery system, or a combination of all of these options. He listed a
number of "key imperatives for UMMC financial success."
The FY 1995 budget assumptions include a cost effectiveness program,
enhanced academic support, relatively flat admissions/visits/length of stay,
self-funded competitive salary program, and maintaining the cost effectiveness
program with an emphasis on cost per case. The proposed budget includes a 5.7
percent reduction in the private/semi-private room rate and no increase in the
intensive care unit room rate and ancillary rates.
Mr. Forsyth concluded his presentation with a discussion of planning
assumptions for FY 1996 and FY 1997 budgets. Following some discussion,
Regent Power moved adoption of the proposed FY 1995 University of Michigan
Hospitals' operating budget, as described in the Regents Communication. Regent
McFee seconded the motion, and it was improved unanimously.
Family Practice Building in Chelsea
This is a proposal for the University of Michigan Medical Center to purchase
a new family practice clinic facility on the Chelsea Community Hospital (CCH)


268




May Meeting, 1994


campus for the Department of Family Practice. On a motion by Regent Varner,
seconded by Regent Deitch, the Regents approved the purchase of the family
practice clinic facility on the CCH campus, which will include a long term lease
for the land, according to the terms described in the Regents Communication.
CESF Report-Ann Arbor Campus
The president called on Professor John Tropman, chair of the Committee on
the Economic Status of the Faculty (CESF) for the Ann Arbor campus, to present the committee's report. Professor Tropman distributed handouts of the
committee's report. He stated that the committee was recommending a salary
improvement program this year and had expressed support for a flexible benefits
package and a one-time salary supplement pilot program. Other recommendations include development of a faculty and staff compensation policy; development of a compensation analysis task force to outline and oversee the regular
development and report of compensation numbers to the University community;
exploring the possibility of developing unbiased programs to educate faculty and
staff in the allocation of their retirement assets; and review of the report of the
New Pay Committee.
The president complimented Professor Tropman and the committee for
their spirit of cooperation in working with the administration and noted that
they had addressed issues that are very important to the institution. A discussion
followed regarding flexible benefits, the retirement program, and other points
raised in the report.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Regarding the April minutes, Regent Baker stated that Regent
McGowan's assumption that he had deliberately chosen to speak about a controversial issue at the end of a meeting is incorrect. He reported that he had advised
the other Regents and the president before the meeting that he was going to be
raising the issue and had given them copies of his remarks. He had asked the
president to be able to speak early in the meeting, but the president had
requested that he speak at the end, so he had accommodated that request.
It was decided to delay consideration of the minutes until the following
meeting.
Reports. Executive Vice President Womack submitted reports of investments, plant extension, litigation, and personnel-labor relations. Vice President
Neal submitted reports of projects established and summaries of a selection of
current research.
Voluntary Support. Vice President Cosovich submitted the report of
voluntary support.

Ludwig Koenen, Ann Arbor                 Terrence Webb, Jackson
Personnel Actions. Provost Whitaker submitted personnel actions, pointing out the recommendation for the appointment of Jeffrey Sean Lehman as
dean of the Law School.
Recommended promotions. Provost Whitaker observed that the faculty
promotion and tenure process is one of the most important things undertaken at
the University, and that it is done as carefully and as seriously as possible
because these decisions affect the reputation and future directions of the
University for many years to come. He reviewed the promotion and tenure process, noting that the criteria are determined by the faculty, who make recommendations to the dean and school or college executive committee, who in turn make
recommendations to the provost and president, with final approval being given
by the Regents. When women and minority candidates are turned down for tenure or promotion, written statements indicating where each person failed to meet
the criteria are forwarded to the Affirmative Action Office for review.
Provost Whitaker distributed a handout indicating progress towards retaining women and minority faculty. This year, 26.4 percent of the people recommended for promotion or tenure were women, a significant improvement over


274




May Meeting, 1994


the past several years. Minorities comprised 15.7 percent of the total recommended for promotion or tenure. Provost Whitaker observed that efforts to
recruit and retain faculty of color and women are beginning to pay off. He then
reviewed the materials for five individuals who were being recommended for promotion or tenure.
Chancellor Renick presented the promotion and tenure recommendations
for the Dearborn campus and Chancellor Kugler presented the recommendations
for the Flint campus.
Following some discussion, Regent Deitch moved approval of the appointment of Jeffrey Sean Lehman as dean of the Law School. Regent Power seconded
the motion, and it was adopted.

Glenn McGeoch Collegiate Professorship in Music. The Regents approved the establishment of the Glenn McGeoch Collegiate Professorship in
Music, effective September 1, 1994.
