Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted retirement memoirs
for 17 faculty members.
Keith W. Bryan, professor of music (flute), will retire from active faculty
status on May 31, 1994.


285




May Meeting, 1994


Professor Bryan received his B.Mus. degree with performer's certificate
from the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, New York, in 1953. Following
graduation, he was a member of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, D.C., from 1953-55, after which he served with the Seventh Army Symphony
Orchestra in Europe (1955-57). He then returned to the National Symphony Orchestra for four additional years (1957-61). During most of this period, Professor
Bryan was also concertizing as a partner in the "Bryan and Keys Duo" with his
wife, Karen Keys, pianist. Beginning with the 1961-62 concert season, the Bryan
and Keys Duo devoted full time to recitals, which included performances in
Belgium, England, France, Germany, and Switzerland, and tours throughout the
United States. Professor Bryan joined the University of Michigan in 1964 as a
guest lecturer in music. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1965, associate professor in 1968, and professor in 1972.
Throughout his tenure at the University, Professor Biyan remained active
as a performer. His recording of Twentieth Century Sonatas for Flute and Piano
was an especially conspicuous highlight of such activities, as was the Bryan and
Keys five-week tour and residency in China during 1985, and Professor Bryan's
premiere performance of a new flute concerto by John La Montaine at the
National Gallery of Art in 1981. In addition to his artistry as a performer,
Professor Bryan is also a sensitive and devoted teacher of flute.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Keith W. Bryan
professor emeritus of music (flute).
0. Lynn Deniston, associate professor of public health policy and administration in the School of Public Health, will retire from active faculty status on
May 31, 1994.
A native of Ohio, Professor Deniston received his B.S. degree from The Ohio
State University in 1954, his M.P.H. degree from the University of California at
Berkeley in 1962, and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1975.
Professor Deniston began his career as a public health professional by working as
a sanitarian for the Ohio Department of Public Health from 1957-63. He came to
the University of Michigan as a research associate in the School of Public Health
in 1964. He received the additional appointment of lecturer in 1966 and was
named associate professor in the Department of Health Planning and Administration (now known as Public Health Policy and Administration) in 1976.
Within the School of Public Health, Professor Deniston concentrated both
his research and teaching in the area of program evaluation, emphasizing the
measurement of health status and quality of life. In the 1970s and '80s, Professor
Deniston was responsible for coordinating the core course for the school's MPH
degree program. Later, he taught the school's course on the history and philosophy of public health. Professor Deniston exhibited a ready willingness to assist
the school in a wide array of endeavors, as reflected in his serving as secretary of
the faculty, coordinator of the blood donor program, and school representative to
the University's recycling office.
Over a quarter of a century's worth of SPH students found Professor Deniston to be an unusually accessible and helpful academic advisor and mentor. He
was revered for an "open-door policy" that found him eager to devote long hours
to working with individual students. He also made significant efforts to keep in


286




May Meeting, 1994


touch with alumni, efforts eased by the fact that alumni often sought him out,
whether it be for career counseling or simply to sustain highly-valued friendships. His dedication to working with public health practitioners extended into
Professor Deniston's many contributions to state and local health departments,
particularly in the area of his greatest expertise, program evaluation.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming 0. Lynn Deniston
associate professor emeritus of public health policy and administration.
Thomas M. Donahue, Edward H. White II Distinguished University Professor of Planetary Science, Department of Atmospheric, Oceanic, and Space
Sciences in the College of Engineering, and professor of physics in the College of
Literature, Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31,
1994.
Professor Donahue received his AB. degree from Rockhurst College in 1942
and his Ph.D. degree from Johns Hopkins University in 1947. He held positions
at Johns Hopkins until 1951, when he joined the faculty of the University of
Pittsburgh. There he organized a program in atomic physics and atmospheric science that led to studies of the upper atmosphere with instruments flown on
sounding rockets and spacecraft. At Pittsburgh, he became associate professor in
1953 and served as director of both the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space
Sciences and the Space Coordination Center.
In 1974, Professor Donahue joined the University of Michigan as professor
and chair of the Department of Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences; he served as
chair until 1980 and was appointed professor of physics in 1989. Professor Donahue has participated in the Orbiting Geophysical Observatory, Voyager, Pioneer
Venus, Galileo, and Cassini spacecraft missions and is the author of more than
150 publications. He is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the
International Academy of Astronautics and is a fellow of the American Geophysical Union and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. His
honors include the Arctowski Medal of the National Academy of Sciences, the
John Adam Fleming Medal of the American Geophysical Union, the NASA Distinguished Public Service Medal, and the Space Science Award from the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. At the University of Michigan, he
was the Henry Russel Lecturer in 1986 and received the Stephen S. Attwood
Award for Excellence in Engineering in 1994.
Professor Donahue knows as much about the planets, especially Venus, as
anyone in the world today. His brilliance is legendary, both as an experimentalist
and as a theoretician. He has served on numerous national advisory boards and
has held visiting titles at major institutions. Professor Donahue has also served
on countless University committees and programs, including the Project for the
Integrated Study of Global Change.
The Regents now salute this member of the faculty for his outstanding
career by naming Thomas M. Donahue the Edward H. White II Distinguished
University Professor Emeritus of Planetary Science and professor emeritus of
physics.
Peter W. Ferran, associate professor of theatre, will retire from active
faculty status on May 31, 1994.


287




May Meeting, 1994


Professor Ferran received his AB. degree from the College of the Holy Cross
in Worcester, Massachusetts, in 1960. He served in the U.S. Army from 1962-64,
then taught at The American School in Switzerland (Lugano) from 1964-66. He
then enrolled at the University of Michigan, where he received his M.A. degree in
1967 and his Ph.D. degree in 1972, with considerable emphasis on the work of
Bertolt Brecht-an interest that he pursued throughout his academic career. Following three years of service as a teaching fellow concurrent with his graduate
studies, Professor Ferran began a long and significant association with the University's Residential College as lecturer in drama (1970-73), assistant professor of
English (1973-79), and associate professor of theatre and drama (1979-1985). He
spent the academic year 1983-84 as visiting professor of literature and drama at
Franklin College in Lugano, Switzerland. In 1975, he received the University's
Distinguished Service Award.
Professor Ferran's teaching has included fundamentals of d rama  tic
theory and criticism, play writing, arts and ideas, and intensive German, in addition to the practically ever-present emphasis on Brecht. He was a founding member of the Residential College Brecht Company in which he involved himself as
actor, director, and-as an avocational musician of considerable prowess-performer and composer. He is author of several published articles and reviews and
has lectured repeatedly at the Oregon Shakespearean Festival and Modem Languages Association meetings.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Peter W. Ferran
associate professor emeritus of theatre.
Bernard A. Galler, professor of electrical engineering and computer
science, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994, following 38 years
of service.
Professor Galler received two bachelor's degrees, in 1946 and 1947, from the
University of Chicago, a master's degree in 1949 from the University of California at Los Angeles, and a Ph.D. degree in 1955 from the University of Chicago.
He joined the University of Michigan Department of Mathematics in 1955 as an
instructor, he was promoted to assistant professor in 1959, associate professor in
1962, and professor in 1966.
As a pioneer in the field of computer science, Professor Galler helped shape
this discipline at the University. In the early 1960s, he was active in the development of the new Communication Sciences Program, and in 1966, he became associate director of the Computing Center. His association with the Computing
Center continued through 1991, during a period of tremendous growth and
change in the areas of computer science and computing services. He became a
charter member of the new Department of Computer and Communication
Sciences (CCS) in 1966 and served as chair of the department from 1973-75. In
1984, Professor Galler was instrumental in negotiating the merger of the CCS
Department and the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer
Science.
The Department of Computer and Communication Sciences was one of the
first of its kind in the country, so it is not surprising that Professor Galler was
influential in the development of the software and mathematics curriculum for
computer science. Professor Galler has also provided vital service to the wider


288




May Meeting, 1994


University community, serving as associate dean for long-range planning in the
College of Literature, Science, and the Arts from 1975-79, and on many
University-wide committees and task forces over the years. Despite all of his
administrative responsibilities, he has served as undergraduate counselor for the
computer science degree program for many years.
On the national level, Professor Galler served as an officer of the Association
for Computing Machinery (ACM) from its earliest days, including the presidency
from 1968-70; in 1980, the ACM awarded him its Distinguished Service Award
for his contributions to the field. He has served on many other national boards
and committees and has been recognized by his peers with numerous awards and
honors. In recent years, he has been instrumental in developing a national record
of the history of computing.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Bernard A Galler professor emeritus of electrical engineering and computer
science.
Arinando A. Ghitalla, professor of music (trumpet), will retire from active
faculty status on May 31, 1994.
Professor Ghitalla received his B.S. degree from the Juilliard School of
Music in 1950, after which he embarked on a highly distinguished career as
trumpet performer. Following service as principal trumpet in the New York City
Opera Orchestra and then in the Houston Symphony Orchestra, Professor
Ghitalla became principal trumpet in the Boston Symphony Orchestra-a post
he occupied with elan for 28 years (1951-79). While principally engaged in
orchestral performance, Professor Ghitalla also taught part-time at the Tanglewood Music Center (summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra), Boston
University, and the New England Conservatory of Music. He came to the
University of Michigan in 1979 as professor of music (trumpet).
At the University of Michigan, Professor Ghitalla gave a decade and a half of
dedicated, expert, gentle, yet demanding instruction to aspiring young trumpeters. In 1991, he was given the Harold Haugh Award for excellence in studio
instruction, in recognition of his outstanding effectiveness in teaching. A noteworthy characteristic of his relationship with students is that it did not begin and
end at his office door: an enthusiastic and dashing cook, Professor Ghitalla furnished many an impecunious student with gourmet cuisine otherwise unavailable to them, regaling them with music "war stories" and arming them with
valuable practical information about American orchestral life.
During his tenure at Michigan, Professor Ghitalla was a frequent guest
recitalist and visiting teacher throughout the United States. In 1980, he made a
tour of Italy performing concerts, and in 1982 he visited Japan, giving an
extended series of recitals. With typical kindness and generosity, Professor
Ghitalla capped his career on the Michigan faculty by donating 23 valuable trumpets to the Steams Collection of Musical Instruments, and his life-long collection
of materials and music associated with trumpet performance to the music
library. Principally though, he gave of himself, his talent, his wide experience,
and his deep love of his art. Generations of students are in his debt.
The Regents now salute this distinguished member of the faculty by naming
Armando A Ghitalla professor emeritus of music (trumpet).


289




May Meeting, 1994


Elmer G. Gilbert, professor of aerospace engineering and professor of
electrical engineering and computer science, will retire from active faculty status
on May 31, 1994.
Professor Gilbert received his B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in 1952, 1953,
and 1957, respectively, all from the University of Michigan. He joined the
Department of Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering (now aerospace
engineering) as an instructor in 1953 and was promoted to assistant professor in
1957, associate professor in 1959, and professor in 1963. In 1987, he received an
additional appointment as professor of electrical engineering and computer
science.
Professor Gilbert was instrumental in establishing strong graduate-level
programs in information and control engineering, computer, information and
control engineering, and aerospace engineering. His high standards of scholarship have had a major influence on the control curriculum, with his emphasis on
depth of understanding and mastery rather than superficial understanding of
isolated topics. Professor Gilbert has also been extremely productive in the guidance of graduate students, having chaired 22 Ph.D. dissertation committees and
influenced many other graduate students in other departments.
A productive researcher, Professor Gilbert has made numerous contributions in the areas of dynamic-system simulation, linear systems and control
theory, optimal control of aerospace and robotics systems, and numerical optimization techniques. He was also one of the founders, in 1957, of Applied Dynamics
International, an Ann Arbor company that is a leading supplier of high-speed
digital computers for simulation. He holds nine patents in simulation and control
technology.
Professor Gilbert is a fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics
Engineers and received two IEEE Control Systems Society best paper awards.
He was also elected to the Johns Hopkins Society of Fellows and received a University of Michigan Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award. In 1993, he
delivered the plenary speech at the American Control Conference in Chicago.
Most recently, Professor Gilbert received the IEEE Control Systems Award and
was elected to the National Academy of Engineering.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his outstanding career by
naming Elmer G. Gilbert professor emeritus of aerospace engineering and professor emeritus of electrical engineering and computer science.
L. A. Peter Gosling, professor of Southeast Asian studies in the Department of Anthropology, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994,
after a most productive career as a teacher and researcher.
Professor Gosling received his AB. degree in 1952, his M.A. degree in 1953,
and his Ph.D. degree in 1958, all from the University of Michigan. He joined the
Department of Geography as an instructor in 1956 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1959, associate professor in 1964, and professor in 1970. During
his tenure in the Department of Geography, he served two terms as chair of the
department. He transferred to the Department of Anthropology in 1982.


290




May Meeting, 1994


Professor Gosling was a founder of the Center for South and Southeast
Asian Studies and served three times as its director. In 1983, he started the
Southeast Asia Business Program, the only program of its kind in the country,
and served as its director until 1993. He also served for thirteen years as the chief
administrative officer of the Association for Asian Studies, the world's largest
learned society for Asia specialists, which is based at the University of Michigan.
Although he has conducted field research and consulted throughout Asia,
Professor Gosling has specialized in Southeast Asia, where he has conducted extensive field research on rural development, population movement, and ethnic
relations. He has served as consultant to a number of international development
agencies and foundations, including the United Nations, the U.S. Agency for International Development, The World Bank, and the Ford Foundation, and
taught at the University of Malaya. Professor Gosling has also served as chair of
the National Research Council-National Academy of Science Advisory Committee
on Geography, and on committees for such organizations as the Social Science
Research Council, American Council of Learned Societies, the National Humanities Alliance, the Association of American Geographers, the Asia Society, the
Ford Foundation, and the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies.
The Regents now salute this distinguished educator for his dedicated service
by naming L. A Peter Gosling professor emeritus of Southeast Asian studies.
Donald T. Greenwood, professor of aerospace engineering, will retire
from active faculty status on May 31, 1994, after an outstanding career at the
University of Michigan.
Professor Greenwood received his B.S. degree in 1944, his M.S. degree in
1948, and his Ph.D. degree in 1951, all from the California Institute of Technology. From 1951-56, he worked at Lockheed Aircraft and the University of Southern California in the area of analog computing. He joined the University of
Michigan in 1956 as an assistant professor in the Department of Aeronautical
and Astronautical Engineering (now aerospace engineering); he was promoted to
associate professor in 1957, and professor in 1963.
Professor Greenwood is best known for his exceptional books on dynamics.
These books provide more than a good exposition on this fundamental subject;
they focus on the practice of solving difficult dynamics problems. This focus was
reinforced by Professor Greenwood in the courses he taught, which earned a
reputation for posing challenging problems that tested the limits of his students'
understanding and abilities. Students have benefited greatly from his thoughtful
explanations and his emphasis on exploiting physical insight in solving problems.
In recognition of his considerable teaching skills, Professor Greenwood was
awarded the Good Teaching Award by the college in 1986.
Professor Greenwood's areas of interest have included dynamics, analog
computation, computer simulation of dynamic systems, control systems, and constrained dynamical systems. He has published numerous articles in scientific and
engineering journals, many conference proceedings, two books on dynamics, and
a book chapter on network analogies of dynamic systems. He has also been a
member of many scientific and professional societies. In addition to his professional accomplishments, Professor Greenwood has been a valued and dedicated
member of the department. In particular, his dedication as an adviser to


291




May Meeting, 1994


freshman and other undergraduate engineering students, and to graduate students, is widely recognized. Professor Greenwood has made enormous contributions to the educational program of the department.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his outstanding service by
naming Donald T. Greenwood professor emeritus of aerospace engineering.
John A. Larson, professor of management at the University of MichiganFlint, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994, after a most productive career as a teacher, researcher, and administrator.
A native of Arkansas, Professor Larson received his M.B.A degree in
accounting (1948) and his Ph.D. degree in political science (1956) from
Northwestern University. He was an officer in the U.S. Navy during World War
II. From 1947-76, Professor Larson taught at Little Rock Junior College, Northwestern University, the University of Tennessee, the University of California at
Berkeley, the University of California at Davis, Stanford University, Pacific
Lutheran University, and the University of Michigan. During that time, he also
worked for the Business Executives' Research Council of Chicago, the North
Central Association-Commission on Institutions of Higher Education, and the
Brookings Institution. He joined the University of Michigan-Flint in 1976 as
professor of management and as the first dean of the newly-established School of
Management. He served as dean until 1980 and was instrumental in leading and
developing the department by expanding the faculty and degree programs.
Professor Larson has been the recipient of several honors during his career,
including the Faculty Achievement Award for Distinguished Service (1985) and a
nomination for Educator of the Year (1988) award by the Sales and Marketing
Executives of Flint. He is a member of Beta Gamma Sigma (1948) and served as
president of its Flint chapter from 1985-87. He is also a member of the accounting fraternity Beta Alpha Psi (1948). In 1977, he was awarded the Shield of the
Trojan, an annual alumni award, by the University of Arkansas at Little Rock
In addition to serving on numerous departmental and campus-wide committees
on the Flint campus, Professor Larson has been involved in the Rotary Club of
Flint (president, 1988-89) and has served in leadership positions with the First
Presbyterian Church of Flint.
The Regents now salute this distinguished business educator for his dedicated service by naming John A Larson professor emeritus of management.
John D. Mohler, professor of music (clarinet), will retire from active
faculty status on May 31, 1994.
Professor Mohler studied at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia
from 1948-50. From 1950-54, he served with the U.S. Marine Corps Band in
Washington, D.C., while continuing his studies part time at Catholic University
of America. Following his discharge from the Marine Corps, he enrolled at the
University of Michigan, where he earned his B.Mus., M.Mus., and AMus.D.
degrees in 1956, 1957, and 1960, respectively. Professor Mobler served as an
instructor at Drake University from 1960-62, before joining the faculty of the
University of Michigan as an assistant professor of music in 1962. He was
promoted to associate professor in 1965 and professor in 1970. During the
summer months, he also taught at the Brevard Music Center in North Carolina,


292




May Meeting, 1994


the Cumberland Forest Music Camp in Morehead, Kentucky, and the National
Music Camp in Interlochen.
During the course of his career, Professor Mohler gave many performances
as a recitalist and chamber musician at sister institutions, including Alabama
State University, Brigham Young University, the College of William and Mary,
Oberlin College, The Ohio State University, Old Dominion University, and the
universities of Maryland, North Carolina, and Western Ontario, among others.
His long teaching career has yielded a large and devoted cadre of admirers, and
he received the Harold Haugh Award for excellence in studio instruction in 1979.
At the University of Michigan, Professor Mohler gave dozens, if not
hundreds, of performances as a member of the University Woodwind Quintet,
which presented concerts not only in Ann Arbor but also in outlying regions of
the state. He also took a leadership role in School of Music affairs as chair of his
department and member of the executive committee and of the scholarship
committee. He also served terms on the Board in Control of Intercollegiate
Athletics and as a member of Senate Assembly. In 1986, he was president of the
International Clarinet Society.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming John D. Mohler professor emeritus of music (clarinet).
Arch W. Naylor, professor of electrical engineering and computer science,
will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994.
Professor Naylor received his B.S. degree in 1952 from the University of
California at Berkeley. After serving in the U.S. Army, he returned to the
University of California for graduate work from  1955-56. From  1957-58,
Professor Naylor was a Fulbright Scholar at Technical University, Delft, Netherlands, after which he entered the University of Michigan, where he earned his
Ph.D. degree in 1960. He joined the faculty as assistant professor of electrical
engineering (now known as electrical engineering and computer science) in 1960
and was promoted to associate professor in 1963 and professor in 1969.
While a graduate student at Michigan, Professor Naylor worked as a
research associate with the Electronics Defense Group at the Cooley Electronics
Laboratory. His research in control systems has been internationally recognized,
as shown by prestigious visiting appointments at the Technical University at
Delft in 1963-64, the Laboratoire d'Automatique, Institut Polytechnique, Universit6 de Grenoble from 1967-78, the University of Chile in 1969, and the Institut
National de Recherche en Informatique en Automatique in Versailles, France, in
1989. In addition, he always maintained an active involvement in industry,
working at the Collins Radio Company while a student at Berkeley, and at
Phillips Company, Europe's largest electronics firm, while studying in The
Netherlands. He has also served as a consultant to numerous firms throughout
his career.
Professor Naylor helped introduce the developing field of information and
control engineering at the University, directing numerous research programs,
introducing important graduate courses, and publishing extensively in technical
journals. The governor's High Technology Task Force recognized these
accomplishments by appointing him acting director of the Michigan Industrial
Technology Institute during its formative period from 1982-83. Professor


293




May Meeting, 1994


Naylor's University service includes membership on several key committees,
including SACUA (elected in 1978; chair in 1980-81) and the College of Engineering Executive Committee (1987-1990).
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his many years of service
by naming Arch W. Naylor professor emeritus of electrical engineering and
computer science.
Richard H. Sands, research scientist in the Biophysics Research Division
and professor of physics, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994,
after a distinguished career as a researcher and teacher.
A native of California, Professor Sands received his B.S. degree from the
University of Redlands in 1950 and his Ph.D. degree from Washington University (St. Louis) in 1954. Professor Sands came to the University of Michigan in
1957 as assistant professor of physics, and together with Professor Peter
Franken established a pioneering program in atomic physics. He was promoted
to associate professor in 1960 and professor in 1965, and has been associated
with the Biophysics Research Division since its inception in 1964.
Professor Sands is a renowned spectroscopist who has pioneered the applications of spectroscopy to studies of proteins. In 1959, with Helmut Beinert, he
made the first electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements on a protein involved in oxidation-reduction (redox) reactions. During the course of his
career, he has developed or initiated a number of techniques, including highpower electron-nuclear double resonance (ENDOR), wide-band electron-electron
double resonance (ELDOR), and multi-frequency EPR spectroscopy. For the past
20 years, his laboratory has been one of the leaders in applications of Mossbauer
spectroscopy to the study of metalloproteins. One of Professor Sands' outstanding achievements was the elucidation of the structure of the active center of the
two-iron ferredoxins by spectroscopic analyses-an effort that combined information from magnetic susceptibility, EPR, ENDOR, Mossbauer, and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) methods to give an accurate picture of the atomic and
electronic structure of [2Fe-2S] centers. Professor Sands has also made crucial
contributions to the knowledge of molecular structure and function in several
other subclasses of redox proteins, including the cytochromes and flavoproteins.
In addition to his research activities, Professor Sands served as chair of the
Department of Physics from 1977-82 and provided a variety of service for the
graduate school, University-wide committees, the Program in Biophysics, and
IST. He has also brought his great energies to bear on both undergraduate and
graduate teaching at all levels. He has chaired 20 Ph.D. dissertation committees
and has consistently taught at the freshman/sophomore level.
The Regents now salute this distinguished scientist/educator for his dedicated service by naming Richard H. Sands research scientist emeritus and professor emeritus of physics.
Scott KE Simonds, professor of health behavior and health education and
professor of public health policy and administration in the School of Public
Health, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994.


294




May Meeting, 1994


Professor Simonds earned his B.A degree in 1949 from Occidental College.
He received his M.P.H. and Dr.P.H. degrees in 1952 and 1966, respectively, from
the University of California, Berkeley. From 1962-66, he was chief health education consultant and acting head of the state heart disease control program for the
U.S. Public Health Service. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1966
as associate professor of health education (now health behavior and health education), and was promoted to professor in 1971. He received the additional
appointment as professor of public health policy and administration in 1991.
While at the School of Public Health, Professor Simonds served as the director of the Program in Health Education, assistant dean for curriculum, and director of the Non-Residential Program in Public Health Policy and
Administration. His teaching has been central to the training of students in
health behavior and health education.
Professor Simonds has long been a national and international leader in
health education. He is a distinguished fellow of the Society for Public Health
Education, and was given the Distinguished Career Award by the American Public Health Association. In 1971, he was appointed by the president to the
National Committee on Health Education. He directed a collaborative study of
competency assessment procedures with the University of Limburg in The Netherlands and has been a frequent consultant to the World Health Organization.
His state and local service includes membership on the Governor's Environmental Education Task Force, the Superintendent's Advisory Committee on
Health Education, and the Health Education Advisory Group of the United
Community Services of Metropolitan Detroit. But it is as a teacher that Professor
Simonds will be most remembered, for he brought to the classroom a deep understanding of health education practice and policy. His classes were real-world oriented and generated a high level of interest and enthusiasm among all involved.
He used innovative teaching techniques and spearheaded the establishment of
competency-based curricula in his department and the school. He has been an
honored and distinguished colleague whose work has enriched the professional
preparation of countless numbers of public health students.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Scott K Simonds
professor emeritus of health behavior and health education and professor emeritus of public health policy and administration.
William B. Stapp, professor of resource planning and conservation, will
retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994, after a productive career as a
teacher and researcher.
Professor Stapp earned his B.S. degree in 1951, his M.A degree in 1958, and
his Ph.D. degree in 1963, all from the University of Michigan. He joined the faculty of the School of Natural Resources in 1964 as a lecturer. He was promoted to
associate professor in 1965, was awarded tenure in 1967, and was promoted to
professor in 1970. During his career, Professor Stapp focused on the root causes
of environmental problems and on educating people to find solutions to those
problems. He and his students are largely responsible for the spread of
environmental education into the curricula of schools around the globe.
In the 1960s and 1970s, Professor Stapp expanded his efforts in environmental education from the local level to the national and international levels as


295




May Meeting, 1994


an advisor to U.S. government agencies and as the first director of the Environmental Education Program for the United Nations (UNESCO) in Paris. Professor Stapp was a founder and first president of the North American Association of
Environmental Education and has worked with the International Union for the
Conservation of Nature in Geneva, the United Nations Environment
Progrmme in Nairobi, and a host of other programs and projects in both
industrialized and developing nations. In 1989, Professor Stapp founded the
Global Rivers Environmental Education Network (GREEN), which grew out of a
1986-87 science project at the School of Natural Resources and Environment. Today, GREEN    is an independent organization linking teachers, students,
administrators, and professionals in river education programs in all 50 states and
125 countries.
A researcher and author of international renown, Professor Stapp has participated in workshops, conferences, industrial programs, and sponsored research
activities throughout the world. He has received more than 40 international,
national, and provincial awards for his accomplishments in the field of
environmental education, including the President's Environmental and Conservation Challenge Award in 1992. At the same time, he has remained a strong
force at the School of Natural Resources and Environment, preparing hundreds
of students from all over the world to be researchers and educators in the environmental education field. He is indeed an exemplary model of both an educator
and a world citizen.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming William   B. Stapp professor emeritus of resource planning and
conservation.
George B. Wilson, professor of music (composition), will retire from active
faculty status on May 31, 1994.
Professor Wilson earned his B.Mus. degree in 1951, his M.Mus. degree in
1953, and his A.Mus.D. degree in 1962, all from the University of Michigan. He
undertook additional studies at the Conservatoire Royale de Musique, Bruxelles
(1953-54); the Ecole d'Artes Americaines, Fountainebleau (1954); and the
Tanglewood Music Center (1955). He joined the University of Michigan faculty
as a lecturer in 1961 and was promoted to instructor in 1963, assistant professor
in 1964, associate professor in 1966, and professor in 1971.
Professor Wilson served as director of the Electronic Music Studios from
1964 until his retirement, taking principal responsibility for the construction and
on-going development of that facility, aided by four successive grants from the
National Endowment for the Arts in the early 1980s. He was a founding member
of the Society for Electro-Acoustic Music in the United States, which honored
him upon his retirement. In 1967, Professor Wilson helped to found the Contemporary Directions Ensemble, which is dedicated to the performance of new music-primarily that of students-and has continuing importance to date.
Throughout his teaching career, Professor Wilson has always been a powerful advocate for students-utterly devoted to their well-being and to the development of their talents. His impact on their thinking has been enormous. Professor
Wilson's own compositions are not numerous but are of very high quality: they
have been performed by such noteworthy performers as Pierre Boulez and


296




May Meeting, 1994


Gunther Schuller, and in locales as diverse as Bergen (Norway), Boston, Bourge
(France), Rome, and Wichita (Kansas). The quality of his compositions has been
recognized by his having received awards from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers; the Walter Hinrichsen Award for Composers; an
award and citation from the National Institute of Arts and Letters; a Society for
the Publication of American Music Award; and the Rome Prize.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming George B. Wilson
professor emeritus of music (composition).
Raymond A. Yagle, professor of naval architecture and marine engineering, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1994, after 45 years of
service.
Professor Yagle received his B.S. degree in 1944 and his M.S. degree in 1947,
both from the University of Michigan. Following his initial appointment at the
University of Michigan's Engineering Research Institute as a lecturer in 1950, he
was appointed assistant professor in the Department of Naval Architecture and
Marine Engineering in 1955. He was promoted to associate professor in 1961 and
to professor in 1965.
During his career, Professor Yagle taught an exceptionally wide range of
courses and introduced a number of new courses in computer applications and
ocean engineering. He served as undergraduate program advisor for several decades, taking an important role in the revision of the program and in developing
concepts and procedures.
Professor Yagle chaired and served on many important national and international technical committees and on a number of departmental, college, and
University committees. His many technical papers, reports, and chapters in
books have made valuable contributions to marine technology. Recognized as a
leading authority on undergraduate education for the marine industry, Professor
Yagle has also written many papers on this subject. In 1993, Professor Yagle
received the department's Outstanding Service Award.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his many years of service
by naming Raymond A Yagle professor emeritus of naval architecture and marine engineering.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.

Alternative Asset Investments
Regent McFee moved that follow-on investments be made with the approval
of two University officers as provided for in Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07.2.a on
approval of investment transactions, for situations where the Board has approved an investment in a fund sponsored by the same group with essentially the
same strategy and core investment personnel. Further, she moved that add-on
investments of up to 10 percent of the original commitment amount, be made
with the approval of two University officers as required in Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07.2.a, provided that the add-on investment is consistent with the original
strategy of the fund.
Following some discussion, Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was
approved unanimously.

University employee, this purchase contract falls under the state of Michigan
Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance
with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the purchase contract will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and Marcia Watkins.

May Meeting, 1994

original large soft-sculpted African tribal doll, for the sum of $400. The doll and

the University Pavilion. Other than payment of the purchase price, no facilities,
services, or employees of the University of Michigan will be involved in the
purchase.
3.   Professor Watldns' pecuniary interest arises from her creation and ownership
of the dolls as a freelance artist and receipt of revenues from her artwork
Clinical Trial Subcontract with St. Joseph Mercy Hospital and the
Emergency Physicians Medical Group

unanimously approved a clinical trial subcontract between the Regents of the
University of Michigan, St. Joseph Mercy Hospital (SJMH), and the Emergency
Physicians Medical Group (EPMG). Because one of the physicians involved in
the subcontract, James Mitchiner, is an employee of SJMH, EPMG, and the University of Michigan, this agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict of
Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  The subcontract to be signed is in compliance with University policies and in
accord with the terms of its contract with the Upjohn Company. The University
will pay $5,000 to SJMH, which sum includes direct and indirect costs.
2.   Dr. Mitchiner's financial interest arises from the salary he receives from SJMH
and EPMG. He plays no role with regard to the University's performance on
the prime contract.

302




JUNE MEETING, 1994


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, June 16, 1994
Public Comments
The Regents met at 4:00 p.m. in the Anderson Room of the Michigan Union.
Present were President Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee,
McGowan, Power, and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy was also
present, as were Provost Whitaker, Executive Vice President Womack, Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim Chancellor Kugler,
and Chancellor Renick. Regent Varner was absent.
The Regents heard comments from the following people, on the topics indicated: Mike Christie, Jr., a student and member of Michigan Student Assembly,
on textbook prices; Wayne A Wolbert, student, on a United Farm Workers boycott of California grapes; and Marcia Federbush, citizen, on inequities between
men's and women's gymnastics.
Following the completion of the public comments session at 4:20 p.m., the
meeting recessed until the following day.
Friday, June 17, 1994
The Regents met at 9:00 a.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, Deitch, McFee, McGowan, Power,
Varner, and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy was also present, as
were Provost Whitaker, Executive Vice President Womack, Vice Presidents Cosovich, Harrison, Hartford, and Neal, Interim Chancellor Kugler, and Chancellor
Renick.
Internal Audit of Department of Communications            Endowment
Accounts
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and observed that a routine, internal audit of Department of Communications endowment accounts had
raised questions about whether certain expenditures that had been charged to
that account were consistent with the stated intent of the endowments. He emphasized that the issue was not whether the expenditures themselves were inappropriate, but whether they had been charged to the proper accounts.
After receiving the audit, the University had immediately removed the
charges in question and had made the endowment accounts whole. He noted that
the matter had received unusual attention by the local media.


303




June Meeting, 1994


The fiundamental issue, he noted, is the University's stewardship over gifts
contributed to support its activities. He stated that the University accepts full responsibility for ensuring that all funds contributed are spent for the purposes intended by the donors. This is accomplished by certification, which means making
certain that those who have authority to spend resources from endowment accounts certify that they understand the purpose of those endowments and that to
the best of their knowledge the expenditures they authorize are consistent with
those purposes. If it is found that questions are raised about charges to the accounts, the departments are required to make restitution by transferring funds
from other sources to the endowment accounts. He said he believes that the dual
approach of certification and restitution provides an effective method to ensure
that all funds contributed to the University are utilized for the purpose intended
by the donor.
President Duderstadt noted that there are 3,000 endowment or fundsfunctioning-as-endowment accounts, and each has an authorized signer who
bears primary responsibility for complying with the wishes of a donor. However,
a memorandum is to be sent to all deans, directors, and department heads to reemphasize their responsibility for assuring that all expenditures are in accordance both with University policies and with restrictions placed by the donors.
Each dean has been asked to review the guidelines for endowment expenditures,
and to certify that guidelines do exist for each endowment or restricted account
and that authorized signers are knowledgeable about these guidelines. The same
memorandum will be sent with account statements to project directors of such
funds. Further, all documents requesting or authorizing expenditures against
donor-restricted accounts will contain a certification that will ensure that the requested expenditure is consistent with the donor's wishes and contributions.
Each academic unit will be required to submit annually to the provost a brief
written description of the activity supported by the endowment or the fund, and
to certify that all expenditures against each endowment were consistent with the
purposes of the gift. Where such expenditures are found to be inconsistent, the
units will be required to make restitution.
Executive Vice President Womack expressed agreement that this was the
proper approach to take. Regent Brown observed that this matter was extremely
important to the Regents as well as to the University, and that it is essential that
alumni, donors, and prospective donors have complete confidence that gifts will
be used in accordance with the donor's designation. Regent Baker pointed out
that the process already in place had worked, as the expenditures that had been
charged improperly to the endowment accounts had been discovered through an
internal audit.
Regent Deitch pointed out that the more vague the goals of a particular endowment, the easier it is to charge expenditures against it improperly. He suggested that there be a central office that would consider whether the donor's
intent was being followed. He also suggested considering the idea of personal responsibility, rather than departmental responsibility, for improperly charged
expenditures.


304




June Meeting, 1994


Provost Whitaker observed that the current practice is to have endowment
gifts reviewed by an attorney in the development office, which results in more
clarity about the purposes of the gifts than what used to be the case. Executive
Vice President Womack pointed out that the best type of gifts are unrestricted
gifts, which place in the dean's hands the ability to determine the most appropriate use for them. He stated that the responsibility for determining which expenditures are in keeping with the donor's restrictions should lie not with a central
office, but with those who are responsible for the school or department. A preaudit would not constitute a sufficient control over the expenditures of these
funds. According to Executive Vice President Womack, restrictions on spending
are best applied by the individual authorized by the institution to sign for
expenditures.
Regent Power noted that there are problems with restricted endowments
created by the passage of time, and that the new guidelines would help clarify instances where such problems exist. He also pointed out that this whole episode is
an indication that the system works as it is intended to work An internal audit
had discovered instances in which money had been spent legally, but not in accordance with the purposes of the endowments. The findings had been aired; a
remedy, restitution, had been implemented; and the incident had triggered the
University's clarifying its policies with respect to these matters.
Report of the UM-Dearborn Faculty Senate Budget and Finance Committee
President Duderstadt called on Professor Seth Hirshorn, chair of the UMDearborn faculty senate, to present the report of the Senate Budget and Finance
Committee. Professor Hirshorn stated that the committee embraces the administration's goals in the following areas: 1) improving the quality of undergraduate
and graduate education; 2) limiting tuition increases; 3) improving the research
environment to enable the faculty to make its contribution to improving society
through research and development; and 4) increasing faculty salaries.
Professor Hirshorn observed that the branch campuses provide quality undergraduate education to a substantial portion of instate students. He also noted
that the Dearborn campus had recently educated its 1000th graduate student,
which is a landmark in the maturation of the campus and indicates that many
faculty members are engaged in graduate, as well as undergraduate education.
The campus has also reached a milestone of $1 million in contracted research activities, which is significant, given the fact that most faculty are so heavily involved in teaching activities. The chancellor has set a goal of $10 million in
contracted research over the next few years, which means that the Dearborn
campus will have to strengthen faculty relations with the Ann Arbor campus in
attaining that goal.
In the area of faculty salaries, Professor Hirshorn pointed out that the Dearborn faculty have consistently lagged behind peer institutions, and that longterm faculty, who have committed their adult lives to the institution, are the ones
who are least rewarded, especially when compared to newly-hired faculty. This
causes a morale problem. President Duderstadt responded that the Regents and


305




June Meeting, 1994


administration are very sensitive to the problems Professor Hirshorn described,
and that he was hopeful that the legislature was beginning to address these
issues.
CESF Report, University of Michigan-Flint
Chancellor Kugler introduced Professor Doug Miller, chair of the UM-Flint
faculty council, to present the report of the Committee on the Economic Status of
the Faculty at the UM-Flint. Professor Miller observed that the upcoming inauguration of Charlie Nelms as the fourth chancellor of the UM-Flint and the opening of the new library on the Flint campus provide an opportunity to
acknowledge the link between the Board of Regents and the UM-Flint faculty as
the cornerstone on which the success of the campus has been built. He reviewed
the history of the Flint campus and described some of the recent initiatives that
have been undertaken there. Professor Miller observed that the UM-Flint has become a home for the nontraditional student.
Regarding the CESF Report, Professor Miller stated that faculty salaries at
all ranks are above the median for peer institutions, but that faculty are concerned about salary differences among schools within the UM-Flint. Finally, he
indicated that Flint faculty are generally in favor of flexible benefits proposals.
Regent Baker expressed the Regents' appreciation to the Flint faculty for
their steadfastness in pursuing the development of the Flint campus. He noted
that this campus had gone well beyond the original expectations of the Board in
its physical plant, the breadth of its educational mission, and its success in bringing a particular dimension of education to Flint.
Regent McFee observed that both the Flint and Dearborn campuses serve
large numbers of nontraditional students and commented that the University's
ability to fulfill the needs of these students is a real service to the state's
population.
Regent Power noted that both regional campuses have the opportunity to
set forth a strategic role and mission which "adds value" to the University of
Michigan and the state's citizens, without necessarily replicating what is provided in Ann Arbor.
Michigan Student Assembly Financial Matters (Audit Report); 1994
Fee Assessments for Michigan Student Assembly and School/College
Governments
Vice President Hartford introduced Ms. Julie Neenan and Mr. Jacob Stern,
president and executive vice president, respectively, of Michigan Student Assembly (MSA). Ms. Neenan stated that MSA is requesting a fee assessment of $2.69
per student per term for MSA and $1.00 per student per term for school and college governments for the 1994-95 year. These requests represent no increase over
the previous year's fee assessments.
Regarding the audit report, Regent Power expressed enthusiasm about the
mostly benign and complimentary management letter and the clean audit.


306




June Meeting, 1994


Executive Vice President Womack and Mr. Carl Smith, director of university
audits, concurred with Regent Power's assessment, and said that MSA should be
congratulated for it. Vice President Hartford expressed pride in the quality of
student leadership of MSA and noted that the $2.69 per student per term fee is
one of the smallest of any student government for any major American
university.
Regent Varner expressed support for the plans to transfer the supervision of
Student Legal Services from MSA to the Law School. Vice President Hartford
stated that she was optimistic that the new Law School dean would be receptive
to the proposal. Regent Baker observed that the whole concept of Student Legal
Services should be discussed more broadly prior to considering its transfer to the
Law School.
Regent Power moved approval of a fee assessment of $2.69 per student per
term for MSA and $1.00 per student per term for school/college governments. Regent McFee seconded the motion.
Regent Baker reported that he had not received the MSA auditor's statement and financial report until that day and questioned why this report, which
was dated April 29, 1994, should have been delayed nearly two months. Mr.
Rodger Wolf, assistant to the vice president for student affairs for finance, responded that the date on an audit report represents the last date of the field
work for the audit. The time between that date and when the report is presented
is spent in writing the report and management letter and in holding conferences
with the client. The other Regents noted that they had received their reports
with their agenda packets the previous week.
Ms. Neenan and Mr. Stern responded to questions from Regent Baker about
specific aspects of the report. The question was then called, and Regent Power's
motion to approve the MSA and school/college government fee request was approved unanimously. Regent Brown was away from the table when the vote was
taken.
1994-95 University Health Service Fee
Vice President Hartford reported that the recommended Health Service fee
increase of 4.89 percent ($4.50 per student term) was below the medical care cost
index, as it had been for a number of years. Following some discussion, Regent
Deitch moved approval for an increase in the University Health Service Fee of
$4.50 per student per term, to bring the total to $96.50 per student per term. Regent Waters seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously. Regent
Brown was away from the table when the vote was taken.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Power, the
Regents unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of April 1994. It was
decided to withhold consideration of the May 1994 minutes until the following
month.


307




June Meeting, 1994

319




June Meeting, 1994


Personnel Actions. President Duderstadt reported that Richard Kennedy
would be stepping down as vice president for government relations and secretary
of the university as of July 1, 1994, and on that date Harold Johnson would assume the role of interim secretary of the university while a search is conducted
for Mr. Kennedy's successor. He also noted the appointment of Professor
Thomas Kinnear as interim vice president for development as of September 1,
1994, at which time Mr. Cosovich would become deputy to the president.
Provost Whitaker submitted the following personnel actions:

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Whitaker submitted retirement memoirs
for six faculty members.
John R. Bassett, professor of forestry, will retire from active faculty status
on June 30, 1994, following a distinguished career as an administrator, teacher,
and researcher.
Professor Bassett earned his AB. degree in 1949, his B.S. degree in 1965, his
M.F. degree in 1952, and his Ph.D. degree in 1961, all from the University of
Michigan. Following service in the U.S. Navy from 1952-56, he was employed by
the U.S. Forest Service from 1956-67. He joined the University of Michigan as an
assistant professor of forestry in 1967; he was promoted to associate professor in
1968 and professor of forestry in 1976.
Within the School of Natural Resources and Environment, Professor Bassett served as director of Camp Filibert Roth in the Upper Peninsula from
1967-76 and chaired the Fisheries, Forestry, and Wildlife Program from 1975-80.
He was director of undergraduate programs from 1980-83 and associate dean for
academic affairs from 1983-92.


325




June Meeting, 1994


A respected member of his profession, Professor Bassett has been a consultant to state and federal governments, private law firms, and landowners on matters concerning diverse management goals of forest lands and has held
leadership positions in the Michigan Chapter of the Society of American Foresters, the Michigan Forestry Association, the Michigan Tree Farm Committee, and
the Society of American Forestry Silviculture Working Group. These experiences
have enhanced his teaching, allowing him to show students both the practical
and theoretical sides of resource management issues.
Professor Bassett's teaching has ranged from general interest courses for
non-majors to highly specialized courses. Well over 100 students per semester
have enrolled in his class, "Forests for People." At the same time, he has taught
courses in biological management, forest biology, and his particular area of interest, silviculture or vegetation management. Professor Bassett's teaching is noteworthy for its combination of science and theory of management with practical
application in the field. Students in his classes could count on theory being translated into application by visiting research sites and management units.
Professor Bassett is perhaps best known for his research on computerized
urban tree inventories. His 1978 paper on this topic was the benchmark upon
which his sponsored research and practice developed. Recently, Professor Bassett
and his students have been pursing research of interest to the state of Michigan,
namely the reproduction of oaks on dry sites in the northern part of the lower
peninsula.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming John R. Bassett professor emeritus of forestry.
Douglas G. Dickson, professor of mathematics, retired from active faculty
status on May 31, 1994, after a productive career as a teacher and researcher.
A native of Montclair, New Jersey, Professor Dickson received his B.A
degree from Wesleyan University in 1947 and his AM. degree from Harvard
University in 1949. He taught at Dartmouth College, Hunter College, Columbia
University, and Barnard College from 1948-57 and completed his Ph.D. degree at
Columbia University in 1958. He joined the University of Michigan as assistant
professor of mathematics in 1958 and was promoted to associate professor in
1964 and professor in 1974. He visited the University of Paris on several
sabbaticals.
Professor Dickson's area of research was in complex analysis, with an emphasis on exponential sums. From 1973-75, Professor Dickson served as associate
chair for undergraduate education in the Department of Mathematics. He also
served on many departmental committees and was always a very conscientious
teacher, who was highly respected by his students. He directed four doctoral theses. From 1988-94, Professor Dickson served as editor for the Michigan Mathematical Journal, a period where the journal grew both in size and in the quality
of its publications.
The Regents now salute this mathematician for his dedicated teaching and
service by naming Douglas G. Dickson professor emeritus of mathematics.


326




June Meeting, 1994


Robert C. Kelsch, M.D., professor of pediatrics and communicable diseases in the Medical School, will retire from active faculty status on August 31,
1994.
Dr. Kelsch received his B.A degree from St. John University in Minnesota
in 1950 and his M.D. degree from St. Louis University in 1954. He served in the
U.S. Army from 1954-57 and then joined the University of Michigan medical staff
as an assistant resident in pediatrics from 1957-59. From 1959-62, he was an instructor in the Department of Pediatrics and a post-doctoral research trainee in
biochemistry, and from 1962-65 he served as assistant director of pediatrics at
Wayne County General Hospital. Dr. Kelsch was appointed assistant professor of
pediatrics in 1966 and was promoted to associate professor in 1969 and professor
in 1973.
Early in his career, Dr. Kelsch developed a keen interest in the field of renal
diseases of childhood, and he is considered to be a pioneer in the development of
the subspecialty of pediatric nephrology. Under his leadership, the Department of
Pediatrics developed one of the most outstanding programs for the care of children afflicted with renal disease. When pediatric nephrology was approved as a
subspecialty by the American Board of Medical Specialties in the early 1970s, Dr.
Kelsch was among the first cohort of successful examinees for certification in this
subspecialty when the first qualifying exam was given in 1974. Dr. Kelsch has
been elected to membership in numerous professional associations and has received the most prestigious teaching awards in the Medical Center, including the
Kaiser Permanente Award for Excellence in Teaching in the Clinical Sciences
(1985) and the Department of Pediatrics House Staff Faculty Teaching Award
(1990).
Dr. Kelsch's clinical and administrative service has also been exceptional.
He has served as director of Pediatric Laboratories, director of the Pediatric General Services, acting chair of the Department of Pediatrics (1980-81), director of
Pediatric Ambulatory Care Services, and director of the Pediatric Nephrology
Service. He also served for more than a decade as the sequence coordinator for
the "Introduction to Clinical Sciences" course. He has participated extensively in
the Inteflex program, both as a member of the Colloquium on Ethics and Human
Values in Science and the Inteflex Policy Committee. Throughout his career, Dr.
Kelsch has also taught general pediatrics and cared for children with general
medical as well as renal disorders. Well-known for his passionate, effective, and
highly humane approach to patients and their families, Dr. Kelsch has established a legacy of superb teaching and patient care.
In recognition of his dedicated service and distinguished and productive career, the Regents now name Robert C. Kelsch professor emeritus of pediatrics
and communicable diseases.
Donald B. Kersten, professor of art, will retire from active faculty status
on June 30, 1994, after a productive career as an artist, designer, and teacher.
Professor Kersten received his B.F.A. degree in 1956 and his M.A degree in
1961, both from Wayne State University. From 1961-64, he worked as an exhibit
designer and an interior and graphic designer for such firms as Ford & Earl
Associates, Sundberg-Ferar Inc., and General Motors. Professor Kersten joined
the faculty of the former College of Architecture and Design at the University of


327




June Meeting, 1994


Michigan as an instructor in 1964 to teach basic design, watercolor, and visualization. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1966, associate professor in
1971, and professor in 1976. Since 1974, he has taught drawing, basic design,
painting, visualization, graphic design, and aqueous media in the School of Art.
He was highly successful in fluencing students, due to his dedication to teaching and his rapport with students.
The recipient of two Rackham Research Grants (1973-75 and 1980-83), Professor Kersten's research was directed at advertising in the environment. The
first grant, "Signs at the Marketplace," culminated in an exhibit dealing primarily with on-premise advertising. The second grant, "Ad Sites as Planned Elements in the Environment," focused on urban and highway off-premise
advertising and generated a proposal for more effective and visually pleasing outdoor advertising.
Professor Kersten's professional activities include architectural delineation,
illustration, product design, and identity programs for Detroit and Ann Arbor
firms; chancel design and furnishings for Ann Arbor churches; and collaboration
on signage programs for Detroit hospital centers. Most recently, he was curator
for "One Man's Vision - The Robert L. Sutton Commemorative Exhibit" in the
Slusser Gallery of the University of Michigan School of Art. Professor Kersten is
also an accomplished and award-winning watercolor artist who has exhibited locally and nationally.
The Regents now acknowledge the contributions of this distinguished and
dedicated artist, designer, and teacher by naming Donald B. Kersten professor
emeritus of art.
Clifford S. Leonard, Jr., associate professor of romance linguistics, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1994.
Professor Leonard received his AB. degree from Yale University in 1950, his
M.A degree in French from Middlebury College in 1953, and his Ph.D. degree in
romance linguistics from Cornell University in 1960. He served on the faculty of
Cornell University from 1960-67 and the University of Wisconsin from 1967-69,
before coming to the University of Michigan in 1969 as a visiting associate professor in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures. He was appointed
associate professor in 1970 and was a teacher and scholar of comparative romance linguistics throughout his 24 years of active service.
Professor Leonard served on many departmental committees and twice
served as acting chair of the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures.
His publications include Umlaut in Romance (1978), as well as several articles on
comparative romance linguistics published in leading North American and European journals.
Professor Leonard will be remembered by his former graduate students for
the breadth of his knowledge and for the enthusiasm with which he introduced
them to the method and practice of comparative reconstruction. He gave many
University of Michigan undergraduates their first exposure to the field of romance linguistics and to the study of the history of the French language.
The Regents now salute this dedicated teacher and scholar for his devoted
service to the University by naming Clifford S. Leonard, Jr., associate professor
emeritus of romance linguistics.


328




June Meeting, 1994


Jack E. McLaughlin, professor of     mathematics, retired from active faculty
status on May 31, 1994, after a productive career as a teacher and researcher.
Born in St. Maries, Idaho, Professor McLaughlin received his B.S. degree
from the University of Idaho in 1944. He served in the UoS. Navy from 1944-46,
and then enrolled in the California Institute of Technology, where he received his
Ph.D. degree in 1950. He joined the University of Michigan as an instructor in
mathematics in 1950 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1954, associate
professor in 1958, and professor in 1963.
Professor McLaughlin's research ranged widely over the various subfields of
algebra: lattice theory, finite groups, and commutative algebra. He is credited
with the discovery of one of the sporadic finite simple groups, that of order
898,128,000, which now bears his name.
In 1986, Professor McLaughlin was awarded the Amoco Foundation Good
Teaching Award. He was an excellent and demanding teacher, especially of honors students who sought his courses to measure their ability. He directed 19 doctoral theses, and many of his students have become leaders in their fields.
The Regents now salute this mathematician for his dedicated teaching and
service by naming Jack E. McLaughlin professor emeritus of mathematics.
Roy J. Nelson, professor of French, retired from active faculty status on
May 31, 1994.
Professor Nelson received his AB. degree from the University of Pittsburgh
in 1951, his M.A degree from Middlebury College in 1952, and his Ph.D. degree
in French from the University of Illinois in 1958.
A teacher and scholar of modern French literature in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures throughout his 37 years at the University of
Michigan, Professor Nelson joined the faculty in 1957 as an instructor in French.
He was promoted to assistant professor in 1960, associate professor in 1965, and
professor in 1972.
Professor Nelson served on virtually every departmental committee and on
many college and University bodies, including the Admissions Conmittee, the
Senate Assembly, and the Divisional Board for the Humanities, which he chaired
for three years. Recognized by his colleagues for his fairness, efficiency, and devotion to democratic principles in all matters of faculty governance, he served as
acting chair of Romance Languages and Literatures, first in 1977 and most recently in 1992-93. He chaired or co-chaired ten doctoral dissertation committees
and was a member of many others.
His publications include Peguy, poete du sacre (1960) and Casuality and
Narrative in French Fiction from Zola to Robbe-Grillet (1989), as well as three
textbooks and a number of articles on French literature and film.
Generations of students remember Professor Nelson as an exceptionally
dedicated and outstanding undergraduate teacher. He introduced the study of
French film into Michigan's curriculum and directed the Honors Program in
French for 15 years prior to his retirement. His devotion to students and success
in teaching were recognized by his having received the Ruth Sinclair Award for
Honors Counseling and, in 1992, the Amoco Foundation Good Teaching Award.


329




June Meeting, 1994


The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and scholar and recognize his many years of devoted service to the University by naming Roy J. Nelson
professor emeritus of French.
Memorials. No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.

voting.

M-Quality. Following the break, Regent Baker expressed the Regents'
gratitude for the efforts of staff members who have participated in M-Quality
training. Executive Vice President Womack observed that a wide variety of people from across the University deserve credit for the progress of the M-Quality
initiative.
Associate Vice President for Finance. Executive Vice President
Womack announced that Mr. Chandler Matthews, associate vice president for
finance, will retire in March of 1995. He observed that in his 24 years at the
University, Mr. Matthews had served as a trusted confidant for him and for his
predecessors, William Pierpont and James Brinkerhoff. He expressed regret
about Mr. Matthews decision to retire, but pleasure that this decision was what
he wants to do, noting that "he is a true gentleman and a great asset to the University of Michigan."
Authorization for Expenditures in 1994-95
Executive Vice President Womack noted that this request allows the University to operate until such time as the 1994-95 budget can be prepared and presented for Regental approval. He reported that in contrast to recent practice,
both revenue budgets and detailed expenditure budgets would be presented in
July.
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved temporary actions for expenditures in 1994-95, under the
following guidelines: 1) Payments for non-salary expenditures in 1994-95 will be
made at a rate not to exceed the monthly budget levels for 1993-94; 2) Salary expenditures in 1994-95 will be made on the basis of salary budgets in effect for
1993-94.
Revision of Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07.2.b (Approval and Execution
of University Documents)
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved a change in Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07.2.b so as to increase from $250,000 to $750,000 the amount of a grant or contract for which the
executive vice president and chief financial officer can delegate in writing to


330




June Meeting, 1994


designated representatives the authority to execute contracts and/or applications
for grants or contracts.
The following is the text of the revised bylaw:
Sec. 3.07.2.b Approval and Execution of University Documents
b. All contracts for sponsored research and supplements thereto, including agreements for fellowships, scholarships, and grants-in-aid, and all contracts covering payment for tuition and supplies may be executed by the executive vice president and chief
financial officer; and the executive vice president and chief financial officer's signature
shall be certified by the secretary where such certification is requested, provided, however, the executive vice president and chieffinancial officer is authorized to delegate in
writing to designated representatives authority to execute contracts and/or applications
for grants or contracts where the amount involved is less than $750,000 and/or training grants or fellowship programs which do not exceed a rate of $250,000 per year and
where the commitments anticipated fall within the normal activities of the University.
Expenditure of the Income of the Julian A. Wolfson and Marguerite
Wolfson Endowment Funds for the Fiscal Year 1994-95
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent McFee, the Regents
unanimously approved the uses of the income of the Wolfson Endowment Funds
for fiscal year 1994-95, as recommended by the Law School faculty, and as described in the Regents Communication.
